Edward epistle to pope Nicolas 2. the chief father of the universal church EDWARD by the grace of God king of England send due subjection and obedience we glorify our lord for the care he have of his elect church in ordain thou a excellent successor in the place and seat of thy good predecessor wherefore we think it fit to lean unto thou as unto a firm rock to sharpen and approve all our good action and always to admit of thy knowledge and fellowship in do good especial desire thou will renew and increase all those donation and privilege which we obtain from thy predecessor to wit that thou ratify and confirm the monastery of monk which I have build in honour of the b. apostle s. PETER according as it be enjoin i by thy predecessor under title of obedience and penance for the dispensation of a vow I make to go to Rome and the remission of all my sin as allsoe that thou reestablish determine and secure all the privilege belong to the he willing pay duty to Rome possession peace and dignity of that place for ever and I for as much as lie in i do increase and confirm the donation and custom of the money which s. PETER hold and challenge in England and now I send they accompany with other free gift from myself humble entreat thou to offer prayer and sacrifice to almighty God for i and the peace of my kingdom and that thou institute and ordain a continual and solemn memory of all England in general before the sacred body of the apostle 14 the pope answer he in this manner Nicolas the pope answer to the king bishop servant of the servant of God to the most glorious most pious and most worthy of all honour our special belove EDWARD king of England send all manner of salutation most sweet health and apostolical benediction we give thanks unto almighty God who have adorn and honour thy most prudent excellence in all respect to conserve devotion towards the bless apostle s. PETER and all love towards we his unworthy successor in give obedience and consent unto Apostolicque counsel and censure we therefore send our letter to thy royal nobility whereby we grant unto thou the holy apostle society and we beseech his mercy who be true lord of all and only sovereign above all to make thou taker of all our good work if any we have in the sight of God and at all time to make we more fervent brethren and fellow in his love wish he to grant no less part or reward of our duty and obedience in his heavenly kingdom unto thou than we desire to fall unto ourselves allsoe we will not cease hereafter unfeigned to pour out our daily prayer for thou that God himself will bring thy foe and enemy which attempt to rebel against thou into subjection and confirm in thou the inheritance of thy father throne beseech the bless apostle s. peter to be thy guardian and aid in all tribulation or adversity that may befall thou we therefore do restablish confirm and increase all privilege give in thy behalf to wit that thou be clear absolve from the vow which thou do seem to fear and from all other thy sin and iniquity by the authority of he that have ordain my unworthiness chief pastor of his church furthermore because it be credible report that that place which under title of holy penance thou have undertake to build and repair have long since be consecrate by the hand of s. PETER himself who unworthy vicar we be as allsoe because it be and have be the ancient seat of king we by the authority of God and of the holy apostle and by the power of this Poman sea and we do grant permit and most strong confirm that henceforth for ever it be the place of the king coronation and the storehouse of his royal enseigne and a perpetual habitation for monk independent of any other person but only the king himself and that they enjoy absolute power to elect fit and worthy abbot out of their own body to succeed in the government according to the rule of s. Benedict Westminster privilege confirm to the Benedictine monk and exempt from bishop and that no sorreigne or strange person be bring in by violence but such as the convent shall free consent to elect we do alsoe exempt absolve and free that place from all episcopal subjection and jurisdiction that no bishop enter there either to order or command any thing unless it be do by the desire and consent of the abbot and his monk and that the same place enjoy a free precinct that be a circuit and churchyard about it to bury the dead without any respect or exaction of the bishop or any other person and with a most ready and willing mind we give and grant to that place all privilege whatsoever by our authority may be grant which belong any way to the honour of God and to increase the dignity of the place we do likewise by the authority of God and we ratify confirm and establish all the possession and hereditament which ancient king or any other person or thou thyself or any of thy lord have grant unto the same place and all the charter and writing make of the same donation we decree to be and remain still in force and all such person as shall attempt to infringe invade diminish disperse or make sale of the same we condemn and declare they to be guilty of eternal malediction with the traitor judas and that they be not partaker of the bless resurrection but that they know themselves to be adjudge by s. PETER the apostle when with his fellow-apostle he shall sit in judgement over the twelve tribe of Jsrael but unto thou and thy successour-king we commit to be the advocat and defender of the same place and of all the church of England in our place and steed that with the council of thy bishop and abbot thou constitute and ordain all thing in all place according to justice and know that for such good do thou shall receive a worthy reward from he who kingdom and empire shall never cease nor be diminish this be the pope answer now let we return to s. EDWARD 15 go once with the queen and earl Harold to see a P^^ (@) great sum of money which without his knowledge they have collect throughout the realm to supply his want and especial to clothe his soldier and servant with new livery against the feast of Christmas enter with they into the exchequer he espy the devil sit and sport himself upon that heap of money of who the king have demand what business he have there I keep my money reply he unjust get out of the good of the poor whereupon the stander by be much amaze hear their speech but see nothing but the holy king s. Edward contempt of money that contemn all temporal riches for love of the eternal command all that money to be present restore from whence it come give herein a perfect example to all prince and ruler in the world not to maintain the glory of their bravery with money wrongful raise and force out of the mean of their poor subject the commonalty the like clemency move he out of his royal bounty to remit and free release his subject he remit dane-gilt of that most grievous tribute call dane-gilt which in his father time be pay to the danish navy and afterward bring into the king exchequer but he command it shall be no more exact free thereby the realm of England for ever of that unsupportable burden 16 be on a time in his palace near to s. Edward tomb till one night he hear a voice that call he by his name bid he rise and go to the church but as he go he seem to behold king edward in great glory go before he and from that three cure of quartan ague time he have the perfect use of his sight ever after allsoe a monk of Westminster a very learned man one sir guerin a knight and a other man of bark be all three cure of quartan ague as they pray at his holy tomb 29 six and thirty year after the death of this glorious king his sepulchre be open at the earnest request and suit of his body find uncorrupted the people his holy body be find most entire without any the lest sign of corruption as clear and white as the crystal as if it have all ready put on the divine robe of glory cast forth of the tomb a exceed sweet and odoriferous savour to the wonderful joy and comfort of all that be present the linen wherein he wrap be as fresh and pure as when first it be employ to that holy use which move Gundulph bishop of Rochester to attempt to pluck a hair of the saint head to reserve to himself for his devotion but his pious desire be frustrate for the hair stick on so fast that it can not be pull off without break 30 a woman that contemptible presume to work upon s. Edward a miracle day be grievous punish with a sudden palsy till be bring to the b. saint sepulchre and with tear demand pardon for her fault she be restore to her health again many other miracle have be do by the merit of this glorious saint all which move pope Alexander the three at the instant desire of king Henry the second and the clergy of England to put he into the number of canonize saint and to cause his feast to be celebrate throughout the kingdom of England but of this we will speak more at large on the feast of his translation the thirteen day of October this feast of his deposition have be always very magnificent and religious celebrate by his successour-king on this day as plain appear in the history of England and be particular prove out of that which Matthew Westminster rehearse of king Henry the three devotion towards s. EDWARD in the year of grace 1249 say he which be the thirty year of our sovereign king Henry the three the king be then at London on the feast of the nativity of our lord and have spend the Christmas holiday in sumptuous feast and banquet as the custom be together with a great multitude of his nobility he assemble many more noble and peer of the realm to be present and Henry the three devotion to s. edwar. rejoice with he at the feast of s. EDWARD who more cordial he love and honour than other of the saint and on the eve of that b. king deposition our sovereign lord the king according to his pious custom fast with bread and water spend the whole day in continual watch and pray and give of alm but on the feast itself he cause mass with great magnificence and solemnity to be celebrate in the church of Westminster in vestment all of silk of a inestimable value and adorn with a great multitude of wax taper and the resound note of the a consideration on his virtue conuentuall and monastical quire ought not we likewise to follow this virtuous example and give praise unto almighty God for the excellent gift wherewith he honour this b. king in choose and call he to so great glory even before he be bear and for that he reveal unto he the great favour promise to the kingdom of England for his sake long before they happen who will not admire and endeavour to imitate the sacred virtue of chastity which so great a king entire conserve so many year with his queen in holy marriage who will not embrace his most profound humility and contempt of the world and himself when he carry that wretched cripple on his royal shoulder to obtain his health who will not strive to serve almighty God with affection see how high he exalt and honour his saint how he exalt they with miracle and so glorious recompense their service give peace health and prosperity to kingdom by their intercession and in the end make they immortal king and everlasting courtier of the kingdom of heaven this life be take chief and almost whole o^t of that which B. allured abbot of rhievall have write John Capgrave have the very same William Malmesburie Roger Hovedon Matthew Westminster Nicholas Harpsfield and almost all writer of saint line make very honourable and worthy mention of he and the roman martirologe on this day the life of s. cedde bishop and confessor of the holy order of s. Benedict jan. 7. out of venerable bede hist. eccl. lib. 3. and 4 saint CEDDE be bear in London and have go so far out of his youth that he be able to make choice of a manner of life he put on a monastical habit among the ancient monk in the monastery of Lindisfarne in which school of piety he profit so well in a short time that he be think worthy to be send as a apostolical man with other devout priest to preach the gospel to the mercian or inhabitant of Middle-England where by his pious labour s. cedde convert the east-angle and exemplar life he great promote the catholic cause but Sigbert then king of the eastsaxons be at that time by the mean of Oswin king of Northumberland from a heathen convert to the christian faith and baptize by bishop of York b. cedde at the earnest entreaty of Sigbert be call back by and send with king Sigbert to convert his country to the faith who labour there take so good effect that in a short time he bring most part of that province from paganism into which since their conversion by s. mellitus the Benedictine monk they have fall to the true knowledge and subjection of Christ church and he himself who by God grace be now make their second apostle return into Northumberland the messenger of his own good success be by the hand of in presence of two other bishop ordain allsoe the second bishop of London the chief city of the eastsaxons succeed s. mellitus both in the apostleship and bishopric he be make bishop of London of that province and now he begin with a more free authority to bring to perfection the work so happy begin by erect of church in diverse place make priest and deacon to aid he in baptise and preach the holy word of God instruct the new-christened to observe as far forth as they be able the strict rule of a religious life great be the joy and comfort which the new convert king Sigbert and his people receive to see the happy success of his endeavour he be to good man meek and courteous to the bad somewhat more stern and severe in punish their vice as appear by the ensue accident 2 there be in the king court a noble man that live in the band of unlawful wedlock against who the holy bishop after many pious admonion give to no effect denounce the sentence of excommunication strict forbid the king and all other person to forbear his company and not to eat nor drink with he but the king be invite by the same nobleman to a excommucation banquet make light of the bishop precept and go to he and in his return chance to meet the holy man he be much affright and leap of his horse fall prostrate at the bishop foot now likewise alight from horse back humble crave pardon of his fault the holy man touch he as he lay along with his rod so s. P^ter ^^eed death to ananias act. 5. with a episcopal authority use these word I tell thou say he that because thou have refuse to refrain from the house of that wicked and damnable person in that very house thou shall breathe thy last all which come afterward to pass as holy cedde have foretell for within a short time by the hand of the same earl and his brother the king be most cruel murder in that house his butcher allege no other cause move they thereunto but his overmuch clemency and mercy in romit offence commit against he so that it be credible think that this untimely death of so good and virtuous a prince do not only wash away his fault but increase his merit 3 this bless bishop be wont sometime to visit his country in Northumberland and to comfort his countryman there with his divine preach and godly exhortation whereby he get so much favour with king Edilwald son to king Oswald that reign over the people of that country call Deiri that move thereunto both by the sanctity and wisdom of this virtuous bishop and allsoe by the mean of his good brother Celin chaplain to the king and court he give to s. cedde a piece of land for the build of a monastery whither he and his people may resort to serve God and receive the sacrament the holy bishop make choice of a place for this purpose in the desert mountain which before that time be rather a covert for thief and wild beast than a fit habitation for christian but he will not permit the foundation to be lay before he have purge and consecrate the place with fast and prayer both which he perform every day until the evening and then he content himself with one and that a small meal consist of a little bread one egg and a little milk mingle with water thus he pass all the lend except sunday until fast in Lent until evening he be call away from this holy exercise upon some special business of the king by which he be force to intermitt his pious seigne when there remain only ten day of the forty to come but because he will not let his holy task be there break off he entreat Cimbell avertuous priest and his natural brother to finish the godly work he have begin according to the foreshowed example which be by Cimbell glad undertake and as pious he builde^h a monastery perform soon after bishop cedde erect the monastery now call lest order it according to the same law and discipline of religion as that of lindisfurne or holy island where he have learn his first lesson and rudiment of virtue 4 but in that great controversy which arise afterward between the old scottish or irish monk and the monk of s benedict order the apostle of England touch the celebration of easter in which it be sharp dispute a each side especial between s. wilfrid the Benedictine monk and bishop Colman a scott holy cedde be a diligent interpreter for both part be so convince by the divine argument of s. wilfrid that he quite give over to follow the footstep of the scot and come to the knowledge of the true and catholic manner of observe the feast of easter and allsoe to wear a round shave crown after the monastical fashion of benedictine bring first into England by s. augustin our apostle and his fellow that be all Benedictine monk and afterward by the persuasion of wilfrid Colman and his adherent be flee into Scotland s. cedde himself receive the rule of our most holy father s. Benedict and induce all the monk of his new monastery of lest of which he be head to do the like and under the same holy rule he govern they in all manner of virtue until his death thus after some year well spend both in government of his bishopric and this monastery at the length as he visit the same in time of plague he fall into a sickness which set free his soul from the tediousness of this worldly life to taste the desire joy prepare for the reward of his merit and good work in heaven he be first bury abroad but afterward a church of stone be build there in honour of s. cedde die our bless lady he be take up and lay at the right side of the altar at his departure he resign the government of the monastery to his brother s. Chad who life you may read the second of March v. when the monk of the monastery he have erect among the eastsaxons understand of his death thirty of they go into Northumberland desire either to live by the body of their holy father or if God so please to die and be bury there such be the great love they bear unto this bless saiuct but in that time of mortality they all walk the path of death except one little boy who as it be pious think be preserve from death by the special prayer and intercession of this holy bishop for live many year after and study holy scripture he come at length to knowledge that he have never receive the sacrament see the peculiar providence of almighty God of baptism whereupon he be forthwith christen and afterward be promote to priesthood he become a very profitable member of God church have be by the prayer and merit of s. cedde miraculous preserve from the danger of a temporal and eternal death s. cedde die about the year of our lord 664. of he do make mention s. bede who we have follow JOHN CAPGRAVE WILLIAM MELMESBURY Pontific lond. Benedict jan. 8. saint WULSINE bear in London of worthy parent be careful bring up in the service and fear of God until he be grow out of his childhood and then they offer he unto God and s. Benedict in the monastery of the Benedictine monk at the virtue of his youth Westminster to be train up in that divine school of virtue wherein he become so good a proficient that in a short time his grave carriage and religious behaviour give a great testimony ^f future sainctetie by watch fast and prayer he overcome the two swear enemy of goodness the flesh and the devil so high he contemn the pleasure and vanity of the world that nothing seem to he more irksome and tedious than the very thought thereof in respect of the great comfort he receive out of the divine contemplation of heaven and heavenly thing whereunto he addict all the power both of his body and soul in humility he be most lowly in obedience most ready and full of charitable affection towards all man have pass over his youth in the continual exercise of these and other monastical virtue he receive the dignity of priesthood and then he do not only shine unto his he be make priest brethren and draw they to virtue by his good example but allsoe by read and expound the holy scripture by pious exhortation and preach he will win they to the love of true religion and devotion at length by the mean of that great pillar of the Benedictine family s Dunstan he be choose abbot of the same monastery in the performance of which holy charge it be beyond the force of weak word to express how much he labour and abbot of westminster for the salvation of fowl and what excellent example of virtue and godly life he show unto his brethren but such be his rare virtue that long they can not be contain within the bound of a weak cloister for king ethelred call he thence as it be from under the obscure bushel of his monastery to be place in the view and admiration of the world in the bishopric of sherburne and by the free election of the clergy and great applause of the people he be exalt to the government of that Sea then it be rare to behold how worthy he begin to rule his people thunder at first a dutiful respect into their the true virtue of a good bishop heart he afterward shine all love among they his first and principal care be to appear unto his subjectss such as he will have they be and to be such as he appear make his godly life the example of his own doctrine and his doctrine to arise as it be out of his deed so that in a small time he win singular love in his people and engraft singular confidence his daily exercise be to exhort his subject to comfort the afflict to feed the hungry to clothe the naked to redeem captive to entertain poor pilgrim to teach the ignorant to withould the desperate from the shipwreck of their soul to inflame the tepid and animate the servant to provide careful for those under his charge and punctual to perform the duty of his profession and calling he be wont to spend the time of Lent within the monk cloister be free from the tumultuous affair of the world he lead a rigid monastical life exercise himself in fast and prayer and heavenly contemplation on maundy Thursday he come abroad and have consecrate holy chrism according to the custom of consecration of chrism the catholic church he will preach unto the people and give they his benediction after the celebration of the feast of easter he be wont to visit his whole diocese as well to teach instruct and direct his under-pastour and clergieman worthy to perform their duty as allsoe to amend correct and punish whatsoever be do amiss contrary to the rule of good order discipline and justice 2 he be wonderful careful both to augment and exalt that ancient sea of sherburne and to establish it in a continual peace in good order and discipline and to that end he cast out from thence nichol. Harp saec. 10. c. 9 and William Malm. monk ought nor to be subject to bishop the secular clergiman for their bad life and in their steed bring in the Benedictine monk over who he will have place a abbot but they desire rather to live under his government whereunto though unwilling he consent foretell they that it will be a beginning of great calamity unto their successor to be subject to the bishop but in all that he do for the monk he never detract any part of the mean belong to the bishopric to set they up withal but provide elsewhere sufficient revenue for they always preserve the episcopal sea in her own ancient and splendour in all thing 3 thus have for the space of five year worthy govern his flock and do the office of a good pastor he fall into a vehement sickness together with a virtuous knight and his dear s. Wulsine fall sick friend name Egeline who hear of his lord infirmity seem to suffer more therein then in his own and therefore not able to go himself he send to know in what danger he be the languish holy man by the messenger will his sickly friend sudden to dispose of himself and his estate and to prepare for his last journey for to morrow next say he we shall go both together to the court of our eternal king where he shall receive the reward of his faithful service the messenger be depart he use these word to his monk by the filial love you have ever show unto i I do conjure you my dear child that before you commit my bone to the earth you cause the body of this our faithful friend to be bring hither and to be bury with i in this church of sherburne that in death our body be not separate who soul during life be tie faithful together in the band of true love and friendship to these word the monk that be present can give no other answer but tear the woeful witness of the sorrow they conceive to depart from so dear a father but he exhort they all to be rather joyful then grieve at his near approach happiness and always to live in the fear and love of God till he feel the pang of death begin to cut of his discourse when lift up his hand and eye towards heaven he cry out with the first martyr s. STEPHEN behold I see the heaven open and jesus stand on the right hand of God and with the breath of these word he breathe forth his pure soul to receive her reward in the pure he die place the eight day of january about the year of our lord 985. of this b. saint do make mention Arnold WION in the appendix of his martirologe WILLIAM malmesbury JOHN CAPGRAVE NICHOLAS HARPSFIELD and other who we have follow the life of s. adrian confessor and abbot of the holy order of s. Benedict jan. 9 saint adrian bear in Africa for his great virtue out of venerable bede and learning be choose abbot of the benedictin monastery of Niridan in Campania not far from Naples he be a great divine and very skilful both in the greek and latin tongue and to these science be add as a ornament of all a true zeal of the service of almighty God and monastical discipline with a perfect knowledge of ecclesiastical government all which shine so clear in he as they give sufficient testimony with how sincere a desire of virtue he have first forsake the world and put on the habit of religion 2 it happen during the time of this holy abbot that the metropolitan sea of Canturbury by the death of deusdedit or gods-guist six bishop thereof be vacant and destitute of a pilot when the people and clergy of benedictin monk move egbert then king of Kent and Oswin king of the Northumber to send one Wighart a^vertuous and holy priest to Rome to be consecrate king of engl. send to Rome for a archbishop of canturb bishop of Canturbury but Wighart come to Rome in the hot time of plague die before he have receive his intend dignity whereupon vitalianus than pope send for s. adrian out of his monastery of Niridan and desire he to accept the charge and dignity of the archiepiscopal sea of Canturbury but he refuse this offer humble answer that unworthy hy be to undertake and more unable to perform any such weighty office in God church and therefore desire some day of deliberation to search s. Adrian refuse the Archbishoprik out a other who worth do more worthy correspond with so hight a degree and calling in this while he find out a holy benedictin monk of his acquaintance call Theodore that live in Rome and he he present unto the pope as one fit for that dignity he be a man excellent in the two chief ornament of the mind learning and virtue this man the pope accept and consecrate archbishop of Canturbury on condition that adrian who have refuse the chief dignity shall at least accompany he into England as his coadiutour in that apostolical mission hereunto the bless saint willing consent and undertake the voyage make himself a subject where he may have be a commander his great humility and choose rather to profit the nation with his preach and learn then govern it by a episcopal authoritle such be his wonderful humility and burn zeal to gain soul to God 3 now therefore this holy couple take their journey towards England and come into France s. adrian who be famous in that country for have be send on diverse embassage between christian prince be for his great merit suspect to go to the king of England on some business of from the emperor plot against the french and therefore be stay by the king of the gaul until he have clear himself of that suspicion which do he go after Theodore into England where within a year or two he be by the same Theodore make abbot of the benedictin monk in the monastery of s. PETER in Canturbury now call s. Augustine from the benedictin monk s Austin our apostle he be make abbot of s. Peter in canturb who lie bury there in this place s. adrian gather together a great number of disciple who he teach and instruct out of the holy scripture to find the ready way to everlasting life and beside this he teach they music astronomy and arithmetic as allsoe the greek and latin tongue which his pious labour take so good effect that many of his scholar speak greek and latin as perfect as their own mother tongue and especial two far exceed their other fellow in all manner of learning one be call albin who succeed s. adrian in the regency of the abbey and the other Tobias who be afterward bishop of Rochester 4 moreover this bless saint be of so great merit and so high esteem before almighty God that he be report to have be the worker of many miracle and that by his intercession a de^d man be raise to life at length have labour in the vineyard of our lord a long time both in Jtalie and England leave his death behind he many learned disciple the fruit of his labour the thirty nine year after he come to Canturbury he leave this world to receive his reward in heaven the nine day of January the year of our lord 708. he be bury in the church or chapel of the b. virgin Marie which king Edbald have build in the foresay monastery of s. augustin and this church happen afterward to be burn s. adrian appear to one of the monk and command he appear in glory he to go to s. Dunstan who then be archbishop of Canturbury with these word in his name thou live in house well cover and fence against the weather but the church of the mother of God wherein I and other domestic of heaven do inhabit lie open expose to the injurious storm of the wind whereupon s. Dunstan careful cause that church to be repair which himself afterward frequent every night such divine sweetness he receive by his prayer offer to God in that place but one night enter into it he behold s. adrian seat among a glorious quire of angel and saint praise and glorifie almighty God his body be always hold in great veneration but especial from hence forth and many miracle be report by the author of his life to have be wrought at his tomb which for brevity sake we omit desire of almighty God grace rather to virtue then to admire his wonder of s adrian make mention s. bede as before Baronius tom. 8. ann. 668. Benedict jan. 9 out of venerable bede hist. gest saint BRITHWALD a monk of s. benedict order in the famous abbey of glassenbury be make abbot of the monastery call reacule in Kent where at that time the king of Kent sometime keep their court albeit now say Camden it be but a poor village not far distant from tanet be a man of very great learning and knowledge in divine scripture and wonderful well practise in ecclesiastical and monastical discipline he be choose by the benedictin of Canturbury to succeed s. THEODORE in that sea which have be vacant the space of two year in the year 692 and consecrate archbishop thereof the year follow he be the eight archbishop of Canturbury and govern his chutch with all true virtue belong to a good bishop the space of thirty seven year six month and fourteen day in his time a council be hold at London wherein the point of worship holy image be handle and confirm at length this holy man load with many year of venerable old age and full of virtue and holiness yield up his bless soul to the begin of that life which never end the nine day of January in the year 731. BRITHWALD s. biscop ABBAS 12 the life of s. BENNET surname biscop abbot and confessor of the holy order of s. Benedict jan. 12. write by venerable bede his disciple the glorious servant of God s. BENNET by birth descend from the ancient race of the nobility of England but the nobility of his mind be such as far more deserve the fellowship and company of the noble and worthy sort of the english nation he be bear in Yorkshire and in his youth follow the discipline of war in the royal service of Oswy king of the Northumber from who princely liberality he receive as the reward of his faithful service no small possession of land and his life during his youth mean suitable to his degree and calling these for a time he enjoy till he attain to the flourish age of twenty five year and then a divine inspiration move he thereunto he forsake and leave the world and fade worldly good for love of the eternal he despise the war fare of these low region and the vain reward thereof that serve under the ensign of our true king CHRIST JESUS he may receive a everlasting kingdom above he leave his country house and kindred for the love of CHRIST and his gospel that he may gain the hundredfould reward he promise and possess life everlasting he refuse to enter into worldly marriage that in the court of heaven he may be worthy to follow the holy lamb so candid with the glory of virginity he loathe to be a carnal father of child be ordain by CHRIST to his first journey to Rome train up his child in the spiritual doctrine of heaven have leave therefore his country because the christian faith and ecclesiastical discipline be yet but raw establish in England he go to Rome there as in the source and fountain of all true religion to learn a perfect form oflife where Christ chief apostle have plant the first and principal foundation and head of the whole catholic church he visit the sacred tomb of the apostle with great devotion unto who his love be always such as the tear now shed over their shrine be sufficient witness to prove it excellent but he make no long stay at Rome but return back into England where he be very diligent and careful to honour and as far as he be able to practice himself and teach other those rule of ecclesiastical discipline at home which he have learn and see abroad 2 about that time Alchifridus son to Oswy have a great his second journey to Rome desire to go to Rome to visit the holy shrine of the apostle will needs take that journey with s. BENNET notwithstanding the earnest persuasion and entreaty of his father to stay at home their journey succeed well and short after they return in safety again during the time of pope Vitalian when s. BENNET come not empty but load with the sweetness of good and wholesome doctrine as before which the better to digest after some he take the habit of s. Benedict month he depart out of England and go to the benedictin monastery of Lirin in France where he take leave of the world and put on the monastical habit of the great patriarch of monk s. Benedict and receive the ecclesiastical tonsure in this pious school of regular discipline he live for the space of two year very careful learning and observe the rule of a true monastical and religious life but no soon be he a little harden in the surnace of religion and make perfect strong and able to resist the temptation and adversity of the world but his love to the prince of the apostle which it seem lay bury at Rome serve as a loadstone to draw he thither again and find a fit opportunity of ship he commit himself to that much desire journey which most prosperous he perform it be at the time when egbert king of Kent as we have say in the life of s. adrian have send Wighart to Rome to be consecrate archbishop of Canturbury but Wighart die and Theodore be make archbishop in his steed s. BENNET find to be a man very wise religious and industrious although at that time otherwise determine be by command of the pope compel to cease from the devotion of his pilgrimage to attend unto employment of a high call which be to return into England with Theodore now elect of Canturbury and s. adrian abbot to serve they both for a guide and a interpreter by the way and in England BENNET who chief lesson be obedience most willing yield to the pope desire and bring the archbishop into Kent where they be both grateful welcome Theodore a scend the seat of the archbishopric and s. BENNET undertake the government of the monastery of s. PETER and Paul in Canturbury of which afterward s. adrian be make abbot for s. BENNET have rule there two his three journey to Rome year enter into his three journey towards Rome which he perform with his wont prosperity and at his return he bring with he not a few book fraught with divine learning all which he have either buy at a easy rate or receive gratis from his friend come thus load into England he betake himself to have some conference with the king of the westsaxons call kenewalk who courteous friendship he have make use of before and be much assist by his benefit to himward but this good king be about the same time take away by a immature death the holy man be frustrate of his desire and therefore he turn his journey direct into his own country where he be bear and go to Egfrid then king of the Northumber to who he make relation of all whatsoever he have do since he depart a young man out of his country neither do he keep secret from he how he be inflame with a fervent desire of religion then he tell he whatsoever he have learned both in Rome and other place touch ecclesiastical and monastical order and discipline and what store of divine book he have purchase and with what great relic of the apostle and martyr he have enrich his country at length the king like he so well and prevail so far with he and get so great love and familiarity that he give he out of his revenue the land of three score and ten family to build a monastery in honour of the prince of the apostle s PETER which s. BENNET with great joy and speed perform in the year of our lord 674. the four year of king Egfrid 3 in the mean time before the foundation of the church be lay s. BENNET go over into France and bring thence mason and other skilful workman to build it of stone according to the roman fashion which he ever love and the great love he the first use of glaze in England bear to the apostle s PETER in who honour he labour make he use such diligence that within the compass of a year after the foundation be lay the solemnity of mass be honourable celebrate therein but when the work draw near unto perfection he likewise send messenger into France to fetch over glasier to adorn the window with glass a work never before use in England they come and do not only perfect this work but allsoe teach their trade unto many of our englishman allsoe such sacred vessel vestment and other necessary for the service of church and altar as can not be find in England like a religious merchant he provide and buy from beyond the sea but find the poverty and want of France not to be able to furnish he with such ornament as he desire and especial to obtain from the pope new privilege for his new-built monastery he make a four journey to Rome and this as soon as he have assemble a convent of monk into it and his four journey to Rome order they according to the rule and institution of great s. Benedict short after he return make a more happy return of spiritual god then ever he have do before for beside almost a innumerable multitude of book and great store of relic of the apostle and martyr of Christ church he have obtain of pope Agatho to have John chief cantor of s. Peter and abbot of s. Martin in Rome along with he into England to instruct and teach as well his monastery as other church allsoe in the form and manner of sing and do all other ecclesiastical rite and ceremony according to the institution of the roman church all which John at his come he perform not only by word of mouth but allsoe by publish many rule and precept to that purpose in writing which for memory sake be afterward careful lay up and reserve in the library of the say monastery allsoe by the licence of king Egfrid and at his earnest entreaty he obtain of the same pope letter of privilege grant unto the say monastery to warrant defend and free it from all extern jurisdiction or forcible invasion for ever likewise he bring from Rome many picture of holy image to beautify and adorn his church and namely a picture of the b. virgin Marie and the picture use in Catholic church twelve apostle which he place in the middle arch or vault of the church from wall to wall and with picture contain all Benedict he make one Eosterwin a priest and monk abbot of the monastery of s PETER to Eosterwin Abbot the end that by the sociable assistance of so virtuous a colleague he may with more ease undergo the labour of government which he be scarce able to perform alone by reason of his much travel up and down for the good of his monastery and his frequent journey beyond sea uncertain when to return Eosterwin therefore undertake the care of the monastery the nine year after the foundation and remain in the same while he live and he live but four year after he be a man by birth noble but he do not make use of the worth of his nobility as many do to breed matter of outward glory and contempt of other but make it the first step to ennoble and enrich his mind with virtue for be cozen german unto s. BENNET they be both so true ally in a virtuous nobility mind both alike such sincere contemner of all worldly respect and honour that neither the one come into the monastery do expect to be prefer either by reason of his honourable nobility or kindred or the other judge it a thing fit to be offer he upon those respect but be a manful of good and holy intention only rejoice that he do observe regular discipline in all thing in a equal measure with the rest of his brethren but s. BENNET soon after he have ordain Eosterwin abbot of s. Peter and Ceolfrid of s. Peter monastery and not a few of his monastical flock to have change this world for a better be take away by the pestilent fury of a sickness which rage all over the country yet to this there be comfort at hand that by the election of the brethren and his fellow-abbot Ceolfrid he find one Sigfrid a deacon of the same monastery a very reverend and meek man substitute in eosterwins place this Sigfrid be a man very sufficient instruct in the knowledge of holy scripture adorn with most godly manner endow with a wonderful virtue of abstinence and for the better conserve of the virtue of his mind he be keep under with no small infirmity of body and to maintain the innocence of his heart he always labour with a hurtfulland disease of the lung 5 and not long after s. BENNET allsoe begin to be weary s. Bennet fall sick with a sickness come forcible upon he for the divine goodness that the virtue of patience may allsoe give testimony of the great sincerity of these holy abbot in religion lay they both prostrate for a time on the hard bed of a temporal sickness that have triumph over the same by death he may afterward refresh they with the perpetual rest of a gladsome peace and ever-during life for Sigfrid as we have say have be long torment with the tedious grief of the inward part of his body evident perceive that now he be come to his last and s. BENNET who disease still increase by degree for the space of three year be now weaken with such a extreme palsy that death seize on the low part of his body take from thence all sense of feeling so that life withdraw itself only into the high lodging of that weak building remain there only the better to exercise the office of a religious and virtuous patience his whole study during the time of his sickness be always to spend the little allowance of breath he enjoy in render hearty thanks and praise unto the author of all goodness for his benefit and to exhort his brethren with the fraternal word of piety to remain constant in the service of God and in the observance of the rule and institution which he have plant among they 7 for you ought not to imagine say he that the law his speech to his brethren on his death bed and constitution which I have give you have proceed out of my owneignorant and unlearned understanding for out of diverse monastery which among all the wearisome labour of my often travel I find to be best have I learn and gather all these precept deliver they to your piety to be observe but chief this precept he do often time reiterate unto they that in the election of their abbot they shall have no regard to the nobility of birth without the worthiness of virtue nor respect the greatness of dignity in the world but the abundance of charity and humility in religion for in very deed I tell you say he that in comparison of two evil I have rather see the place in which with so great labour I have build this monastery reduce into a perpetual desert if so it please God then that my own brother who be know not to follow the step of virtue shall succeed i in title of abbot to rule and govern the same therefore dear brethren be always very careful never to choose your abbot a abbot to be choose not for nobility but virtue according to birth nor out of any other body than your own but follow that which our great abbot s. Benedict have prescribe in his rule and the decree contain in our privilege you ought in the convent of your congregation with common counsel of the brethren to search out one who according to the desert of life and doctrine of wisdom shall be find and approve to be most worthy and fit to perform so great a office and such a one be find you shall present he to the bishop who with his wont benediction ought to confirm he in the abbatiall dignity in these and such like speech do he spend a great part of his weak sickly day whilst to mitigate the wearisome tediousness of the long night which the heavy burden of his disease do render restless from sleep he will some time call one of his brethren to read unto he either the example of holy job unmatcheable patience or some other part of the scripture whereby he may receive some comfort in his grief and be able more lively to lift up himself from the low degree of worldly torment to the consideration of the high reward of his suffering and because he can not by any mean rise to pray nor easy make use either of tongue or voice to recite his accustom task of psalm he learn by his own prudence and the he true religious spirit of a true religious spirit and affection to call certain of the brethren unto he at all the hour either of day or night office with who be divide into two quire he will sing and say as well as he be able all the accustom psalm of the office and what his weakness will not let he perform be by their assistance supply 8 but when this worthy pair of abbot BENNET and Sigfrid have be long weary with BENNET enter into consultation with Sigfrid^ and the rest of her brethren send for Ceolfrid that be abbot of s. Paul monastery a man not only near unto he in the band of kindred but allsoe which be the chiefall in the sweet society of virtue and he by the common consent and favour of all he place at the helm to be the only pilot and governor of both his monastery judge it the only best course the better to conserve the peace unity and concord of both place to beepe they perpetual under the regiment of one only superior and for this purpose he wish they to call to mind that evangelicall sentence every kingdom divide within itself shall become desolate but two month after this the venerable and belove man of God Sigfrid luc. 11. v. 17. have pass through the fire and water of temporal tribulation be by a welcome death bring into the sweet refresh of a everlasting rest and at length after four month more the excellent worker of virtue and great conqueror of vice s. BENNET conquer with the weakness of his earthly body come to his last it be when the freeze night come on with his winter blast to beget a sacred day of eternal and clear light of felicity his watchful brethren meet together in the church with prayer and psalm to drive away night horrid shadow and to comfort the grief of their dear father departure with the continual sing of the divine praise some will not budge out of the chamber and from the bed side in which the strong sick-man lay expect by the passage of death to take the sweet entrance of life with desire they expect that as his example teach they how to live well by the same they may likewise learn how to die for the further mitigate of his grief the gospel be read all night as it be wont by a priest that attend on he the hour of his departure draw near the sacrament of Christ facae body be give he for his and so that bless soul have be a long time parch and examine in the flame of a happy tribulation forsake the earthly furnace of the flesh and be at liberty take a long desire flight to the never-dieing glory of his death celestial happiness this glorious confessor die in the year of our lord 690. the twelve day of january when he have govern his monastery sixteen year eight by himself and other eight with the assistance of his holy colleague Eosterwin Sigfrid and Colfrid he be bury in the church of s. PETER which he build that so he may not be separate from he in death who he ever love in his life and by who aid the gate of heaven be open unto he his life be write by s. bede who we have follow VSVARD malmesbury WIGORNIENSIS JOHN CAPGRAVE Baronius and other grave author make honourable mention of his virtue this saint BENNET be the first that reduce the benedictin order in s. Benedict jan. 12. write by John capgrave alured bear in England of noble parent be bring up from his tender age in the fear of God and good learning he learn even in his youth to undegoe the sweet yoke of our lord remain always in the innocence of his life pure from all spot of sin his piety and learning increase daily with his age he gain so great favour and love with David king of the scot that he esteem he before most of his court and have exalt he to a bishopric have not his entrance into a he refuse a Bishoprik religious order hinder it in all occasion this holy youth carry himself with so great piety and meekness as no injury can move he to anger no opprobrious speech can provoke he to revenge he always endeavour to repay hatred with love to render good for evil and to overcome envy with duty and service a certain knight perceave he to be belove and honour of the king more than any other raise a hateful and malignant persecution against he and grow so fierce in his malice that he be not afray sometime open to vomit part of his venom against he with injurious word before the king himself to who the holy man with a mild and unmoved countenance you speak very well say he and honest I know your tongue be never acquaint with untruth and therefore I take you to be his rare humility and patience my very good friend the knight find he to be a firm rock who all the outrageous storm of his malice and hatred can not move nor stir from the ground of virtue suffer a willing overthrow in his wicked endeavour and show the effect of a repentant mind demand pardon for his great temereity promise from thence forth ever to oblige himself unto he in a unfeigned league of friendship to who alured I confess say he I rejoice hearty at thy repentance and therefore I shall love thou better far than ever for thy hatred to i have increase my a good lesson love to my dear redeemer and my patience be exercise and try hereby have perhaps mean to make i profit a little in my duty to almighty God thus this b. man from the brier of other man malice reap the sweetrose of virtue unto himself 2 after this mean to bid adieu to the world and all he take the habit of a monk the vanity thereof he go unto the abbey of rhievall or Ridall in Yorkshire and put on the habit of a bernardin monk under the holy rule of s. Benedict in which solitary kind of life give himself whole to contemplation of heavenly thing and the continual exercise of true religious and monastical virtue he attain to such perfection that like the moon among the lesser star he shine among the rest of his brethren in all manner of virtuous life and behaviour and short aster he be so he be make master of the novice good a proficient he feel that he be think able to read a lesson of virtue unto other and therefore the education of the novice or probationer be commit to this charge but while he execute that office there be a unconstant clerk that enter into the order who vocation after a small trial begin to waver like a reed in the wind his unsteadfast mind be perceive his good master earnest request almighty God to give he the grace of perseverance soon after the same brother desire to return into the world open the thought of his heart unto his master say that his weakness be not able to endure the hardness of the order that all thing therein be contrary to his nature that he can not undegoe their daily pain and exercise that he be grievous vex and torture with their long watch that he often faint under his manual and daily labour that the roughness and rudeness of his clothes do pierce his tender skin and that indeed his will be rather incline to follow secular delight and worldly lust and pleasure then to break his back with such austerity and I reply his master will prepare thou dainty meat and gentle clothing and in all thing else belong to thy profession I will be more indulgent unto thou I will not stay say he although it be to be master of all the wealth in the house neither will I taste any food reply alured until God all mighty bring thou back again either willing or nil the one run to the gate to be go the other enter into his chamber to pray that he shall not go the holy man lament the loss of his son and with the deep sigh of a sorrowful heart bewail his great temereity refuse to he for have often time strive with all his force to go ^orth he fail of his purpose and be not able to pass over that place where the gate be wont to stand be shut be strike with admiration hereat he shadow or figure of true religion he begin as it be to reform and wind himself up into a far high degree of austerity and devotion and when as now he may assume more liberty he contrary to custom do quite abridge himself of all such thing as may give his body content in his diet so spare that his extreme abstinence make he seem to bear the shape rather of a spirit then of a man he increase the life to whatsoever proceed either from his pen or tongue in his writing saying do and all his manner of life he be a most diligent imitator of the great father of his order s. BERNARD always meek humble patient and one that both in himself and with other and among all man be so peaceable that it far exceed the force of this pen to express or any heart to think how entire and sincere he do embrace purchase and nourish true peace and concord 4 as once he sit before the fire be so cruel torment with the colic that through the sharp convulsion of his grief he be force to sit double with his head bend down between his knee there come into the room one of the brethren that long before hate he for his goodness and now spie this opportunity to be advantageous for his revenge steal behind he sit in that manner and with all his force thrust he violent into the fire cry out aloud now thou be just punished'for thy hypocrisy and falsehood hereupon some of the monk come to the noise get up the holy abbot out of the fire and out of a zealous anger begin to lay violent hand upon the author of this mischief but the bless saint forget his infirmity his wonderful patience and still mindful of charity strict forbadd they from that enterprise cease cease say he my dear child and do not rob your wretched father of his garment of patience alas I be not angry I be not hurt I be not trouble at this my child it be that cast i into the fire and hereby he have not urge i my death but purge my imperfection he be my child albeit weak and imperfect and indeed I be not sound in body myself but his weakness have cure the imperfection of my soul and here withal embrace he about the neck he give he the love salutation of peace and as though he have endure no wrong at all he study with all gentleness to mitigate the fury of his heart which without cause be enrage against he v. four year before his death he have his body perfect exempt and discharge from all pleasure of enjoy this life for he bring it so lean and bare with continual fast watch sickness and other voluntary austerity that nothing but the skin be leave to cover the naked bone and in all his infirmity he will not hear of a physician but contemn for the love of God all remedy of the body he only busy himself about that one thing which be necessary to provide for the health of his soul he read such book as will move his heart to melt into tear of sorrow and compunction and instruct he in the way of good life and manner and among many other he use very much to read s. augustins confession he be often wont to sit in a hollow place make in the floor of his oratory pious ruminate with himself that from earth he come and into earth she shall return in a word live on earth his conver sation be in KENTIGERNE bishop and confessor jan. 13. write by Joscelinus LOTHUS the heathen king of the pict have a fair daughter call Thamet who by the often hear and attend to the preach of god servant the power of the divine grace concur thereunto be convert to the christian faith this Thamet have be ravish by the lascivious violence of a noble man of the court be in punishment of that faultless fault by his parent the law of the country and her own father decree adjudge to be cast down headlong from the top of a steep hill so to perish in the execution of which cruelty recommend herself to almighty God and lift up her hand and eye towards heaven for aid she be throw down backward but by the hand of he that save those who true call upon he she be deliver from receive any hurt at all which miracle her pagan father ascribe to the power of art magic cause she present to be put into a leather boat and without either sail or oar to be commit to the uncertain conduct of the wind and wave but the almighty protector and ruler of the s^as bring her safe to a other port where she go on land and come at length to the town of el^e or Assaph in Flintshire his birth and there she be deliver of a boy who be baptize by Seruanus a holy man of that country be name KENTIGERNE such be the birth and parentage of this saint who although he may seem to have contract some stain of honour therein yet his worthy manner of life so clear wash away all spot of any such imputation that for true virtue life and learning he become a example to be set in balance with any holy man of those time his youth be first train up in the virtuous school of Seruanus under who he profit in a short time beyond all his other school fellow both in learning and virtue purchase by his own towardness such a singular love with his good master that he be wont to call he Munghu that be most dear friend and by that name he be ever after honour and call upon by the people of that country in their devotion unto he but the malice of envious person who because they can not attain begin to hate so great goodness fore he to depart from his master Sernanus he go into Scotland to a place call Glasghu where he lead a his anstere life and penance very austere and holy life in his poor clothing and diet he bear the true pattern of a other JOHN baptist his clothes be make of goate-skinne he will fast oft time without taste any meat the space of three day neither will he then seek after dainty but be content to eat such thing as first come to hand he abstain from flesh and wine perpetual his sleep be very little which when nature compel he unto he take lie along in a hollow stone with a great stone under his head in steed of a pillow to this austerie he add the rudeness of a shirt of hayre-cloathe which he always wear next his skin and in this poverty do he travel over that country preach teach and convert great multitude of people of the faith till at length by he be make bishop the common consent of the king and clergy but much against his own will he be exalt to the sacred dignity of bishop in the sea of Glasghu which honour nothing alter he in his rigid and strict kind of life but rather serve as a spur to increase his wont austerity 2 he will walk abroad always in his albeit and steal with his crosier-staff in his hand which although it be but of plain wood yet he be if I may so call he a golden bishop shine his manner of prayer and mortification to the world with great example of charity and good work every night after a short refresh of sleep he will go naked into the cold water and in that manner recite over the whole psalter and this custom he always observe in despite of winter frost and snow unless his sickness or some other necessary journey do hinder he and then he will make amends with some other spiritual exercise so entire have he mortify and deaden in himself all the lafcivious instigation and motion of the flesh that as he will often tell his disciple he be no more provoke to lust at the sight or touch of the fair woman in the world then in the cold embrace of a hard stone often time while he preach there appear a white dove over his head with a beak as it be of gold every lend he will segregate his observance of Lent himself from all company and live in some desert place eat no other food but herb and root on Maundie Thursday he be wont for the exercise of his humility have gather a company of poor people and leper together to wash their foot with water his own tear in the mean time concur thereunto and have wipe and dry they first with a towel and then with his own kiss he will attend on they at table with all submission and diligence on good Friday in memory of our lord passion he spend almost the whole day and some part of the night in scourge and chastise his body with sharp whip and stripe until his own nakedness do blush at this his pious cruel piety on holy Saturday or easter Eve except the time of the divine office he always lay hide in a certain grave or sepulchre within the ground in contemplation of our lord passion and punish himself with stripe till the hour of our saviour resurrection the next morning by his preach he reduce the infidel o^ his diocese unto the Catholic faith and with the force of his sacred doctrine he reduce all apostate and heretic to the safe bosom of our holy mother the church he demolish all diabolical idol build some church allot certain limit and bound unto parish and where soever he travel in this spiritual traffic to gain soul he will not make his journey on horse back but always on foot as do the apostle and lest he may seem to eat his bread in idleness he labour many time with his own hand in the tillage of his land 3 after the death of king Morken during who reign he be make bishop the kinsman of the same king like the son of Beliall plot and conspire his death whereof the holy man be admonish by revelation from God he take his journey into southwall which country be at that time rich beautify with the flourish virtue of s. DAVID with who have spend some time he receive of the king of that country call Cathwalla a piece of land to build a monastery and have erect a he build a monastery monastery at ell in Flintshire he there constitute his episcopal sea he gather together in that monastery the number of nine hundred threescore and odd monk which all serve God under regular discipline in a very strict and rigid manner of life three hundred of the most unlearned of they be depute to the labour of husbandry to toil and ^ill the field and keep sheep and other cattle other three hundred be employ in work within the the manner of life of the ancient monk monastery to provide victual and other necessary and the rest which be sufficient learn be allot to the quire night and day to celebrate the divine office and none of these be easy permit to wander abroad but be bind to the limit of their monastery as to the sanctuary of our Lord the holy bishop divide they into diverse company or convent and as one company end the divine office in the church a other present enter to begin the same again and that have do come a three company in like manner so that by the continual succession of the diverse company the divine service be maintain in that church night and day without any intermission among these monk there be one call asaph a man of very great virtue and a worker of many miracle he s KENTIGERNE love above all the rest and for his virtuous life he deliver unto his hand the care of the monastery and appoint he for his successor in the bishopric 4 the holy man remain on a time long at his devotion then his ordinary custom be his face appear fiery and glisten to the great admiration of the beholder and after his prayer be end he fall into most grievous lamentation which he have a revelation of s. David death move some of his disciple humble to request he to declare the cause of his so great sadness to who after a silent pause you must know say he my dear child that the crown and glory of Brittany and worthy father of his country s. DAVID be now depart out of the prison of his body to receive his reward in heaven believe i I behold not only a great multitude of angel but the lord of angel CHRIST JESUS himself come to meet he and lead he into the glory of his heavenly paradise know likewise that our Brittany be deprive of this her great light will groan for the loss of so great a patron who praise of s. David whilst he live be the only buckler of our defence against the revengeful sword of God just anger half draw out to punish the malice of our country and long since have not his virtue withhold it have make a general slaughter among we now therefore our lord will deliver this country into the hand of strange nation which neither acknowledge he for God nor his religion for the truth and this our wretched isle shall be inhabit he prophesy the misery of briny by pagan and all christian religion therein shall for a time be utter destroy but afterward by the wonderful mercy of almighty God all shall be repair again and the country reduce notone into her ancient but into a far better and more flourish state of religion v. this bless saint have be seven time at Rome where unto s. Gregory the great afterward apostle of the english bishop confirm by the pope he relate the whole course of his life the manner of his election and consecration and all other chance which have befall he the holy pope understand he to be a man of God and full of the grace of the holy ghost confirm his consecration which he know to have proceed from God and supplie according to his earnest desire such ceremony as have be omit therein he dismiss he unto his pious charge by the holy ghost enjoin 5 in the mean time death have exercise his revenge on all the holy man enemy in Albany or Scotland the inhabitant thereof forsake the way of truth and return like dog to feed upon their own vomit fall again into the rite^ of flat idolatry and therewithal the heaven and element with draw their usual influence cause a general famine and dearth in their country till at length almighty God raise a king name reder who have be baptize in Ireland by the disciple of s. KENTIGERNE come from his monastery in the island with a great company of his monk he make great league with s. columb to visit he and enter into a league of friendship and familiarity with he and come near unto the place where the holy bishop be he divide his whole company into three troop the bishop likewise that come to meet he do in the same manner divide his follower into three squadron in the first he place the junior or young sort in the second those of a middle age and in the three old age man venerable in their gray hair and as these two sacred army of JESUS CHRIST march towards each other they song spiritual hymn and canticle on both side and s. columb to his follower I see say he over the three quire a fiery light in manner of a golden crown to descend from heaven upon the bishop head but the two holy leader of these troop come near together salute each other with mutual embrace and holy kiss of love and friendship in testimony thereof they change their pastoral staff and the staff which s. columb give the bishop be keep afterward with great reverence in s. the holy man be so far spend with ouldage as his wither sinew do scarce hang his joint together and his last exhortation to his disciple perceave that the hour of his death be at hand he call his ancient holy father and ever to follow the institution of the Catholic Roman church when many of his disciple who most dear love he fall prostrate before he cry out with weep word we know dear father that thou do desire to be dissolve from thy age body to reign with CHRIST but we humble beseech thou to take pity on we who thou have gain to the service of CHRIST confession of sinne^ in whatsoever our humane frailty have offend we have always confess unto thou desire to be correct by the arbitrement of thy discretion obtain therefore of almighty God that together with thou we may depart out of this vale of tear and misery to the everlasting joy of our dear lord for unto we it seem a thing unfitting that either a bishop without his clergy a shepherd without his flock or a father without his child shall enter into the joy of his Lord the holy man be move with pity fetch his breath as well as he be able the sacred will of God say he be fulfil in we all and according as he know best and as he please let his divine providence dispose of we all hereupon be admonish by a angel that his prayer be hear he be likewise will to enter into a warm bath in which lift up his hand and eye towards heaven he resolve as it be into a sweet sleep and yield up the manner of his death his blessed soul into the hand of his redeemer it please the heavenly wisdom to give his servant this pleasant kind of death who life be a continual martyrdom his disciple have take his body out of the bath many of they enter therein have the favour to follow their holy leader into the heavenly dwelling he die the PETER Abbot of the holy order of saint Benedict jan. 13. out of venerable bede peter be a roman monk of s. benedict order and one of those which be send by s. Gregory the great with our first apostle s. augustin to preach the gospel of CHRIST unto the english nation s. augustin be consecrate archbishop of Canturbury send back Laurence and Peter his fellow to bring news unto the holy pope of their good success in the conversion of England and allsoe by his prudence and counsel to be resolve of some difficulty which arise in the plant of Catholic religion in that new church this s. PETER at his return into England be by the same s. augustin ordain the first abbot of the benedictin monastery of Canturburie erect by king ethelbert in honour of the apostle s PETER and s. Paul of the time and manner of his government in this office we have nothing certain but that he lead a very virtuous and holy life it be manifest by that which s. bede write of he at length say he be send ambassador into France he chance to be drown in a gulf of the sea between two c^pes at a place call ampleat and be by the inhabitant commit to a ignoble burial it please almighty God to make know of how great meritt the holy man be by a heavenly light which appear every night over his grave until the neighbour understand thereby that certain it be a holy man that lay bury there and be better inform who it be and whence he come they take away his body and carry it to the city of Bullein where it be bury in a church after such reverend and honourable manner as become so worthy a holy man he die about the year of Christ 607. of he do make mention beside s bede Trithemius in his work of the famous man of s. benedict order MOLANUS in his catalogue of the saint of Belgia and other who we have follow the life of s CEOLULPHE king and confessor monk of the holy order of s. Benedict jan. 15. out of venerable bede gest angl. CEOLULPH after the death of king Osrick be make king of the Northumber but the beginning and progress of his government be encumber with so many difficulty and adversity that after some year trial thereof enter into a serious consideration with himself of the miserable uncertainty and uncertain misery of man life and perceave how dangerous be the tumult and precipice of this world and that the great and most prosperous fortune of prince be most of all subject to decline and change even in a moment and call to mind the strict and rigid account that we must render of all our thought and action at the day of judgement before the dreadful tribunal of the all see judge he begin so far to loathe the care of worldly thing and so to despise those vain honour he resolve to be a benedictin monk that forsake the royal estate and robe of majesty he put on the poor weed of a monastical humility in the benedictin monastery of lindissarne or holy-iland pious follow herein the footstep of six other his predecessor english king now instead of his crown of gold the token of sovereignty he wear his hair shave with a crown make of the same as the badge of a punish humility his royal sceptre by virtue whereof he bear sway and authority in the world be now turn to a breviary whereunto he be wed and he that before rule a kingdom be now under the check and command of a poor monk his superior for his chain of gold which be the ornament of his princely body he be now content to use a poor pair of bead and thereon daily to reckon the number of his almost numberless devotion he be a man in who a great knowledge of thing divine and humane be join with a excellent piety and singular devotion so absolute learn that venerable bede the great scholar his learning and piety and writer of our nation dedicate his history of England unto he with the title of most glorious king to be by his wisdom not only review and read but also approve and if need be correct the often read of these book he be of himself much addict unto the knowledge of antiquity and especial of England be a spur unto he already incline thereunto to undertake this monastical life in which when he have live the space of all most twenty year in the continual exercise of piety and devotion he give up his holy soul to receive for a temporal kingdom a eternal among other bless king who the same pious consideration have cause to leave their sceptre and purple to be range under the humble ensign of s. Benedict the day of his death be unknown but how full of merit and good work he die his burial which be near unto his death the great benedictin monk s Cuthbert and the many miracle which it please God to show at his tomb do give sufficient testimony afterward his body together with s. cuthberts be take up and place in a rich shrine in a more eminent place thus much of he we have gather out of venerable bede WILLIAM malmesbury gest reg. angl. lib. 1. cap. 3.
