Benedict jan. 16. out of venerable bede FURSEUS bear in Ireland of royal parent but more ennoble by his virtue then his birth be famous for dignity among his friend but excel over the world in the special gift of divine grace he be of a beautiful form chaste of body devout in mind affable in discourse of a amiable aspect and replenish with grace and good work bring up from his very infancy in the continual study of holy scripture and monastical his youth and learning discipline and as he grow in year so grow he allsoe in the daily increase of virtue and pious desire for the better accomplishment whereof he forsake his parent friend and native soil and betake himself for the space of some year to the study of holy scripture in which in short time he become sufficient well instruct but that the world may know that he do not only labour for himself but for all those that seek the truth he build a monastery which serve as a free-school of virtue wherein he teach all that come unto he the true way of salvation great be the number of people that flock together unto this holy teacher of virtue by who godly preach and devout exhortation many be not only retire from their bad manner of life and bring into the right way of salvation but allsoe be subject unto the regular observance of a monastical order among these he be desirous to have the company of some of his own kinsinen and for that end he make a journey unto his native country but in the way he happen to fall sick and in this sickness his soul be as it be separate from her earthly lodging enjoy a most delightful vision of angel that seem to lift he up towards heaven be he behold a infinite company of heavenly citizen who with their sweet melody fill his ravish understand with inestimable joy and comfort the ditty of their a vision song be that versicle of the psalm in Zion holy man will proceed from virtue to virtue the god of god shall be see in Zion this song they repeat oftentime with such ravish tune as it be far beyond the force of weak word to express but be restore to his body and himself again about the time that the cock give warning of the day approach he hear in steed of the melodious harmony of the angel the woeful lamentation and cry of his friend and kinsfolly who all this time have watch at his body which they suppose to be dead but now perceave he again to come to himself their lamentation be change into a fearful admiration and their admiration breed joy to see he alive then the holy man look about he and find no man unto who wisdom he can commit the knowledge of the vision he have see be very sorrowful choose for that time rather to bury it within the secret of his own heart then reveal it unto such as know not how to understand it 2 but the three day afterward be again take with the like ravishment he behold nor only great joy of the bless company an other vision most strange of heaven but allsoe the wonderful war which the wicked spirit raise against he strive to hinder his journey towards heaven albeit the protection of the angel frustrate their malicious endeavour many false accusation they bring against he and lay diverse crime to his charge of all which by his guide the angel he be free disengage and as he be lift up by these bless spirit towards heaven they command he to look down into the world which do he see like a dark and indeous the 4. fire of vice that burn the world valley underneath he and in the air he behold four fire not far distant one from the other which they tell he be the fire that shall burn and consume the world the first they say be the fire of liar which those fall into that neglect to fulfil their promise make in baptism in renounce the devil and all his work the second be the fire of covetousness appoint for such as prefer the riches of the world before the love of heaven and heavenly thing the three be the fire of discord provide for those that stick not to offend their neighbour even in trifle and superfluous matter the four be the fire of jmpietie allot for such as care not how they spoil and oppress see the inferior and weak sort of people he behold these fire to increase so by little and little till at length by spread they come together and make one mighty huge and dreadful flame which seem to approach near unto he whereat he cry out to his guide the angel o lord behold it come upon i fear not reply he that which thou have not kindle shall not burn thou for although this seem to be a mighty great and terrible fire yet it only try and examine man according as their work have deserve the worldly desire of man shall burn in these flame for even as one be inflame in body by unlawful lust and pleasure so release from his body he shall suffer his deserve torment in fire then he behold one of the three angel his guide to walk before and divide the flame and the other two conduct he on each side through the fire defend he from the danger thereof he see likewise the devil fly through the flame make fiery war against the just then follow their many accusation against he and the angel defence in his behalf with a vision of a great company of heavenly spirit as allsoe of many man of his country and acquaintance that he have know not unworthy to have behave themselves in the sacred function of priesthood of who he learn many thing very profitable as well for himself as for all such as will hear they when these have end their discourse and return unto heaven with the troop of angel there only remain with b. FURSEUS the three angel his guide with who return again towards the foresay fire the angel divide the flame as before but as the holy man enter into the way lay open for he the wicked spirit catch up one of those wretched soul which they broil in those flame and throw it at he at the very touch whereof he find his shoulder and cheek to be scorch and burn the holy man well know the person and remember that at his death he have give he a garment which he receive but the holy angel take the torment soul cast he again into the fire whereat the wicked spirit cry out why do you cast he of now who you receive before for as you take the good of that sinner so ought you to partake of his torment not out of covetousness reply the angel but to save his soul do he receive it and therewith the fire cease and the angel turn unto the holy man say that which thou do kindle now have burn thou for have not thou take the good of this man die in sin the torment of his fire have not touch thou and speak further he teach he what be to be do for the salvation of those that do repent 3 be restore to himself again he bear all his life time after a visible sign of the burn which he have endure in his soul upon his shoulder and cheek the flesh evident show to the wonder of all beholder what the soul have inward and hidden suffer but he retain always his wont care and diligence of follow virtuous and pious course by word work and example to teach and preach the way of truth and justice unto the world yet he will never manifest the order and manner of his vision but unto such only as out of a desire of repentance or compunction of hearth desire to know they there live yet say proof of the foresay vision venerable bede a ancient monk of our monastery who be wont to relate that a certain religious and trusty man tell he that he have both see s. FURSEUS in the province of the east-angle and hear the manner of these vision out of his own mouth add moreover that in the midst of winter when the frost be most sharp and cold that sit in a light and single garment recount these vision either out of the greatness of the fear he conceive or of the sweetness he receive by the remembrance of they he will sweat as much as if it have be the hot day of summer 4 have therefore a long time preach the word of God in Jreland his own country be not able any long easy to endure the great multitude of people that flock unto he he forsake all that he seem to enjoy and go out of his native country with some few of his brethren in his company he pass the sea and come through Wales into the province of the english where he be honourable receive and worthy entertain by Sigebert then king of the east-angle but he that desire wheresoever he go always to promote the service of almighty God begin present to put in practice his accustom trade of preadhing labour by the example of his virtue or the incite force of his speech either to convert the incredulous to the truth or to strengthn and confirm the faithful and more in the truth and love of JESUS CHRIST such be his daily labour such be the pious employment in which he continual busy all the power of his soul and force of his body v. but while these thing be thus do he fall again into a other sickness during which he enjoy the delightful vision of an other vision angel that admonish he to proceed with courage and diligence in the happy begin work of preach as also with a invincible patience to hold on his accustom exercise of watch fast and prayer because that his death be certain but the hour of his death most uncertain with this vision be much confirm in his pious course he hasten to build a monastery on the land which king Sigebert have give he for that purpose which do he institute it with the regular discipline of a monastical life under the holy rule of of s. Benedict the situation of this monastery by reason of the nearness of the sea and word be very pleasant it be build in a certain old castle call Cnobbersburg that be the town of of cnobber it be afterward by Anna king of that province and many other nobleman very rich adorn with more stately edifice and enrich with diverse gift of great worth 5 and in this very monastery king Sigebert himself be weary Harp saec. 7. cap. 15. king Sigebert become a benedictin monk of the world and worldly care and desire to give his mind only unto God put of his princely robe and leave the government of his king do unto his cousin Edrick betake himself to live under the humble weed of a benedictin monk judge it more honourable in a cloister to conquer himself by obey then in the world to bear sway over other by command but long he have not enjoy this quiet life when wicked Penda king of the mercian make war against his forsake kingdom he be by force take out of the monastery by his own friend and make general of their army which they presuppose will be much hearten and encourage with his presence who to show that his profession be dear to he then his life put on no other armour than a good conscience nor take other weapon than a little rod in the canfidence of a secure conscience his hand go secure though unwilling against the bloud-thirsting army of he and Christ enemy where both he himself and king Egrick unto who he have leave the kingdom happy lose this life to win a better 7 but let we we return unto s. FURSEUS who now have as we have say build a monastery and establish it with the rule and disciple of a monastical order be desirous to free himself not only from all worldly care but allsoe from the government of his monastery give up the whole care thereof unto his brother and be at liberty he so dispose of himself as meaning to spend and end the remainder of his life in a anachoreticall or eremitical life he have a other brother call Vltanus who out of the continual probation of the monastical and cloister manner of live have betake himself to the solitariness of the desert unto he FURSEUS go alone and together with he he live by the labour of his hand for the space of a whole year in continual fast and prayer and do of penance but perceave the country to be much disquiet by the frequent incursion of pagan and foresee the eminent danger of the monastery leave all thing in good order he sail into France where be honourable entertain by the french king Clovis the second and Erconwald then provost of peronne he build a monastery in a place call into which be introduce the monk of s. benedict order for as yet and many year after there be no other rule on foot but he in all the occidental church and not long after s. FURSEUS fall sick he quick feel the vehemency of his disease to grow so strong upon he as he plain perceive his time to draw near therefore recommend himself unto God and lift up his eye towards heaven he yield up his pure soul into the hand of his redeemer the sixteenth day of January Erconwald cause his body to be reserve in the church porch of peronne where it remain for the space of twenty fix day till the consecration of the new-built church in the same town be finish at what time be take up it be find with no more sign of corruption then if he have die but that very hour 8 four year after a little chapel be erect on the east side of the high altar and dedicate to s. FURSEUS his body be take up again by the worthy bishop Eligius and Ausbertus and find to be uncorrupted as before it be translate thither in most honourable manner where it have most manifest appear unto the world that through his merit diverse miracle have be wrought by the almighty worker of miracle who be wonderful in his saint for ever he flourish about the year 636. or as other say 650. HENRY hermite confessor jan. 16. henry be bear of the noble sort of dane and be come to such age as his face betray his sex his parent earnest solicit he to marry whereunto in the beginning he seem not unwilling but the appoint day of his marriage draw nigh it be reveal unto he in a vision that he ought to abstain from all carnal copulation and to keep himself chaste and pure from this world by studie rather how to please God than a wife whereupon sudden leave all his friend and free he refuse to marry himself of the possession of those good he enjoy he take ship at Tinemouth and sail about twenty mile into the sea to a island on the east side of Northumberland name cocket from the river cocket run there by this island be in ancient time very famous for a holy convent of monk that live there s henry be thither arrive with leave of the prior he enter the island and have build himself a little lodge scarce of force to beat of the injury of the weather he begin to serve God in great rigour and austerity of life for the space of some year he fast continual his rigorous fast only with bread and water afterward he eat but thrice a week and three day in the week keep silence in four year before he die he satisfy his hunger only with little cake dry in the sun make of barley meal mix with pure water 2 go upon a time in pilgrimage to Durham he come to the bank of the river wyre and not find a boat ready to carry he over he make his prayer to almighty God and present without the help of man a boat loose of its own accord from the other a strange miracle side of the river and come over to the bank where he sit into which he enter with his companion and without any sail or oar they be both waft over in a moment have perform this pilgrimage he return to the place of his belove solitude where by the instigation of the devil the firebrand of all mischief he endure most vehement tentation of the flesh that grow so strong upon he as often time he wish rather to suffer death itself than so painful to struggle and fight against those importune allurement to increase these vexation the monk that be guardian or overseer of the island do often treat he with very sharp language cast to his tooth many contumelious and disdainful speech till at length admire the wonderful humility join to the continual piety and devotion of the man he throw himself prostrate at his foot and with weep entreaty humble crave pardon for his temereity the holy man with great joy take he from the ground quick pardon whatsoever he have commit against he and from thence forth their mind be ever after unite in the band of true love and charity 3 in the mean time messenger be send from his parent his friend endeavour to recall he but in vain who earnest desire he to voutchafe to come over and visit his native country friend and kinsfolk which he utter refuse to do stout affirm that for the love of CHRIST and hope of eternal life he have quite forsake his country and whatsoever else be dear unto he therein and therefore to return to it again be to incur that hard censure of CHRIST whoesoever lay his hand to the plough and look back be not worthy of the kingdom of heaven they reply that luc. 9 v. 62. in his own country there be many desert and solitary place much fit for his purpose then this which do expect he and shall be at his free disposition hereat be move with a natural love to his own country he give some ear to their peaswasion but differ to give they his absolute resolution till the next morrow promise in the mean time to do whatsoever shall be please and acceptable unto God the night follow muse and ponder many thing in his mind and be whole ignorant and uncertain what course to take he have recourse unto almighty God beseech he with prayer wash i^ the stream of his own tear to inspire what will be most acceptable unto his divine goodness for he to do when as he pray he hear a voice seem to come from the crucifix before he that forbid he to depart from this solitude but courageous to hold on in the course he have begin promise a crown of glory for the reward of his labour and perseverance then fall prostrate see the force of his pious resolution on the ground give thanks unto almighty God he desire that he will give he such a impediment as shall hinder and retain he there although he be desirous and willing to depart he have his desire for as he give himself to sleep be weary with the instancy of his watch and prayer he be sudden strike as it be with a sword that make he break of his sleep scarce well begin and put down his hand he feel he s^l^ wound with a most grievous pain on his knee which grow daily worse and worse grow at length to a mighty ulcer out of which every day run great store of corrupt matter with such a stench as it be insufferable to those that come near he insoemuch that the messenger that come to fetch he thence return well enough satisfy suppose that his friend albeit he be willing will not desire the company of a creature so loathsome as now he be 4 notwithstanding all this the holy man live by the labour of his own hand and continue his daily work in till his little piece of ground which as he dig he be glad to sustain his own unableness by the help of a staff when he wax weary of work he wouldsitt he down on a stone to rest and expose his a strange example sore to the face of the sun with the heat whereof the corrupt breed of the hide filth therein which be great store of creep worm will sally or issue forth but see the wonderful patience o^ this holy man as they sell to the earth he will gather they up again and restore they to their former possession say return return and consume the impure of your own nature who inheritance you be almighty God grant to his till of a barren piece of ground a incredible increase of fruit from the little earth he have and a increase of patience unto himself for by how much the more sharp and miserable the force of his grief do pierce into the strength of his body with so much the more alacrity of heart in the anguish of his tribulation do he always give thanks unto his maker and refer himself to the disposition of his divine will and providence v. this bless hermit be so illuminate by God that he be wont to see and foretell not only thing present and at hand his gift of farresoe and foresee but alsoe such as pass a far off and be but in future for as once the monk guardian of the island come into his oratory he find he prostrate before the altar pour out a flood of bitter tear which seem to betray some great anguish of mind of who the monk demand the cause of his sorrow he look upon he with a blubber face make this answer my own brother say he by the cruelty of malignant people be murder within my father own land and our lord have privilege and licence prayer and penance for the dead i to do worthy penance for his soul therefore my belove master be you a publisher of this my woe unto the religious and other of your knowledge that by the help of your prayer suffrage and almsdeed he may be find worthy to receive absolution from the pain that his sin deserve 5 one that some day before have bestow a towel upon he come again to visit he to who the saint have thou as yet say he pacify the wrath of thy angry wife who discontent be so violent against thou for the small gift bestow upon i here take it again and give it she if that will make her patient with thou hereafter thus will he object and reveal unto many that come unto he those thing which they think to be most hide and secret as direct as if he have see all with his corporal eye and of their secret fault he will sharp reprehend they to the great wonder and admiration of the doer 7 at length when like a other Job in the continual suffering of his loathsome grief be alone in his poor cottage without the assistance of any man he have pass over some year overcome many a tedious day and irksome night with wonderful patience the hour of his death draw near wherein he shall receive heavenly music at his death the everlasting reward of his labour there be hear in the air over his cell most melodious tune of heavenly voice that enterchaingeable sing the hymn LAUDAMUS to the end in the mean time a monk that hear the sound of his little bell run thither and find he sit on a stone with the bell-rope in one hand and a candle burn in the other and perceave he to be dead he put of his garment and his hayre-cloath-shirt and have wash his body with water it become sudden as white and clear as snow neither do there remain on his skin any sign or scar of his former grief to be perceive his face seem so beautiful and resplendent as he can hardly be know for the man he have be and he appear as though not death but a sweet sleep have seize on his body 8 the Benedictine monk of Tinemouth hear of his departure meet together to carry away the body and bury it in their church but the people of the next parish fear much to be rob of so great a treasure according to their foretaken counsel gather a multitude of man together and endeavour to prevent the monk by take away the body by force to bury it in their own church but they be no soon at sea but there arise a thick mist which paint the face of heaven with such a hidcous and dark picture of night that those ravisher wander out of their way they know not whither lose both themselves and the prey they seek for the monk safe arrive at Tinemouth with their holy lade bury it very honourable near unto the body of s. OSWIN king and martyr in a arch of the wall on the south side of the church where many miracle be wrought afterward by the intercession of this glorious saint he die in the year of our lord 1120. the sixteenth day of January his life be extant at antwenrp in a ancient manuscript out of which JOANNES Anglicus and JOHN CAPGRAVE we have gather the foresay history the life of s. WOLSTANUS EPISCOPUS WIGORNIENSIS monachus Benedictinus jan. 19 the life of s. wolstan bishop of Worcester a monk of the holy order of s Benedict jan. 19 write by Senatus bravon a monk of Worcester the belove servant of God s. wolstan be bear in Warwickshire of worthy and religious parent who offer he to s. Benedict in the monastery of Peterborough where his youth be pious train up and instruct both in secular learning and ecclesiastical discipline till he grow of year and sufficiency that he be make priest in which sacred function he so worthy behave himself that his godly manner of life be always his manner of life be a priest in the world correspondent unto the height of his dignity he ever celebrate his mass with wonderful great gravity and reverence add both before and after that dreadful sacrifice daily preparation and prayer in which for the most part he spend the whole day be ERMENBURG queen and abbess of s. benedict order jan. 21. out of Matthew Westmin and other saint ERMENBURG daughter to Ermenred brother of Ercombert king of Kent be marry unto Merwald king of the mercian with who she have the happiness to be the mother of the three holy virgin Milburg Mildred and Mildgith who she bring up so pious as afterward they all embrace a monastical life and become nun and saint of s. benedict order their mother also queen Ermonburg although her husband be yet live yet she be so take with the desire of a solitary and monastical life that she never rest until she have obtain the consent of her husband to the furtherance of her virtuous desire which be get she go into Kent to her cousin egbert that reign there and make he acquaint with her holy purpose earnest entreat he to put his help hand to the performance of her good intention egbert be much move at so great devotion give she a piece of land at the town of Estrey in Kent according to her own election and build she a monastery upon it dedicate to the two holy martyr ethelbert and ethelred her brother where s. of ethelbert and ethelred see the seaventeenth of October ERMENBURG have gather together the number of seventy other nun under the holy order of s. Benedict spend the remnant of her life in the continual exercise of religion and virtue govern the monastery as abbess with all true observance of regular discipline until by almighty God she be call out of this world to receive the everlasting reward of her merit in a better what day she die it be uncertain but this one and twentieth of January be make a commemoration of she of this bless saint do make mention MATHEW Westminster ann. 654. and 676. william malmesbury gest reg. angl. lib. 1. c. 1. and gest Pontif. ang. l. 4. and NICHOLAS HARPSFIELD hist eccl. saec. 7. cap. 10. who we have follow the life of s. theorithgid virgin andnunne of s. benedict order jan. 22. out of venerable bede hist. gest ang. lib. 4. c. 9 theorithgid be scholar unto the holy abbess s. EDILBURG 1. cor. 12. in the Benedictine monastery of berk in Essex where she live for many year ever exercise in the diligent service of almighth tie god with all humility and sincerity and help s. EDILBURG the abbess to keep the true observance of regular discipline she be the mistress to correct and instruct the young sort or novice but that her virtue may as the apostle say be make perfect in infirmity she be sudden take with a most grievous sickness and through the merciful providence of our redeemer she be afflict there with for the space of nine year that whatsoever spot of filthy sin by ignorance or negligence have creep in and get place among she other virtue may be quite parch and burn up in the painful furnace of a long tribulation 2 this holy virgin go out of her bed one night towards the she enjoy a strange vision dawn of the day see manifest as it be the body of one bright than the sun itself carry up on high in a white sheet from ward the dorter where the sister take they rest till at length it be draw out of her sight into the open heaven by this vision she suppose to be signify that some one of her sister be short to be call out of the world as indeed it fall out for within a few day s. EDILBURG the abbess change this life for a better 3 now when theorithgid the bless handmaid of CHRIST have live three year more after the death of the abbess she be so far spend with the forename sickness that her skin and bone do scarce hang together and at the last the time of her departure draw near she lose not only the use of all her other limb but be not able to move that member which be most voluble her tongue in which case have endure wonderful pain for the space of three day and three night be then recreate with a celestial vision she open her eye and cheerful look towards heaven begin to speak in this manner unto the vision she behold thy come be very grateful unto i and thou be hearty s. Edilburg appear unto she and reucale the hour of her death welcome this say she be silent as it be expect the answer of the party she speak unto and again as she be a little move I can say she glad endure this present after a short silence she speak the three time if it can be to day I beseech thou that it be not long delay then be silent a while she conclude thus if it be full so ordain and that this sentence can be change I beseech thou that there be this only night between be demand with who she hold this discourse she answer with my most dear mother EDILBURG whereby they understand that her come be to bring news that the time of theorithgids departure be at hand for according to her desire after that day and the next night be deliver out of the prison of her weak body she take her flight to the celestial paradise to receive the eternal reward of her suffering she die about the year of our lord six hundred seventy eight thus much we have take out of venerable bede gest lib. 4. cap. 9 and Nicolas HARPSFIELD saec. 7. cap. 14. of she do make mention MOLANUS in append and Arnold WION in append martirolog the life of s. Cadox bishop and martyr jan. 25. out of joannes Anglicus s. CADOCK be bone in Wales noble parent his father be call Gundley his mother Gladusa be baptize by a anachorite of that country under the same man care he be bring up and instruct in the rudiment of christian religion in which he profit wonderful be yet but a youth he bear the mind of a age man refuse to follow such youthful sport as his equal invite he unto true consider that in the late day laughter shall be change into weep and weep into joy at length depart from his master and his native soil he build a monastery he build a monastery in Glamorganshire about three mile distant from cowbridge into which have gather a good number of monk he institute they in the rule of a monastical life the monastery be call Llancarnanan that be the service of heart because it be report that in that work he have wild heart familiar and obedient unto he there in very great abstinence he lead a solitary life night and day apply himself unto the contemplation of heaven and heavenly thing but the same of his learning and sanctity be a cause that many famous man flock unto he and put themselves into the rank of his scholar and by the instruction of so good a master make a wonderful progress both in learning and virtue among these be Gildas surname the wise and Ellenius that afterward succeed he in the government of the monastery and many other 2 in his time a certain captain or duke of the Britan have slay a duke fly to he for succour three of noble king Arthur soldier be compel be cruel persecute by the king to fly for refuge to s. CADOCK who comiserate his case very courteous entertain he till the king be somewhat pacify at the holy man entreaty it be determine by the judge of the country that to redeem the man slay he shall give for each one three of his best kine according to the ancient law of the Britain but king Arthur refuse to take such kine a be of one colour with much wrangle demand such as have their fore part red and hinder part diverse spot with white and black whereuppo the nine beast be by the paayer of s. CADOCK change into the forename colour and present again in the king own sight turn into so many bundell or faggott of fearne whereat much astonish he humble demand pardon for his unjust demand many other wonderful miracle be report to have be do by the prayer of this holy man which because they seem to be not very authentical report be witting ommit only this we have that be afterward make bishop he desire of almighty God to pass out of this life throng martirdom which be grant he for as he celebrate the mystery of the dreadful sacrifice of he be martyr day ma^le at the altar the mass a tyrannous ring leader of a army of other wicked spirit waste and spoil the town be he live a knight of this bloody company rule by a mad fury run into the church and with his lanuce pierce the of the holy man at the altar who with his hand lift up to heaven recommend his soul unto almighty God and earnest crave pardon for his murderer depart out of this world to receive a place among the holy martyr in heaven the twenty four day of January about the year of our lord five hundred seventy in the reign of Malgocune over the totter state of Brittany the memory of this saint be conserve to these our day in many church in Wales and one in gloucestershire dedicate to his name and honour by a other name he it be call Sophia which give occasion of error to the author of he english martirologe when he make Cadock and Sophia to be diverse saint his life we have gather out of JOANNES Anglicus recite by JOHN CAPGRAVE Nicolas Harpsfield saec. 6. cap. 27. and other the life of s. BATHILDE queen and nun of the holy order of s. Benedict jan. 26. write by a author of the same time the author prologue by how much the virtuous life of widddowe be more famous in merit by so much it be worthy of praise in the mouth of the world for they no soon show a example of pious conversation unto other but they stir up the tongue of all to celebrate their praise call therefore to mind the excellent virtue and merit of the glorious and religious widow and worthy queen s. BATHILDE once wife to the famous king of France Clodovens let we give praise and glory unto JESUS CHRIST our redeemer who be always know to be wonderful in his saint and to lay open the way of justice unto we not only by man but by the frailty of woman allsoe he show both to we and to all those that love he rare example of religion and virtue for indeed our god have a special care of all and will have none of those to perish that he have redeem by the shed of his own precious blood holy man he exhort to remain in their sanctity and admonish sinner to forsake their sin and follow good work that they may walk the high way to heaven which be understand and well understand by this venerable lady she study with great care to fulfil it for she be both religious and very devout towards God and take upon her the care of the church and the poor with a wonderful courage of mind she stout govern the palace and uncontrolled she rule the kingdom of France in so much that her own desert exact it she be reverence of all the bishop peer and people through out her kingdom with more than ordinary love and affection the renown of who life because she be bear in England I have here set forth among our english saint i. s. BATHILDE descend by birth from the noble blood of the saxon in England but be take away in her youth not without the particular providence of almighty God and as a prey carry into France she be sell at a rate far to base for so incomparable a parcel of merchandise there this precious and admirable jewel of God be first entertain by a famous prince of the french by name Erchinoaldus then chief ruler of the king palace in who service be but young she behave herself so decent that her she serve the prince Erchinoald virtuous conversation and admirable condition be very please both to the prince and all his family for she be of a generous mind most chaste in her behaviour sober prudent and friendly plot harm to none in her speech neither light nor presumptuous but guide all her action with the sincerity of a noble wit the form of her body be correspondent to the nobility of her birth verle grateful and beautiful to all beholder of a countenance merry and constant and in her gate grave in a word she behave herself in all thing so well become herself that she please the prince erchinoald infinite and get great favour in his sight in so much that he appoint she to wait at his elbow where often time she play the part of a honest cuppbearer careful fill wine unto he she grow not proud with this favour but rather be well ground in humility become more obedient and love to all her companion serve her elder with such reverence as she disdain not with her own hand to untie and pull of their shoe at night and make they clean to provide they water to wash and the like all which work of humility she do exercise with a prompt and willing mind by this her behaviour so humble noble and noble humble among her fellow she get a wonderful praise and love of all and her good fame deserve so happy that erchinoald the prince desire she shall succeed in place of his bedfellow who be dead and become his second wife which this holy maid understanding inspire by God grace with great care and secrecy she withdraw herself from his sight and be call to she fly the marriage of Erchinoald the prince chamber she hide herself in a corner of the house under some ragged clothes so subtle that no man suspect she be in that room and then like a wise and crafty maid fly all vain honour and humble embrace a humble chasterie she endeavour to her power to avoid the company of a man that she may deserve to enjoy the society of her spiritual and heavenly spouse but have escape the prince embracement and he in the mean time be marry unto a other by the disposition of she marry the king the almighty providence it come to pass that she who have avoid the marriage of this prince shall afterward be join in wedlock unto the great monarch of France Clodoneus and be raise by the desert of her humility to a high degree of dignity by refuse the king servant she be marry unto the king himself and become the mother of the royal progeny which without all doubt be thus bring to pass that she who descend from the race of king shall by marry a king bring forth a issue of king but in all these honour ever rule herself by the reins of wisdom her wonderful work of mercy with a watchful care she obey the king as her lord carry herself to the prince as a mother to priest as a daughter and to youngling as a pious nurse she be love unto all honour priest as her father favour monk as her brethren cherish the poor as her domestic and remember her own estate of pilgrimage she entertain pilgrim as her own child she be a perpetual refuge unto widow orphan and fatherless child and give succour unto all that be weak and in want she will always exhort young man to piety and religion and often put the king in mind to have a care of the church and poor alsoe be desirous in this her secular habit to serve under the banner of CHRIST JESUS she often frequent her prayer daily recommend herself with tear of devotion unto her heavenly King of who her earthly king Clodoneus be likewise very careful that she may the better bring to pass what she have in mind conceive according to her own faith and devotion counsel she to have some conference her charity to religious house with the venerable abbot genesius to aid and assist she in her pious intention through who hand she exercise her piety to priest give maintenance to the poor clothe the naked and careful bury the dead by he she send no small store of gold silver and other rich gift unto the monastery both of man and woman all which be by this pious servant of God with great care perform 2 in the mean time king die and leave the care of his child to their mother by who mean and the authority of the peer of the realm lotharins the elder son be settle in the government of the kingdom of France also through the labour of this bless queen her son Childerick be make king of A^strasia and the burgundian enter into a league with the French she build the monastery of Chelles 3 have thus order the public affair of the kingdom it be incredible what great commodity and gift she large bestow on religious house in land wood and other hereditament either to build their monastery on or to maintain those that be build with sufficiency yet this her great liberality do not seem to satisfy the piety of her desire unless at she own only charge she do build a monastery which and rich endow the same among the other particular house of God shall look towards heaven wherefore now as it be spurn the sea of the world she erect a monastery for nun of s. benedict order at a place near unto Paris common call Chelles on the bank of the river marne this abbey she enrich with wonderful great revenue of whole village and lordship all which she deliver into the possession of the nun live there strict and severe oblige the rule thereof in a precept seal with she own hand and the king seal that none hereafter shall ever presume to alienate or diminish any of the good or land thereunto belong under pain of incur damnation with the traitor Judas and this writing she cause to be safe reserve in the treasury of the monastery where to this very day there live a very religious convent of a above threescore nun of s. benedict order in a very strict observance of regular discipline she be foundress of the abbey of Corbey 4 this glorious queen build a other monastery in the suburd of Amiens call Corbey abbey and place therein a devout flock of monk likewise of s. benedict order over who Theodofred be ordain abbot and to this place allsoe she give great revenue of land and rend sufficient for the maintenance of a great convent it be almost incredible unto how many other monastery and abbey of man and woman and unto how many church else this devout queen make donation of spacious land great good rich gift and uncomparable ornament never cease from do such pious office for the pure and sincere love of God who honour and glory in all her action she chief endeavour to increase v. her piety and virtue increase daily and now she be in very great care to undertake a monastical life in the monastery of she be take with a desire of areligious life Chelles which she have erect and to dwell there in body as she do in mind but the peer and noble of the realm withstand she devout intention chief because by her wisdom the palace be govern and for that her pious conversation have gain the love of all so that they have not permit she to have her desire herein have not a certain commotion happen about the miserable bishop sigebrand who pride among the french hasten his own death and ruin hence therefore a contention arise among they and have put the bishop to death against the course of law without examine his cause fear the bless queen severe punishment a example of the divine providence and revenge of so great and wicked a offence they persuade she to embrace her pious intend course which before out of a temporal respect they will not permit she to do but although the prince do this rather out of policy than any love of goodness yet the holy woman lighten by God grace consider that this come not to pass so much by their counsel as by the secret providence of the divine wisdom to the end her intend devotion may by some occasion be fulfil according to her desire be therefore convey by some of the most ancient prince of France unto the long desire monastery of Chelles and there by the nun honourable receive into their company she give hearty she become a nun thanks unto almighty God who hithereunto have preserve she under the shadow of his holy protection and now have bring she unto the sweet haven of her desire now she that before sway the her obedience sceptre of France submit herself to the obedience of a poor abbess as her mother appear to the rest of her sister not as a mistress but as a discreet servant in all thing piouf bear a serviceable duty unto they and with such courage of mind she show her humility unto all a example of sincere humility that in her turn she will serve her sister according to s. benedict rule in the office of the kitchen wash and cleanse all implement thereunto be long and perform all other base office of the house and these act of humility she do with a merry and willing mind for the pure love of he that say in the gospel i come not to be serve but to serve for what heart can ever think that the height of so mat. 20. v. 28. great power shall become a in thing so base and abject unless the mighty love of CHRIST have grant this special grace unto she with tear she daily insist at her devotion and prayer and often time frequent her spiritual lecture and in her visitation of the sick which be very frequent her custom be to impart some pious consolation and godly exhortation unto they her charity she be so well practify in the study of charity as she sorrow with the sorrowful rejoice with the joyful and for the weak and sickly she will often with humility put the abbess in mind rom. 12. to get they provide with necessary help both for body and soul who pious desire she like a good mother do very careful see perform for indeed according to the rule of the apostle act. 4. they have but one heart and one soul so dear and tender they love each other in the true love of JESUS CHRIST 5 in the mean time this bless woman begin to be afflict she fall sick with a sickness of body and to labour grievous with a certain gripe in the gut which have bring she near her end have not the grief be something assuage by the power of physic but although the force of her pain do cruel torment her tender body yet she cease not out of the purity of a holy conscience to give thanks unto the heavenly physician who succour those that labour in tribulation and from who she confident expect to receive the everlasting reward of her suffering and show herself a great example of virtue unto other she study to give her sister a pattern of true piety obedience and humility often admonish the abbess to be likewise mindful of her duty towards the king and queen and other noble their friend that the house of God may not loose the good name and fame it have get but rather encease it more and more in the true affection of charity towards their friend and chief to get strength and constancy in the sacred love of God and their neighbour for according to s. Paul we ought alsoe to have the good testimony of those which be 1. tim. 3. without but above all by the mercy and love of JESUS CHRIST she recommend unto she to have a very special care of the poor and of stranger 7 therefore the death of this holy saint be at hand there appear a famous vision unto she in which she behold a ladder stand up right before the altar of the b. virgin Marie the her vision before she die top whereof seem to reach unto the heaven and many angel ascend thereon which seem to accompany and lead she herself to the never die joy of paradise o true happy who in her journey have angel her companion this be the ladder which she erect to heaven in her life time these be her fellow angel who by her exercise of good work she make her friend the degree of this ladder be the twelve degree of humility contain in the holy rule of s. Benedict which she profess by the continual exercise whereof she deserve to be exalt to the clear vision of of CHRIST JESUS the master of all humility by this vision the holy woman plain understand that short she be to leave this world and take her journey thither where long since she have hide her great and chief treasure command those that have be eye witness of the vision to conceal it from the rest of her sister that they may not be contristate until it please almighty God to call she unto he in midst of these joy she begin more and more with piety and alacrity of mind to insist at her prayer never cease with humility and compunction of heart to recommend herself unto her heavenly king CHRIST JESUS and hide as much as she be able the vehemency of her grief she consort the abbess Bertilia and the rest of her sister with some hope of her recovery ease they hereby of a present sorrow which afterward take they before they expect it 8 but perceave within a short time after that now she she yield up her soul be to pay nature her due and feel the violence of her pain to be ready to cut asunder the union of her soul and body confident arm herself with the sign of our redemption and lift up her hand and eye towards heaven she yield up her bless soul out of the tedious fetter of the body to be crown with the diadem of eternal glory for at the same instant a divine splendour she be carry into heaven by angel shine over all the chamber and with that very light there appear to the stander by a troop of angel with who come her faithful friend genesin the bishop to meet she and by this heavenly troop her bless soul long try in the furnace of affliction be carry up out of their sight to receive the reward of her holy merit among the angel and saint in heaven she be bury SEXULPH bishop and confessor of s. benedict order jan. 28. this holy man be the first abbot and in some kind founder of the Benedictine abbey of Medishamsted dedieat to s. PETER which afterward by reason of the greatness be call Peterborough in which office have for some year discharge the by his suasion king wulfere build this abbey part of a good and religious prelate by the authority of Theodore archbishop of Canturbury he be consecrate bishop of Lichfield in place of Winfrid depose from that sea for his disobedience he govern his people with very great sainctetie of life and example of good work for the space of three year when be load with virtuous deed he leave this world to take his place among his fellow Benedictin monk in heaven about the year of our lord 700.
