SEXULPH the life of s. gyldas abbot and confessor jan. 29. out of a anncient author recite by John Capgrave gyldas bear in that part of Brittany now call Scotland and one of the twenty four son which a king of that country have by one wife be from his youth of a very virtuous disposition and much incline to the knowledge of all manner of learning for the better obtain of his desire therein he pass over into France where he employ seven year in the continual study of all good science and return into Brittany load with great store of book and learning but to the end he may with more freedom attend unto the contemplation of heavenly he go into frace to study thing he with draw himself from the tumult of the world into a solitary place of abode where he lead the life of a hermit continual chastise his body with fast prayer watch and haircloth yet his virtue can not lie so hide but that many be draw to he with the noise of his great fame to be instruct both in religion and learning and at their departure they serve as trumpet to invite other unto he such great content they receive in his virtuous life and rare learning whatsoever gift he receive from the charity of the rich sort he always distribute unto the poor content himself with the riches of his his great austerity of life own poverty he never taste any flesh his ordinary food be herb and barley bread mingle with ash in steed of spice his drink pure water out of the fountain his continual abstinence have bring his face to such leanne that he all way appear like a man that have a fever at midnight his custom be to enter into the river up to the neck and in that sort he power out his prayer to almighty God while his tear strive with the stream which shall run fast afterward he repair to his oratory and spend the rest of the night in prayer his clothing be one single garment in which only he take his rest lie upon the down of a hard rock have teach many both in word and deed to follow the rule of good life he depart into Jreland where he convert a great multitude of that rude people to the faith of CHRIST short after return into Brittany he find his brother Howell slay by king Arthur who humble crave pardon of his fault receive from the saint a salutation of peace friendship and forgiveness he be a perpetual enemy unto the Pelagian heretic and to be the better inform against they and their doctrine he make a journey against heresy he consult the roman church to the fountain of true religion Rome and return not only better instruct against they himself but able to fortify and strengthen other with such sound principle of catholic religion that they may easy defend their cause against all the vain battery and proud bull wark of heresy 2 at length he build a little church upon a rock in a island near unto the river seaverne where spend his time night he build a ermitage and day in continual prayer he keep his mind whole vacant and free from the world and worldly creature serious attend the contemplation of the divine goodness of his creator but be in such want of fresh water that he have no other store but what be retain after a shower in little hole of the rock he make his prayer to almighty God who send he a clear spring of water g^shing out of the same place but by the frequent injury and incursion he depart to glasten bury of pirate he be compel to depart from hence to Glastenbury and be honourable receive of the abbott he instruct the monk and people thereabouts in the science both of humane and divine thing and build a little church not far from thence he lead there a eremitical life in great austerity and penance unto who as unto a oracle many come from all part of Brittany to partake of his wisdom and learning he who holy desire tend only towards heaven strive with all the force of eloquence he can to divert their mind from the transitory thing of this world and settle they on the only consideration of heaven have in this manner spend some year in this habitation the holy man fall into a grievous sickness which make he quick understand that the hour of his death be nigh therefore earnest desire of the abbot to have his body bury at Glastenbury and recommend his soul unto the hand of almighty God he leave this miserable world to receive his reward in a better the twenty nine day of January in the year of our lord 512. his body according to his desire be bury at Glastenbury in the midst of the old church of this holy saint make mention MATHEW WESTMINST. n. HARPSFIELD saec. 6. cap. 23. JOHN CAPGRAVE and other who we have follow the life of s. BIRSTAN bishop and confessor jan. 30. out of William malmesbury and Westminster saint BIRSTAN be a man of most pure and sincere life be choose bishop of Winchester where he rule the space of four year he be wont every day to sing or say mass for the soul depart and by night without any fear he will walk about the churchyard recite psalm and other prayer to the same end and as once in his wont devotion he go this round mass and prayer for the dead and add to the end of his prayer in pace he hear from the ground the voice as it be of a infinite army that answer amen whereby he find his labour and prayer to be very grateful and profitable unto the soul depart the same holy man be a ardent follower of our lord example will every day without any spectator execute act of profound humility in wash with his own hand the foot of diverse poor people cover they a table give they sufficiency of meat and at length his work of humility as their devout servant take away what be leave this service be finish and his poor guest dismiss he will remain in the same room the space of two or three hour at his prayer until once enter according to custom to exercise these pion office not have be before trouble with sign of any sickness sudden unknown to all his soul depart out of his mortal lodging the manner of his death leave it void of all vital spirit his family and servant that have long be acquaint with his custom think that then he be alsoe busy at his prayer let he lie there a whole day and the next morning break into his chamber they find a dead body stark and stiff without any sign of life therefore with great cry and lamentation they bury he in the church of Winchester but the citizen of the town because they see he intercept by a kind of sudden death bury the worthy memory of the holy man in the deep cave of silence be ignorant that it be write the man that live well can die ill and by what sap. 4. death soever the just man shall be prevent and overtake he shall be in a place of refresh and comfort but a long time after this their rashness be correct by the almighty power of he that can err for to Ethelwold bishop of the same place as one night he watch and he appear to s. Ethelwold pray according to his custom before the relic of the saint in the church of Winchester there appear three person which stand by he not in a ecstasy but full awake the midst of the three speak these word I be BIRSTAN in time past bishop of this city this on my right hand be BIRINE the first preacher and that on my left be SWITHINE the special patron of this church and city and thou must know that as thou see i here present with they so do I enjoy the same glory with they in heaven why therefore be I deprive of the honour and reverence of mortal man who be high exalt in the company of heavenly spirit saint be to honour at these word they vanish and ever after by the commandment of s. ETHELWOLD his memory be celebrate with great veneration by this we may learn that holy man the providence of heaven so dispose may sometime be take away by sudden death and not without a special favour in get by a minute of pain that which other can obtain but by many year torment of sickness this holy man be consecrate b. an. 932. and die in the year of our lord 934. thus much of he we have gather out of WILLIAM malmesbury lib. 2. pontific angl. and MATHEW Westminster ann. 932. NICHOLAS HARPSFIELD saec. 10. cap. 8. POLIDORE Virgil lib. 6. Arnold WION lib. 2. lig and other mak^ worthy mention of he the life of s. wilgis confessor and monk of the holy order of s. Benedict jan. 31. out of s. in the life of s. willibrord there be in that part of the brittsh island call Northumberland a househoulder name Wilgis by birth a saxon or Englishman who have be natural father unto willibrord afterward a saint and archbishop of vtreight as if he have perform the whole duty of his marriage resolve both he and his wife to leave the world and undertake a religious course of life which holy purpose how virtuous he accomplish be by miracle afterward sufficient testify and make know to the world for have leave his secular garment he put on the black monastical habit of the holy order of s. Benedict and make profession of a monk not he take the habit of s. Benedict upon a force service but out of a true will and desire to religion and because in leave his house and temporal good and enroul himself into a spiritual warfare in the camp of JESUS CHRIST he have undertake a perfect life he will not therefore be backward in what he profess but in all thing show himself to be a most perfect servant unto the dear master he serve but when he have for a while give a pattern of his virtuous life in the school of the monastery he become so brave a soldier that the rudeness of the fearful desert can not affright he for shut up himself within the limit of a straight and narrow cottage that stand between he lead a eremitical life the ocean and the river Humber dedicate to s. andrew the apostle he labour in the exercise of a solitary conversation and imitate his grand master s Benedict he lead a heavenly and angelical life on earth in pureness exceed the ruddy blush of the rose or the whiteness of the fair lily but delightful shine with a more sweet variety of virtue then do a dove in the beam of the sun with diversity of colour within a short space his desire to lie hide be betray by the wonder of his frequent miracle and his name be blow so far abroad with the trumpet jan. 31. of fame till it arrive at the king court and sound such a alarm all over the country of Scotland that great store of people flock unto he who he never send away empty but always load with the sweet instruction and admonition of his heavenly learning the fame of his virtue draw many scholar be compel hereuppon to labour sometime in a contemplative and other time in a practical manner of life he become at last of so great esteem and honour with the king and noble of the realm that they give he the possession of some land near adjoin and bestow many other rich gift upon he by help whereof he build a honourable church on the sea side in honour of the b. virgin Marie and gather together a convent of Bevedictine monk small in number but great in the exercise of true virtue and religion these he govern as abbott with all sanctity of he build a monastery life and doctrine until the divine clemency willing to set a period to the conflict of his holy labour absolve this his worthy champion from the most painful warfare of this present life to reign in his heavenly court which so long he have thirst for and desire he be very honourable bury in the same church which he have build and at his tomb have be wrought many and wonderful miracle which give evident testimony of how great price and dignity his most bless soul be hold to be in the sight of almighty God he die the 29. of January but his feast be celebrate on this day in the benedictin abbey of s. willibrord in Germany where say s. wine wonderful increase by his merit ALCVINE on the annual feast of s. WILGIS there be but one flagon of wine in the house it be by the merit of this b. saint so miraculous increase that the whole convent of monk which be a great number have every one drink two cup thereof it be nothing at all diminish whereupon the abbott and monk give thanks unto almighty God with joyful sobriety and sober jollity every man drink as much he desire thus much out of s. alcvine in the life of s. willibrord MOLANUS JOHN CAPGRAVE THEOFRID abbot of s. willibrords monastery in Germany make worthy mention of he the life of s. BRIGITT virgin of Kildare in Ireland feb 1. write by a author of the same time GOD be wonderful in his work and his power be infinite in that he draw good out of our naughtiness and condemn not the soul of the child for the sin of their parent but contrary wise he gather rose oftentimes out of the midst of thorn and produce a clear day out of the darkness of a ugly night we have a peculiar experience here of in the life of this holy virgin s. BRIGITT which follow 2 there be in Ireland a man call Duptac who have purchase as a slave a young and not unhandsome woman name become so amorous and fond of she that at length her her parent and birth great belly witness their more than honest familiarity together his own wife perceave this naughty husbandry be high enrage against her husband force he by all mean to make a resale of this slave and refuse to be persuade to pity either by earnest prayer remonstrance or indeed by the holy revelation which two good bishop have of the treasure which the slave carry in her womb in a word the good wi^e can take no rest nor repose until she see her husband minion as she term she out of her house the poor slave at her time be deliver of a daughter which be call BRIGITT who as soon as she have over grow the use of her nurse her father take home again into his own house where be very careful bring up she always carry herself honest the virtue of her youth humble peaceable obedient and above all so charitable that unintreated she take upon she the office of almoner in her father house give away to the poor whatsoever she can lay hold on and among other thing she have give away her father sword for this cause meaning to ride she away he go to the king and offer he a bargain of she at a easy rate the king have ask she why she give her father sword to the poor I give it reply she to CHRIST himself and true if God will demand it and that I be able I will free give my soweraigne lord the king and my father himself with both your good and possession unto his divine goodness hereat the king amaze say thy daughter be of too much worth either for thou to sell or for i to buy and give she a sword to make restitution unto her father he send she away 3 these virtue of her soul be accompany with a exceed her beauty of body fair beauty of body and especial her face and eye be so excellent in that gift that they ravish the heart of all those that behold she and make many desire and seek she in marriage her father be much sue unto on all side and not know how to ride himself of those impatient wooer nor answer their importunity motion the matter to his daughter give her free leave to make choice of a husband according to her own like among that band of suitor but BRIGITT who desire JESUS CHRIST for she only dear spouse and to consecrate her virginity unto he she obtain the loss of a eye to avoid suitor be quite of a other intention and know that the beauty of her face be the chief cause of these rude assault she pray hearty unto her sacred spouse to give such a deformity unto it as may hereafter breed rather a detestation of all the than love of any towards she our lord hear her prayer and grant her request by the loss of one of her fair eye which burst and drop out of her head like a dissolve pearl and by this mean she become so defform that no man seek after her any more when she get her father consent to hasten her entrance into a monastery of religious woman which be the only height and aim of her desire at the time she receive the holy vayse of chastity from the hand of Machil bishop and disciple unto s. PATRICK he behold she enter into religion and be restore to her former beauty a pillar of fire hang over her head and as she incline her body and lay her hand on the foot-step of the altar which albeit it be of dry season wood yet at her touch and in testimony of her chastity it wax green and flourish afresh and at the very same instant her eye be restore again and her face become more beautiful than ever for it seem her dear spouse will not endure that she who have desire to loose her beauty to preserve her virginity shall remain in such deformity 4 we shall never come to a end if we go about to set down in this paper all the rare and excellent virtue of this bless virgin with this wonderful great miracle which our saviour wrought at her intercession it shall suffice to rehearse some only she free a young maid from t^e company of the devil be by a young maid invite to dinner she see the devil sit by her side that have invite she and have ask he what he do there and why he come thither he answer that the weakness and idleness of that maid invite he to stay with she with who he find himself very welcome the maid have hear these word speak with a long and intelligible voice and see not the author be much amaze until be will by s. BRIGITT she make the sign of the cross on her eye and then she see that dreadful ugly beast belch flame of fire out of his horrid throat which sight together with the persuasion of the saint make she to acknowledge her fault and amend her life be free ever after of the company of that infernal monster v. a woman bring unto this holy virgin a basket of apple a woman punish for disobey she for a present find at the self same time some poor leper at the door expect a alm the saint bid she give those apple unto the wretch at the door but the woman whether of niggardliness or out of some horror she conceive refuse so as she think base to bestow they say that she bring they for she and her religious sister and not for such loathsome creature this answer much displease the holy virgin who sharp reprehend she for hinder a work of charity with a prophetic spirit tell she that in punishment of this offence all the tree in her orchard shall wither away and never bear fruit again the woman depart and be come home find her tree which she have leave well store with apple to have store of nothing but want and from that time they remain dry barren and fruitless ever after 5 a naughty woman be deliver of a son unlawful beget the better to hide her offence lay it to the charge of the holy bishop broon disciple to s. PATRICK but when he avow the contrary that he be most free from any such wicked act s. BRIGITT send for the woman and ask she who be the father of punishment of (@) her child she answer very impudent that no man but the bishop have to do with it whereupon the saint make the sign of the cross upon the mouth of that vile woman present her shameless tongue swell in her head that she can not speak she also make the same sign of life on the tongue of the little infant a newborn child speak and demand of he who be his father a strange miracle he that never speak word before answer very distinct that it be not the bishop but a deform and vile fellow the base among all the common people and thus by the discovery of the truth the holy bishop reputation remain untouched that miserable woman do penance for her slander and the people give thanks unto the almighty searcher of our heart and secret 7 the daughter of a great prince have vow perpetual chastity and choose JESUS CHRIST for her only spouse be nevertheless forcible solicit by her father to marry on the day appoint the virtue of the sign of the cross for her marriage when the banquet and all other rich preparation be in a readiness she steal away secret from her father house and flee for refuge into s. brigitts monastery her father accompany with many horseman pursue she mean to take she out by force the saint see they come make the sign of the cross on the ground and at the very instant the man horse and all stand flock still like so many statue then the prince acknowledge the strength of the mighty hand of God to hold he do penance for his rashness and at the prayer of the saint both he and and his follower be set at liberty and his daughter persevere in the performance of her sacred vow 8 this bless saint have cure many disease the fame of her sanctity be blow over the country which make two leper come unto she with tear entreat to receive their s. Brigitt cure leper health for who have make her prayer unto almighty God she bless a little water and bid they wash one and other therewith one of they be cure she command he to wash his companion but he be so ravish with joy to see himself recover and so fearful to loose his health again that he have not the courage either to wash or touch his fellow fear thereby to repurchase his disease but he feel the punishment of God be sudden cover all his body over with the same leprosy when he see his companion perfect heal by the prayer of the holy Virgin 9 in the monastery of s. BRIGITT among her other Nun^^^ there be one beautiful young dame grievous haunt with a nun grievous trouble with lascivious thought lascivious thought which have enter into her heart at the gate of her eye by impure gaze on a dishonest person unto who she have promise a meeting at time convenient the flame of her filthy affection increase daily and the devil according to his custom forget not to blow those impure coal never suffer the poor soul to take any rest so necessary a thing it be to keep a close guard over the gate of our sense for fear we give death a entrance into our soul so that be near unto the utter ruin and shipwreck of her chastity whilst s. unto who our saviour have reveal all that pass make her prayer for she she be inspire by be cure by the prayer of s. Brigitt almighty God to go barefoot upon hot burn coal which she perform and by the heat of one ^ier she quench the flame of the other and by the sensual pain of her body overcome the eternal heat which do torment her soul on the morrow s BRIGITT speak these comfortable word unto she because say she thou have fight courageous this night and extinguish the flame of wantonness which make war against thou hereafter thou shall be exempt both from they and the fire of hell then make her prayer unto almighty God for she she be cure of the burn of her foot and quite free from the wont temptation which do molest she x. a maid name Daria which be blind entreat s. to make the sign of the cross on her eye by mean thereof she she give sight to a blind maid not only recover her sight but allsoe by a inward light in the soul she understand that all whatsoever she can see in this world be subject to corruption and vanity and that that which we see oftentimes with our corporal eye be but a bar and hindrance to the soul therefore she return unto s. BRIGITT and desire to be restore again to her former blindness the saint by her prayer shut up the window of her eye in darkness which before she have open to behold the light a lady of that country who have a daughter that be dumb from her very birth bring she at the age of twelve year unto s. BRIGITT who take the girl by the hand say will thou for the love of JESUS CHRIST keep perpetual chastity her mother answer that her daughter forsooth she ^ureth a dumb gytle be dumb and can not speak nevertheless reply s. BRIGITT I will not let she go till she answer i then the girl speak and say she will obey her command in all thing in performance whereof she remain a virgin ever after and speak as well and as distinct as ani^ of her sex 11 nine man conspire among themselves the death of one man who they be agree to kill at a set day s. BRIGITT be she deliver a man from be slay by his enemi^^ advertise hereof labour as much as be possible by prayer and entreaty to avert they from this wickedness but find their cruel mind to be so obstinate bend to that bloody purpose as they grow rather worse by entreaty she have recourse unto almighty God her only refuge in distress humble desire he to hinder the execution of their malicious intent on the day appoint when they go about to act this bloody scene they see the very for i and figure of the man they mean to murder and take a figure for the true body as our Protestant do they run after with great fury to kill one who be dead already and have give he as many mortal wound as be sufficient to have murder the strong live man they return victorious to bring news of their triumph unto s. BRIGITT who smile at their mistake tell they the man they think they have slay be yet alive and that their courage have exercise his cruelty only upon the imaginary figure of their enemy and no man hereupon be much astonish they acknowledge their fault and repent they of their wicked purpose correct their life ever after 12 our lord wrought diverse other miracle by the holy merit many miracle do by s. Brigitt of this bless virgin the blind their sight the dumb their speech leper and other disease person recover their health by her prayer she turn water into beer and stone into salt she change the course of a great river and which be more by her good persuasion many desperate wicked fellow withdraw themselves out of the gulf of their vicious manner of life and enter into the sure port of religion where they finish their day in the service of JESUS CHRIST when this bless virgin ^ad happy end the course of her life and endure manine great labour for the love of JESUS chcist her dear spouse be advertise of her death and have make it know unto one of her sister specifi her death the day and hour thereof she give up her pure soul into the hand of her dear redeemer the first day of February in the year of our lord according to Sigebert 518. but marianus Scotus say 521. in the reign of the emperor justin the elder her life be write by a author of her time name COGITOSUS and by JOANNES Anglicus JOHN CAPGRAVE who we have follow the roman martirologe make mention of s. BRIGITT as allsoe that of s. bede VSVARD and Adonis and Baronius in his seven tome of annal but GYRALDUS a very grave author in his topography of Ireland among many other miracle of this bless saint make mention of s. brigitts fire miracle of s. Brigitts fi^r which be report to be unextinguished not that it can be extinguish but because the nun do so careful and continual nourish and feed it which new matter that from her time for many hundred year after it nevergo out and in the consume of so much wood which have be burn there in all this time the ash never increase this fire be compass about with a little hedge of twig within which no man dare to enter and if at any time some do presume so to do their presumption be punish by a revenge from heaven woman only do blow it and that not with their mouth but either with bellows or a fan a archer that rash attempt to leap over the headge and blow s. BRIGITTS fire with his mouth sudden lose his wit and fall into madness and run up and down the town put his breath in the face of all he meet say do thou see thus I blow brigit fire and wheresoever he find any fire he will blow it still repeat the same word till at length be take by his companion and bind hand and foot he desire to be bring to the next water where he drink so much to quench his extreme drought that he burst his belly and die many other say GIRALDUS be punish for the like attempt 14 but who do not behold and admire in the life of this glorious a brief consideration of her vettue and miracle saint the wonderful greatness of the goodness of almighty God who out of the sin of her parent draw so precious a jewel as s. BRIGITT make a poor slave to be the mother unto she that deliver^^ so many captive soul out of the servitude and slavery of sin how can the frail vessel of a poor bondslave gyrlo be capable of the noble condition of so great love unto virtue and of such a boil desire of pure virginity that for the preserve thereof she choose rather to loose the tender part of her body her eye and to deface her beauty the very idol of woman then to consent unto a lawful marriage how manifest it appreare hereby that our b. saviour be sweet and gracious to his true servant in restore unto BRIGITT her beauty of which at her own request and for her great good he have before deprive she so that it be no wonder if she that know so well how to keep she own virginity untouched and sacrifice it unto her dear lord be allsoe of power by her prayer to obtain the like favour for other young woman and deliver the innocence of the good bishop from the calumny which that wicked woman lay upon he and that God have wrought by this bless virgin the miracle before rehearse let he be ever praise and glorify as well for that which he be in himself as allsoe for what he work by his saint amen s. Laurentius ARCHIEPISCOPUS CANTVARIEN monachus Benedictinus feb. 2. the life of s. Laurence archbishop of Canturbury of the holy order of s. Benedict feb 2. out of bede gest ang. saint Laurence be one of those benedictin monk who pope Gregory the great send with s. augustin to preach the gospel of JESUS CHRIST to our english nation in which pious work he labour wonderful to gain soul out of the blindness of idolatry to the light of the true catholic faith he be a man of excellent learning and virtuous life and when ethelbert king of Kent and most part of his kingdom be baptize s. augustin send the holy monk Laurence and PETER to Rome to bring unto the holy pope the joyful tiding of their happy success s. Austin choose Laurence for his successor in Canturbury after his return into England when s. augustin archbishop of Canturburic perceive the time of his death to draw near lest that church as yet but raw and rude in religion be one hour destitute of a pastor shall begin to waver he ordain Laurence for his successor plain follow herein the example of the first pastor of the universal church the prince of the apostle saint PETER who in like manner institute Clement to succeed he in the primacy of the sea of Rome s. Laurence be install in the dignity of the archbishopric begin with great courage and industry to augment and promote the foundation of christian religion so noble lay and by his frequent preach exhortation and continual example of pious work he endeavour to advance they to due height of perfection neither do he only his care of all the church take the charge and care of the new church of the english but be allsoe very solicitous and careful of the ancient inhabitant of Britain not forget allsoe to be a pastoral guardian of the scot and irish. for understand the manner of life and profession of faith of the Britan and scot to be in many thing scarce ecclesiastical and chief that they do not celebrate their easter in due time but judge it to be observe between the fourteen of the moon and the twentieth he together with his fellow-bishop write unto they a epistle of exhortation desire and conjure they to keep the same unity of peace and catholic observance which be observe in the church of CHRIST over all the world of which his epistle this be the beginning his epistle to the scotish or irish bishop Laurence mellitus and justus servant of the servant of God unto our most dear brothren the bishop and abbot throughout all Scotland when the sea apostolic according to the accustom manner thereof which be to send to all part of the world direct we into these western quarter to preach the word of God unto pagan and heathen and we happen to enter this island call Britain indge before we know that all who be christian walk according to the custom of the untuersall church we honour with great reverence of sanctity as well the Britan as the scot but now have have some knowledge of the Britan error we judge better of the scot till we understand by Dagamus bishop that come into this foresay island and by columban abbot in France that the scot in their conversation do nothing from the Britain for Dagamus bishop be here refuse not only to eat with we but will not taste any meat under the same roof with we etc. in like manner s. Laurence together with his other fellow-bishop send letter worthy his call unto the priest of the Britan whereby he endeavour to reduce they to the unity of the Catholic church but all his labour profit little so obstinate and perverse they be in their foretaken opinion 2 in the mean time a most grievous tempest and perturbation arise in the church for b. ethelbert king of Kent be dead Eabald his successor utter destroy his father holy institution of a perturbation in the english chur. christianity run headlong into all manner of vice and wickedness and marry his stepmother he live in that foul fornication which the apostle so high detest in the corinthian together with he the nobleman and many of the people choose rather to offend God than not to follow the king fashion fall as the manner be from their Catholic institution into all manner of looseness and lewdness of life and religion to augment these misery about the same time Sigebert king of the east-angle be dead his son fall from the Catholic religion which in their father time they seem to approve into the flat profession of their ancient idolatry therefore in the midst of these so great difficulty the holy monk and bishop mellitus of London and Justus of Rochester meet at Canturbury to deliberate with s. Laurence what be best to be do at length they be bring to such strait that they determine rather to return into their own country there to serve God in peace and quietness then to loose their labour among these barbarous people so rebellious to the faith of CHRIST mellitus and Justus depart into France there to expect what will be the event of these the bishop fly into frace series who s. Laurence promise short to follow unless the wickedness of the time do change in the mean space he cease not to admonish and persuade the king and people with all the force of argument he can invent that they ought not so silthy to forsake such excellent precept of religion and soeunaduised fall from the great happiness already obtain but the king find the holy bishop to withstand he and his desire begin daily to have a great aversion from he and grow at length to be so malicious bend against he that Laurence intede wise to go after his brother-bishop into France 3 the night before he mean to depart he command his bed to be prepare in the very church of s. PETER and Paul where have Laurence meaning to fly be scourgedby s. PETER pour out his hearty prayer bathe in tear for the present miserable state of the church he betake himself to his rest and fall asleep during which the prince of the apostle s PETER appear unto he and have severe scourge his nacked back and shoulder with sharp stripe a good space of the night he ask he by a strict apostolical authority wherefore he will forsake the flock which he have commit to his charge and to what other pastor he will dismiss the sheep of CHRIST from which he intend to fly and leave they in the midst of wolf have thou forget my exaple say he who for the little one of JESUS-CHRIST which in testimony of his love he recommend unto i have suffer chain stripe imprisonment and affliction and at last death itself upon a cross s. Laurence with these stripe of the apostle although wound in body yet much encourage in mind go the next morning to the king and discover his back show he how cruel he be scourge and the king much amaze hereat demand who dare be so bold as to exercise such cruelty on so great and worthy King Edbald renounce idolatry a man and understand that the holy bishop have endure those cruel blow from the apostle s PETER and all for his health sake he be exceed affright and thereupon abandon all idolatry and reject his unlawful marriage he embrace the faith of CHRIST and be baptize by s. Laurence which do he call melli^us and justus out of France remain ever after constant in the Catholicque faith but s. Laurence have again settle his bishopric in good order and reduce the people of the country to the fold of CHRIST be desirous allsoe as we s. Laurence preach in Scotland have say to bring the scot and Britain to the unity of God church go into Scotland in which journey he be report to have walk like a other s. PETER over a arm of the sea on foot when the mariner that refuse to carry he ou^r be in his sight punish with fire from heaven and swallow up together with his boat in the merciless gulf of the Sea preach in a certain village and find no man that will receive either he or his doctrine but rash expel he from among they he be force that night to take a hard lodging under a hedge be expose to the injury of the wind and weather but almighty god who never forsake his servant send forth a bright shine light which encompass the holy man with such splendour that the next approach morning may well blush at the lustre of his brightsom night and the same almighty power shoot a dreadful thunderbolt into that village which have refuse to harbour his messenger whereby it be fire destroy and bury for ever in its own ruin afterward Tonanus a bishop of Jreland understand of the fame of s. Laurence and of his preach come to see he and have hear he dispute of the apostolic institution of the Catholic church and of the true observance of easter he embrace the truth and earnest endeavour to reduce his own country unto the same v. Laurence return again into Kent happen by the way to lodge in a house where his host son be new dead and he raise a dead boy to life the father and mother wonderful lament their loss desire he if he will have they believe in the faith of he he preach to restore their son to life again the holy bishop have make his prayer unto almighty God full of faith and confidence in he that promise whatsoever you shall ask in my name shall be grant unto you command the boy to rise and he arise forth with and relate how when s. Laurence pray for he he be by the hand of bright-shining angel take out of the ugly claw of the black horrid spirit and restore to his body again move with this miracle the father and mother of the boy together with all their whole household and kindred receive the faith of CHRIST and be at the same time wash in the sacred font of baptism at length this holy prelate have for the space almost of eleven year govern the sea of Canturburie continual labour in his happy death the promotion of god cause leave this world to receive the everlasting reward of his labour in a better the second day of February in the year of our lord 619. he be bury near unto s. augustin his predecessor in the benedictin abbey of Canturbury dedicate unto s. PETER and s. Paul which have be found in s. augustins time but be perfect and consecrate by s. Laurence and in the epitaph over his tomb mention be make of his scourge in this verse a long time after his death together with his fellow-bishop and saint Augustine and mellitus he appear in glory to a lame cripple who leg by the contraction of the sinew grow fast to his haunch but as he pray for help in the same church the bless saint with his own hand seem to dissolve his joint and sinew so that he sudden find himself to be perfect cure this life i have gather chief out of venerable bede geft ang. lib. 2. and JOANNES Anglicus recite by JOHN CAPGRAVE mention be make of he in the roman martirologe this day Trithemius of the famous man of s. benedict order lib. 3. cap. 59 Harpsfield 7. cap. 7. malmesbury gest angl. lib. 1. cap. 1. and gest P^ntif angl. lib. 1. and all our english historiographer do whorthy speak his praise the life of s. WEREBURG virgin and abbess of the holy order of s. Benedict feb 3. out of diverse grave onthor as a precious diamond when it be artificial and well set in a gold ring give a double lustre and grace unto the eye so the virtue of the mind which be engraft in the nobility of birth and beauty of body do shine with a far great glory and dazzle the beholder with more admiration a strong proof hereof we have in the life of the glorious virgin s. WEREBURG who by the sanctity and virtue of her good life ennoble the resplendent royalty and no blenc of her birth she be daughter unto Wulfere her royal parentage king of the mercian and s. ermenild his queen be therefore bear of a noble and holy race and in beauty excel many other of her equal she judge it a thing very unseemly to degenerate from the virtue and glory of her ancestor or that the vilence of a corrupt soul shall blemish and deform the beauteous grace of so fair a body and because she have her beginning from noble progenitor she abhor the terrene desire of the lover of this world to unite herself to the most worthy spouse of all chaste soul CHRIST JESUS unto who she betroth the pure and holy soul of her unstained body Gould gem costly apparel and whatsoever else the gorgeous pomp of this world do brag of seem unto she rather odious then glorious 2 at length the time be come when she be resolve to celebrate her spiritual spousage she go to the monastery of benedictin she take the habit of s. Benedict nun at Ely where CHRIST and his angel be witness she receive the sacred veil of virginity and range herself into the company of those holy virgin under the rule of s. Benedict and the government of etheldred her aunt they abbess of the same place from which time tread under foot the vain pride of the world she ever show herself a humble handmaid of CHRIST and by submit herself to all her other sister she overcome they all in the virtue of true humility always serve their necessity with the pious work of a boil charity not forget likewise to keep a special guard over she own action lest she shall commit any small oversight which may be displease unto her heavenly spouse for who love she have forsake the pomp of the world which mortal so much admire the whole force and power of her soul be bend only to endeavour which way she may become excellent in silence abstinence watch pious read and holy her pious exercise meditation that in a short time she go as far beyond she other companion in these and all other virtue as she excel the in the nobility of blood yet always think so humble of herself that she be ever most ready to obey they all and to undergo the base office of the house in a word all her life be such that although as other do she carry her body upon earth yet she always have her mind fix in heaven and heavenly thing 3 after she have a long time give such a pattern of virtue and religion in the monastery of Ely king Wulfere her father be she be make abbess of three nunnery dead etheldred her uncle then reign over the kingdom of Mercia send for she home into she own country and give she the government of three monastery of Benedictine nun to wit Trentam and Hindbury in Staffordsshire and wedune in Northamptonshire that with her good and pious example she may there promote the observance of heavenly and immortal life where she have first receive her mortal breath in this authority she carry herself with so great sanctity and prudence that she worthy obtain a wonderful praise and name in the world of piety wisdom and discretion for in such wise she exercise the authority of a mistress that she seem allsoe to bear the condition of a servant instruct her subject in the way of virtue more by she own example then by imperious command 4 as on a time she make some stay at her monastery of wedune near Southampton news be bring that a infinite company of wild-goose yearly accustom to make a very great spoil in the corn and other pasture belong to the monastery whereupon she command the messenger to return and bring they all before he into the pound he although he imagine the holy note a wonderful miracle virgin flout he go into the field and seek to drive those wild fowl off the corn he find that not one of that almost infinite multitude once offer to lift up his wing to fly away therefore perceave now a possibility in what he judge before impossible he begin to drive they forward when they go before he like so many sheep on a foot pace hang down their head as it be out of the confusion of their own guiltiness till he have they in the place appoint where he shut they up as close prisoner all that night never be so many wild the wild fowl obey her command creature at once under lock and key before the next morning betimes with their cackle note they begin to cry out like poor prisoner for pardon for their offence or at lest for sustenance to maintain nature alive the holy virgin who be ever of a mild disposition towards all creature command they to be set at liberty with a straight charge threaten against they never to return again into those part she have no soon speak than obedience follow for the whole troop of those goose flee away so far that never after any of the same kind once appear within the confine of that monastery v. a herdsman belong unto her monastery call Al^...thus a man of very good life be oftentimes much injure and at length in presence of the holy virgin sore beat and wound by the Baylyf of the same place all which the good man quiet bear of with the buckler of patience whilst s. WERBURG on her knee with prayer mingle with threaten cry out on he to spare the one strange punish for notobey s. Werburg poor innocent but his fury and pride swell in her humility disdain to listen to her pious entreaty but pursue his rude cruelty when by the just judgement of god he receive his punishment for Gilbert of Sempringham confessor author of the Gilbertin monk feb 4. out of Nicholas Harpsfield and other saint GILBIRT be son to joceline a worthy norman soldier his mother be a english woman who before his birth have a famous vision foreshow his greatness when in she sleep the moon seem to fall into her lap he be bear at Sempringham in Lincolnshire in his father house he be of so poor esteem that the very servant will scarce deign to eat their meat with he for in feature of body he be something rude and unhandsome be set to school and profit but poor he go into France where by his good endeavour he attain unto the degree of master in the liberal science afterward return into England his care in bring up young child he bend his whole labour pious and free to bring up child of both sex who he not only instruct in the rudiment of learning but allsoe give they exact and as it be monastical rule of good manner prescribe unto they certain time and place when to read their lesson when to talk and when to be silent always endeavour from his very youth to win soul unto CHRIST and to profit whosoever he can by word work and good example in the mean time his father who be lord of the two church Sempringham and Tyrington be much delight with the virtuous life of his son bestow both those benefice upon he which charge he perform with so great care and diligence that by his often preach and worthy example of virtue he do great incite his parishioner to follow the footstep of his piety in so much that wheresoever they go their religion and piety give a clear testimony unto what pastor and parish they belong yet there want not some one as it be ordinary in so great a multitude who nothing answer the expectation of so good a pastor have deceive he in the payment of their tithe Gilbert have find out this deceit bring a rare example of zeal the deceiver to such strait that he compel he to empty his barn again and count his corn sheff by to pay his due tithe to the uttermost this do to beget in other a detestation and horror of so great a offence he cause the ti^he so gather forthwith to be fire and consume to ash 2 he live a while in the family of Robert bioet bishop of Lincoln and Alexander his successor where much against his will he be honour with the sacred dignity of priesthood from which he be make priest time although before he have follow a very singular and pious course of life he bend his endeavour much more exact to all manner of devotion and chief to the work of charity and give of alm be always so far from all thought of ambition that he utter refuse to accept a worthy archdeaconship of the church of Lincoln when it be earnest offer and almost force upon he re^useth a archdeaconship he he have a singular inclination and as it be a natural disposition of mind to help all poor people but he chief excel in succour the female sex of which he make choice of seven maid to who he may more peculiar show his charitable liberality these he cause to vow perpetual chastity and have before hand have the cowsell and authority of Alexander bishop of he institute a religio^^ o^ (@) Lincoln he enclose they in such sort that no man can have any access unto they be only a window leave open by which they receive their provision of victual which be serve in by some poor woman servant common call lay sister who afterward be likewise bind to the monastical rule of the house 3 these holy endeavour of s. Gilbert be worthy entertain with the great applause of the king and prince who for his furtherance therein give very large possession of land and good prince liberality towards he which he compel thereunto partly receive and partly utter reject leave the overmuch abundance of riches shall choke the first spring of his pious religion in the mean time a great company of man and woman flock together to embrace this new institution when he out of his great humility of mind indge himself unworthy to govern such a pious company make a journey to the abbey of cisterce in France where pope at that he go into France time seiourn that by his supreme authority he may get the assistance of some of the cistercian monk to undertake the charge and care of his new offspring the pope have make a curious and exact inquiry of he and his manner of life and understand that almighty God have ennoble he with many admirable work be much grieve that he have no soon notice and acquaintance with he that he may have honour he with the archiepiscopal dignity of York and now he judge no man fit than himself though very unwilling to who he may recommend the pope approve his endeavour the pious charge of nourish bring up enlarge and govern of his young flock in this place he fall into the acquaintance of the famous archbishop of Jreland s. Gilbert their author call gilbertine 4 as he excel all of his monastery in authority and dignity his exact obseruace and strict manner of life so likewise go he far beyond they in strictness of life and the exact observance of monastical discipline no man more spare in his diet for he always abstayned from flesh unless some great sickness force he to the contrary and in lend and advent from fish also content himself only with herb root and such like as his great dainty in which as in all other meat he be so spare that it be a wonder to the world how he can keep alive in so great abstinence when he notwithstanding all this severity be wont often time to complain of eat overmuch one pious custom he ever observe which be to have a certain vessel or platter set on the table in time of habit time himself remain in his secular apparel and not oblige by any vow unto that profession of a monastical life which he prescribe unto other lest perchance his successor may take example thereby ELFLED virgin and abbess of the holy order of s. Benedict feb 8. take out of venerable bede saint ELFLED be daughter unto Oswy king of the Northumber who after many cruel invasion of the merciless Penda be force to sue unto he for peace with proffer of infinite treasure and very rich jewel all which the barbarous tyrant reject pursue his deadly enterprise protest utter to extinguish he and his country king Oswy humane mean fail he have recourse unto a high power make a sacred vow unto the almighty god of army that he will consecrate his daughter ELFLED to the profession of perpetual chastity and give twelve v^wes of chastity please unto God farm with the land thereunto belong to the erection and foundation of monastery if by his divine assistance and to his great honour he shall overthrow the insolent pride of his barbarous enemy this say with a heart full of confidence he prepare himself and his small army for the battle the number of his adversary be report to have redouble thirty time his all well repoynt and old try soldier against who bold march king Oswy with his son Al^frid the battle be fight be the river Junet which at that time overflow his bank so that the victory fall with Oswy more by flight be drown in the water then king Oswy victorious over slay with the sword and herein proud Penda pay death his due with the overthrow of all his Mercian power this noble victory be by god holy assistance so noble or rather miraculous win king Oswy give infinite thanks unto almighty God and for performance of his vow make he deliver his daughter ELFLED as yet scarce a year old to be bring up in a monastery of Benedictine nun call Heretheu under the pious conduct of s. HILDA and withal he give the land of one hundred and twenty family for the building and maintain of monastery but two year afterward s. HILDA purchase the possession of ten Elfled take the habit of s. Benedict family and build the monastery of Streanshall where ELFLED be come to age first receive the habit of s. benedict order and have be long train up in this holy school of virtue in the continual exercise of monastical discipline she afterward succeed s. HILDA be for her holy life choose abbess of that place and become a mistress of virtue unto the whole convent govern her virgin subject in the joy of virginity with the care of a motherly piety and invite they to the true observance of religion by the virtuous and pious example of her own life 2 whilst thus she ennoble the nobility of her stock with the great nobility of virtue she fall into a grievous sickness that make she almost taste the bitterness of death pang and when the skill of physic can nothing avail she sudde by the grace of the she fall sick divine physician she be take out of the gate of death and free from all her inward pain yet still remain in so great weakness of her limb that she can neither stand nor go but be force to creep on all four in so much that with sorrow she begin to fear a perpetual lament have long since despair of the physician help till one day sit pensive in the anguish of her sorrowful thought the great sainctity of s. Cuthbert who she love dear come into her mind and present she wish to have something from he firm believe and trust thereby to receive perfect health not long after there come one which she recover by miracle bring she a linen girdle send from s. Cuthbert she great rejoice with that present and understand that her desire be make know by divine revelation unto the holy man gird herself with the same girdle and one the morrow after she become able to stand on her foot and the three day she be restore to perfect health to the great admiration of all within a short time after be desirous to communicate to other the great blessing bestow upon herself she apply the same girdle unto one of her nun that be almost dead with a insufferable pain which daily increase more and more in her head but no soon have this holy virgin of CHRIST bind she about the temple with that girdle but the pain cease and perfect health succeed afterward b. s. Cuthbert before I go to mass thou will tell i his name she send to know and on the morrow as the bishop be dedicate the church she come run mass for the dead to he in a womanish amazement as if she have bring some great news I desire you my lord say she to be mindful in your mass of Hadwald thas be his name who die fall from a tree as he be cut wood 3 when this most noble and holy virgin of CHRIST ellf have for many year rule her monastery in great sanctity and preserve the sacred treasure of her virginity from her tender infancy to the age of threescore year she deliver up her pure soul to the most happy and long desire marriage of her heavenly spouse about the year of our lord 714. she be bury in the church of the same monastery dedicate to s. THELIAN bishop and confessor feb 9 out of a ancient author saint THELIAN a ancient Britan bear of noble parent ' much more ennoble his stock by the splendour of his virtue he be scholar unto Dubricius bishop of Landaff under who holy care he attain unto that height of wisdom and learning that as yet he be call (@) and way but a youth he obtain the name of helios which in greek signify the sun for his sacred doctrine shine like the sun and disperse the darkness of sin and infidelity lighten the heart of the faithful people of his country with the sacred beam of true religion and virtue but hear the fame of a prudent and holy man call paulin he go unto he and confer with he concern the more secret and abstruse place of the holy scripture where he enter into acquintaince with great s. DAVID bishop of his love to s. David between who the grace of the holy ghost tie so strict a knot of true love and friendship that they be esteem in those day as a noble pair of friend of one mind and soul but while they live together in a delightful and mutual accord of sanctity certain barbarous people who either from their paint garment as from some mark in their eye be call pict land with a great navy upon the coast of Britanny and be take with a love of the country set upon the Britain more by deceit then force and for a time bear a tyrannous sway among they one of their prince murder the country before he and burn church and house at he go arrive at length near unto where he build himself a palace and perceave envy plot mischief against he the life of s. DAVID and THELIAN to be so holy and so contrary to his proceed he great envy they and spit much of his venom in opprobrious and reproachful speech against they who he can not just condemn of any fault and at length to make his malice bring forth the child of wickedness he command his wife to send her maid and make they the instrument of mischief by their lewd art and lascivious allurement and motion of their naked body to attempt the overthrow of the holy man good purpose but as those wanton thing follow their mistress a just punishment of malice direction and in the dishonest execution thereof exercise a kind of feign frenzy or madness in presence of the saint sudden they become mad indeed and return to their commander without sufficient discourse to relate their own misfortune which be see of that cruel persecutor turn all his fury into meekness and both he and his whole family receive the faith of CHRIST and be wash in the sacred font of baptism 2 not long after s. THELIAN together with s. DAVID make a he go to Jerusalem journey to Jerusalem where they spend some time in continual prayer and visitation of the sacred place wherein our dear saviour wrought the miracle of his bitter passion and our dear redemption in those place they be wrap in holy contemplatlon that they have no memory or thought of any thing that be in this world unto s. THELIAN as he return home they give a cymbal of more worth than greatness and more precious than it be fair for the sweet tune thereof seem to excel the sound of a organ it ring at every hour of its own accord and this be a true figure of s. THELIAN who like unto a cymbal or bell which raise man from the dullness of sleep and sloth to praise and serve God in the church do he by his virtue and holy sermon stir up by his prayer he expel the plague the heart of the people unto God out of the dungeon of sin and wickedness be return prosperous into Wales by his prayer unto almighty God he free the people from a cruel plague which miserable waste and devour the country afterward succeed in the bishopric of Landaff in that sacred dignity he spend the whole remnant of his life govern his diocese rather with his sanctity and example of good life then by the exercise of his poewr and authority at length load with merit and old age by the happy loss of this fade world he purchase a everlasting dwell in heaven the nine day of February about the year of our lord 563. the many church in south Wales dedicate to s. THELIAN which to this day retain his memory by the many church dedicate to his name name of Llanthilo or Llanthilio be unresistable witness and proof of his great sanctity and as yet his praise be fresh in the mouth of all faithful whelchman although the great part of that wretched nation do live in such blindness that they will rather pluck he out of heaven then do he or any other of God saint any honour at all contemn herein the counsel of the kingly prophet who invite we to praise God in his saint with psal 150. five 1. who he live for ever amen thus much of this saint life we have gather out of JOANNES Anglicus recite by JOHN CAPGRAVE in his legend and Nicolas HARPSFIELD saec. 6. cap. 27. the life of s. TRUMWINE bishop and confessor of the holy order of s. Benedict feb 11. out of venerable bede gest an. lib. 4. trumwine a man of very holy life be by Theodore archbishop of Canturbury ordain bishop of the pict then subject to the english but after the overthrow and death of Egfrid king of the Northumber cause by the same pict s. trumwine together with many other monk of the monastery of Ebbercune in the confine of the pict and english retire himself out of that province and have recommend the great part of his monk to diverse monastery according as he be able he himself choose his habitation at the monastery of Streanshall where under the holy rule of s. Benedict with a few of his companion-monk he lead a most strict monastical life profitable not only to himself as tend to the height of perfection but to many other allsoe the princely virgin s. ELFLED of who the eight of this month be the abbess of that monastery who by the come of this holy bishop receive great help in her regency and much comfort for the direct of her own life in the way of piety the place where the bishop with his monk live be separate from the monastery of enclose nun but not so far but that they be ready in all occasion to help they with the sacrament and all other spiritual comfort of their priestly function and dignity the most holy bishop trumwine hist l. 4. c. 2d as venerable bede style he have live there in great holiness of life the space of many year at length yield up his bless soul to make one in the glorious quire of benedictin bishop in heaven his body be bury in the church of s. Benedict feb 10. take out of we nerable bede as the divine gift of tongue wisdom learning and such like wherewith it please allmigtie God to furnish his holy apostle and adorn the primitive church have not be want in late age so have they not fail in the time when our Englishmen first receive the Catholic faith a abundant and worthy example hereof we may behold in this holy benedictin monk CEDMON he become learn by miracle who out of the rudeness of ignorance and mere simplicity in matter of learning by the special grace of God become so notable and so religious a poet in his mother tongue that whatsoever he can learn out of the holy scripture by the help of interpreter he will present turn into verse with such a sweet and move strain that by the force thereof many be oftentimes incite to contemn the world be thereby inflame with a pious desire of a heavenly and everlasting life many other there be among the english which assay to imitate his holy poetry but no man be comparable unto he for he learn not this art by any man help but receive it gratis by the special gift and grace of the divine goodness whence it be that he can not make any frivolous or vanie poem but such thing only which belong unto piety and religion can become his religious and godly tongue he receive this divine gui^t upon this occasion 2 while he live a secular man in the world which be till he be well strike in year and be servant to the monastery of Benedictine nun of s. HILDA have never before learn any thing touch either verse or fing he chance to be in a banquet where for their great merriment and recreation it be agree upon by the whole company that every one shall sing a song in his course but CEDMON when FEB. 12. he see the harp come near he be guilty of his own ignorance in that quality arise from the table and go home to his own house the like he have practise diverse time till once it fall out that go out of the company upon the same occasion he go into the stable to take care of the cattle which that night be commit to his charge where when the time of the night compel he to give his body to sleep he behold as it be in a dream a man stand by he that salute he and call he by his name say CEDMON I pray thou sing i a song I can sing answer be and he enjoy a strange vision for that cause I forsake my company and come hither because I can not sing but yet reply the other thou have somewhat to sing unto i what say he must I sing the beginning of all creature answer the other at which word present in praise of God the creator of the word he begin to sing verse which he never have hear before whereof this be the sense now must we praise the author of the heavenly kingdom the power of our creator his counsel and wisdom and the work of the father of glory how he bring God (@) be the author of all miracle who first create heaven to the child of man for the top of their dwell and next the almighty guardian of he have the art of sing and ver^isying by revelation mankind make the earth for the floor thereof at his rise he perfect remember whatsoever he have soug in his sleep whereunto he add afterward many excellent verse more of the same matter and come in the morning to the bailiff of the monastery who be his master he reveal unto he the great gift he have receive and be bring to the presence of the bless abbess s HILDA he be command to relate his dream unto many learned man that be present and to repeat his verse that by the general judgement of they all it may be try and examine what it be and whence that which he report do proceed which do it seem unto they all to be most certain that the divine goodness have bestow some heavenly grace and gift upon he and for better trial thereof they expound unto he the process of a history out of the sacred scripture command he if he can to turn that likewise into the shape of true meet and verse he undertake the task and bring it admirable well perform against the next morning whereupon the abbess admire so great a gift in a secular man deal earnest with he to HILDA call Sthreanshall where among the other brethren he receive the habit of s. benedict order and straight by the commandment of the holy abbess he be teach the sacred story of the divine scripture which he make to run in such sweet line of meet that his master be glad in that art to become his scholar he make poem in english of the creation of the world of the of mankind and of all the other history and sacred mystery of both testament and last of the terror of the universal judgement of the horror of hell dreadful torment and of the sweetness of the never-dieing joy of heaven by which and many other his no less elegant than devout poesy he reduce many from the downfall of (@) and wickedness to the amendment of their life and the divine love of heaven 4 for he be a man very religious most free from all counterfeit his religious observance colour of vanity and with a sincere plainness and humble simplicity the chief arm of the benedictin order whole subject unto the rule of regular and monastical discipline but inflame with a pious zeal of great fervour against those that do any way seem to disobey the good order of the monastery when it come pass that the almighty ruler of life and death give he the grace to finish the course of his godly life with a end worthy so great sanctity for the hour of his death be at hand fourteen day before he be visit with a corporal disease by which although it be very moderate and gentle he foretell his neere-ensuing end and therefore the night before he depart he desire to have a bed provide he in the infirmary which be a place for such only as be in a mortal disease the brother that attend he wonder why he that seem to have no more sign of death in he shall desire such a remove obey his will although he judge it to little or no purpose be place in the infirmary when together with those that be there before the time be spend in merry discourse till after midnight CEDMON on the sudden demand if the holy sacramet the bless acramen reserve for the sick of the eucharist be within you that be so merry answer they need not so to hasten to the sacrament for death can lay hold on a heart so joyful and lusty as you yet seem to be again he instant desire to have the holy sacrament which be bring before he will receive it he humble desire pardon of all his brethren if in any thing he have offend they and impart the like courtesy unto they earnest crave it of he and then with great reverence fortifie himself with that heavenly he prepare his pious soul to enter into the happy voyage of everlasting life v. this do he ask the assistant how long it be to the hour that the monk shall rise to matin they answer that the time be not far of well then say he let we quiet expect that bless with the sign of the cross good hour and within a while when the stander by nothing suspect his death arm himself with the sign of the holy cross the only sign of our redemption and soft incline his head upon the pillow he take a sweet slumber and therewithal in great his death correspondent to his life silence and tranquillity both of mind and body he deliver up his still soul into the hand of his redeemer so that by the divine providence it come to pass that even as he serve our lord in his life time with a pure and quiet devotion of mind so leave this world he go to enjoy the clear vision of he he have serve by a peaceable and untroubled death and that elegant tongue which have sing so many sweet line and poem in praise of his creator do close up the breath of his last word to god honour and glory Benedict feb 13. gather out of diverse author saint ERMENILD be daughter to Erconbert king of Kent and s. SEXBURG his queen natural and from the womb she inherit her good mother propension to work of piety compassion and relieve of every one necessity both mother and daughter use the same bounty and charity towards all and be both queen on earth they have both the same pious desire and affection to the king and kingdom of heaven ermenild be give in mapiage unto Wulfere king of the mercian and by that mean the kingdom of Kent be happy unite to that of the mercian at that time her husband wulfere be but new baptize his people be but rude and scarce well settle in the Catholic faith but s. ERMENILD who have be train up from her infancy in true virtue piety and religion with her care and singular example of holy life her wise and prudent exhortation and many benefit liberal bestow upon they tame the obstinate heart of that rude and unlearned people and bring they under the sweet yoke of JESUS CHRIST by a mild force and a forceble mildness subdue those perverse and rebellious mind to the obedience of the Catholic church 2 such and so great be the fervour and zeal of this holy woman to the service and honour of almighty God and propagation of christian religion that she be whole careless of all other affair in respect thereof never cease until she have quite destroy idol root out all the devilish rite of idolatry and furnish her kingdom with church and priest for the comfort and salvation of her people who in the end she accustom diligent to frequent the divine service and sacrament and all other duty of christian piety and devotion and this her godly zeal be much promote by the royal power and authority of the king her husband who invite by her pious example much advance her good endeavour and do many good work himself admire to see the whole intention and mind of his wife amo^gst the turbulent broil of the world to be always so true fix on the contemplation of heaven and heavenly thing beside she do abound in charity and compassion towards the poor and all such as be in necessity and affliction in so much that never any come to she that depart without consolation and her liberal alm to relieve their want 3 at length after the death of her husband with who she have she take the habit of s. benedict order live seaventeen year and be mother of s. WEREBURG who life you may read the three of this month have hither unto overcome all other she now overcome herself for go to the monastery of benedictin nun at Ely she renounce all mortal pomp and glory for the pure love of the immortal and put on the habit of s. bemedict order under the government of her holy mother s. SEXBURG then abbess of the same place where by humility and obedience she become queen of her own passion and spend the remnant of her life in continual fast and prayer and all other austerity of a virtuous and religious life and after the death of the abbess s SEXBURG s. ERMENILD be choose in her place in which office while she discharge the duty of a very religious and virtuous matron incite her subject by her own good example to embrace the rule of true religion she be deliver out of this mortal prison and call to receive the everlasting reward of her labour in heaven the thirteen day of February about the year of our lord 685. and be bury in the same monastery where after her death it please almighty God for the honour and glory of this saint to work many miracle at her tomb whereof one be that a saxon condemn for some offence to be bind with iron chain or ring be on a time present at mass in the monastery of Elie and as he pray before the body of s. Edward well by virtue whereof many sick person to the great glory of CHRIST and his martyr receive afterward the wish benefit of their health 2 but now by the trumpet of fly fame the impious deceit of queen Alsrith be diwlge all over England the innocence of the murder king and his virtue and high desert be by the general acclamation of all extol to the sky the news arrive at length to the ear of duke Alferus who although heretofore he stand for the queen against his king and together with she have much wrong and grieve the monk in destroye many of their monastery yet now be willing to do some satisfaction for his duke Alfere prepare for his translation fault past and to show at left his faithful service unto the dead body of his master who alive he have nor honour as his duty require he determine to translate his holy relic into a more honourable place and to that end he exhort the bishop abbot and other peer of the realm as many as he can draw to his side to lay their help hand to his pious endeavour he send likewise a messenger unto the benedictin nun at Wilton in Wiltshire where holy Edith king Edward sister at that time lead a religious life earnest entreat wilfred the abbess thereof with her devout convent of virgin not to be want at the exequy of so holy a King hereupon the bishop abbott and many other meet together with great care and reverence duke alfern have gather a huge multitude of man and woman out of Dorsetshire come with great devotion to Warrham where that royal body his body be find uncorrupted be but poor bury and in presence of the company his sepulchre be open the body which have lie there for the space of three year be find to be as and whole from all corruption as if it have be bury but the same day which be perceive by the bishop and the whole multitude with one voice they sing hymn and praise unto allmigthie God who by so manifest a token have declare and bring to light the innocence and worth of his holy martyr but saint Edith his sister be no long s. Edith his sister able to contain the pious love of her brother within the limit of her virgin-breast run to his dead body and fall down on her knee clip it with her love embracement honour it with her religious kiss wash his seeming-live race with the stream of her joyful tear as one not able to be satiate with that so great glory of her glorious brother but then by the hand of some venerable and reverend man these sacred spoil be lift up and carry with great reverence and the wonderful gratulation of the clergy and people to the famous monastery of benedictin nun at Shaftesburie in Dorsetshire which king Elfred father to s. Edward great grandfather for love of his daughter Ailene who become a nun there have erect and enrich with very ample gift and possession 3 in the mean time be yet in their journey with that sacred treasure many person of both sex flock thither and among the rest two poor creature who sinew be so shrink and contract that with great difficulty they be able to creep along the ground upon their hand and thigh come to pray unto two cripple cure at his body almighty God and s. EDWARD for the recovery of their limb and draw near unto the holy bier the bearer thereof stay to give they licence to touch it and do reverence unto it when on a sudden to the great admiration of that infinity of beholder they be both restore to perfect health and receive a full cure and recovery of their long unserviceable limb great be then the joyful acclamation of the people that high extol the merit and praise of s. EDWARD till the news and noise of these miracle come to the ear of the queen his murderess who thereby touch to the heart with a sudden compunction and sorrow for her wickedness commit present mount on horseback and begin her journey towards the sacred body with intention to beg pardon for her offence but her sudden haste receive as sudden a stop by the way for her horse that at other time be behold strange miracle wont to run away with his load as swift as the wind by the beck of the divine providence stand stock still whilst her servant earnestprovoke the unwilling beast with sharp whip and threaten cry but all in vain for he seem most unsensible of both she blame her horse as be tire cause a fresh one to be provide which in like manner refuse to carry the author of so foul a murder till at length her brutish heart understand what this unusual accident may portend and therefore by the mean of a three person she perform this intend visitation which her own worthiness can not personal effect 4 the holy body be bring to Shaftsburie which be the place destine to be the sacristie of so rich a treasure it be receive by those holy virgin of CHRIST in most honourable and stately manner and reverent entomb on the north side of the high his body be eushrine at Shaftsburie altar the eighteen day of February and afterward by reason of the many miracle wrought at this holy martyr tomb that monastery be common call s. Edward and the miracle wrought there be such so great and so authentical esteem by king ethelred that in respect thereof he adorn the monastery of shaftsbury with many rich gift and possession and in the donation thereof make in the year 1001. he acknowledge God scourge of his country by the dane to have befall they for the unjust murder of king edward who together with the bishop and abbot of that time he honour with the title of bless martyr part of his relic be afterward bring to enrich the monastery of lemster in Herefordshire this history we have gather out of the author of his life in a aunciet manuscript recite by Surius Tom 3.
