VLFRICK confessor and hermit febr. 20 the worthy champion and brave follower of a monastical and solitary life s. Vlfrick be bear in a village call lenton or litton eight mile from Bristol of a mean yet a honest parentage in the same place he be breed and bring up till he come to such age and learning that he be make priest which office he exercise his manner of life in his youth for some year space have as it be think receive it in the fervour of his youth more out of a youthful levity incident to that age than any way guide by the reins of true reason for as yet be not well acquaint with the true spiritual knowledge of almighty God he be rule more by the impetuous motion of worldly pleasure and delight then by the inward inspiration of the soul whece it come to pass that he stick not to stain his priestly function by daily employ of himself in the gentleman slavery of keep hawk and dog and follow the toilsome sport those dumb beast can allow he when he have better and more befit his call be quiet busy in study and contemplation but be on a time in hot pursuit of this a poor man foretell he of his future life kind of a game he meet by chance with a man that bear the habit and countenance of a poor beggar who very humble demand for a alm a piece of new money which as yet by reason of the newness of the coin come out of the mint of Henry the first be not very common in England therefore VLFRICK answer he that he know not whether he have any of that kind or Noah look in thy purse reply the other and there thou shall find two penny halfpennie VLFRICK be amaze at this answer open his purse and find as the poor man have say he devout give he what he ask who receive his penny let he reward thou say he for who love thou give it and I in his name declare unto thou that short thou shall depart from this place where now thou live unto a other dwell and thence again to another where thou shall find a quiet habitation till after long perseverance in the service of god thou be call to enjoy the joyful society of the saint in heaven 2 VLFRICK therefore after a while live like a poor priest in he abstain from flesh the house of one William lord of the village where he be bear and have his diet daily at his table where he lay the first foundation of a new life and enter into a perpetual abstinence from flesh till at length his good purpose and devotion still increase he be great take with a earnest desire to embrace a eremitical and solitary life and to that end the foresay lord doubtless not without the particular inspiration of the holy ghost send he to a village call Hasleburrow in Dorsetshire distant eastward from Excester his austerity of life about thirty mile there in a little cell near adjoin unto the church set aside all thought savour of the world with great austerity and mortification of his body he purchase the grace and favour of JESUS CHRIST to his soul for with such a exact and severe a observance of abstinence fast and watch he mortify his body upon earth that the skin only stick unto the bone he appear unto the behoulder as the true picture not of a carnal but of a spiritual man in a human shape his dainty his poor diet and clothing meat be oaten bread and a kind of gruel or pottage make of oatmeal he never drink wine or any other drink which cause drunkenness but only on principal feast and then he will taste a little more for the solemnity of the feast than any contentment of body in watch he be so diligent and unwearied that he pass many night without any sleep neither will he ever give himself to any rest but when extreme necessity and weakness of nature compel he and then not in bed but lean his head to a wall he take a short allowance of sleep out of which present rouse himself he will much blame and chastise his body as yield unto overmuch niceness his pillow if that may be call so which he use to put under his head be make of roll or rope of hay wound up together he be content with poor simple clothing line next to the skin with a rude shirt of haircloth till after a while be grow from a freshman to be a old beat soldier of Christ instead of his haircloth he wear next unto his skin a iron coat of mail which his old lord and master understand his desire thereof have send unto he consecrate that warlike armour his mortification of body to the warrefarre of heaven to these his daily austerity he add other by night far exceed they in rigour for in the sharp cold of winter he be wont have first put of his iron coat to entire naked into a vessel of cold matter where he will remain recite psalm and hymn in praise of almighty God until he have thorough mortify and quench those dishonest fire and importune motion of the flesh which very furious and often assail his mind seek the ruin of his chastity but his breast be a firm rock of pure marble that utter deny entertainment to any such uncleanness and in all this rigour so unmerciful exercise upon himself both in discourse and behaviour he be ever humble and pleasant unto all other and although he seldom or never speak to any man but unseen and with his window shut yet his sweet speech yield the sound of a kind of heavenly harmony to the ear of his hearer the fame of his sancti^ie be discover 3 while thus the holy man exercise himself in the discipline of a rigid-devout life know only to the alseeing deity he break forth at length to the knowledge of the world like a fair morning of good health and happiness unto his country for his coat of mail hang down somewhat below his knee with the rudeness thereof hinder he to kneel at such time and so often as he desire whereof have admonish the knight his old master who be only privy to this secret he demand his counsel therein the knight will have persuade he to send it to London to be cut according to his desire but he be impatient of such delay and fear thereby to lay open a gate to vain give he a pair of shear and bid he in the name of God dispatch that work with his own hand the knight stagger in his obedience and judge it to be dotage in the holy man that set he on a task as he think quite impossible know not what to say be constant reply VLFRICK and fear nothing behold I go to recommend this business unto God in the mean time endeavour confident to finish this work the one fall to his prayer the other endeavour with iron and steel to cut iron and steel when both their labour take prosperous effect to the admiration of the one and great joy of the other for the knight note a strange miracle in his cut work seem rather to divide a piece of cloth than a piece of iron with so great facility the shear run through that steely garment but the holy man rise from his prayer before the work be finish the knight be force to hold his hand when VLFRICK come to the window where he labour and ask how he have succeed in his business well and prosperous say he hitherunto but now at thy come the shear turn edge and be at a stay be not move thereat reply the saint but with the same shear finish thy work so happy begin then resume his former confidence with the like facility he go through the rest and from that time the holy man in the strength of his own faith without any shear pull asunder the little ring of that part of his coat cut off and distribute they charitable to all that desire by virtue whereof many the parcel of his coat cure many disease disease be cure according as it be record of the chain of the holy apostle PETER and Paul and many other martyr but the knight much amaze at so great virtue sell prostrate at the holy man foot whereat great confound he lift he up conjure he not to reveal that miracle as long as he live but the fame thereof grow so famous that it can not be hide when many religious and devout person be glad to enjoy a ring of his iron coat whereby the glory and sweet odour of his sanctity be blow over all part of the kingdom 4 whilst our worthy champion of CHRIST thus noble the devil raise war against he fortify his mind with the armour of a generous virtue and show so great confidence in almighty God and such incomparable rigour in chastise and afflict his own body and beat down the dishonest rebellion thereof the common plotter and worker of all mischief to mankind great enuie such rare goodness assail he on all side with wonderful trouble rude vexation and almost mortal torment not inferior to those raise against s. HILLARION s. ATHONIE and other ancient hermit to batter and beat down the constancy of his virtuous mind and resolution once those infernal spirit appear visible in most horrid shape with violence drag he into the church and round about the pavement thereof in great fury till by the unexpected come of a most reverend virgin he be relieve out of the hand of those hellhound who she chase sudden away he understand afterward that this be a holy virgin of who he^ have make a commemoration in his mass the same day an other time the holy man be sick his ordinary enemy enter into the room where he lay and cast a terrible look upon he with a staff he have in his hand give he three great blow on the head and depart and further it please almighty God to give the devil so great power over his body that like a Benedict febr. 23 write by Gotzeline monk ethelbert king of Kent and the first of our english king that receive the christian faith be s. milburgs great grandfather father she be daughter to Merwald king of the mercian and his queen dompne^e by some call Ermenburg Milburg therefore her royal pa^^nts inherit the royal splendour of two princely kingdom Kent and Mercia as the ornament of her birth and have the prerogative of seniority among her father child be so far from glory therein that for the only dear love of almighty god her creator and the pure desire of heaven she utter contemn those honour which worldling so high admire and whole settle and tie herself with all the thought study care desire and power of her soul to find out the best and ready mean to attain to that kind of virtuous life in which be free from all broil and trouble of the vain world she may spend the short time of her mortality in the contemplation of almighty God and his heavenly gift and grace thereby to ennoble the royalty of her blood which the nobility of perfection and virtue and the better to put these her good thought and purpose in perfect execution she ^^^^ged her faith (...) litter and princely palace for a monastery her royal^ (...) irple for a hayre-cloathe her princely diadem for a little black veil and in sum instead of her worldly dowry which can not but be exceed rich and honourable she make a happy choice of JESUS-CHRIST to be the only spouse and spiritual ornament of her soul 2 all this she perform in a monastery which herself have build she become a nun of s. benedict order at Wenlock in Shrops^ir^ where at (@) hand of s. THEODORE a benedictin monk than archbishop of Canturburie she receive the veil of perpetual virginttie and be range into the order of nun of s. benedict or d^^^^d (...) o make abbess of the virgin that she have gather together in the same place and under the same rule this monastery her father and her uncle Merwald and wulfere both king of Mercia very rich adorn afterward with large and ample possession of land many precious relic of saint and diverse other great privilege and prerogative and now by reason of that holy society so worthy addict to the divine service of God and chief for s. MILBURG herself a mother worthy such a progeny or for that holy progeny worthy so good a mother that sacred place begin to represent a new kind of little paradise in which among the inhabitant be a holy contention strive who shall get the prize in the advancement of true piety chastity and humility to triumph over the vain delight fond pleasure and fade glory of the world 3 but yet s. MILBURG far excel the rest especial in all humility and demission of mind preserve herself for the spiritual union which her heavenly spouse most chaste pure and unspotted in all and through all her action and as a bright a young man take with love of she sun to the lesser planet she give light unto she other sister by the rare example of her virtue to show they the high way to perfection in this her holy course of so great virtue CHRIST be not want to his pious virgin neither do he only give she daily a great ardour of will and a fresh supply of force to further her progress in the path of virtue but allsoe honour she with famous testimony of his care and love towards she and bestow by she many excellent document to posterity among which one and not the lest be that be on a time out of her monastery in a village call stokes a young gallant son to a prince of that country be so take with her beauty that he have a vehement desire to carry she away by force and marry she and have gather a band of man together to put his wicked thought in execution he endeavour to make the holy virgin his prey but she that have intelligence hereof by revelation from her heavenly spouse present with her company betake herself to flight when the rash young man fierce than any wolf follow the pure lamb of CHRIST till come to a little shallow brook call corse through which the virgin with her company have easy wade his fury receive a stop for the water as it be displease at so bad a enterprise sudden she it miraculous preserve swell up and fill his bank with angry stream seem to threaten those passenger with destruction the young gallant much confound and astonish herewith declare by his cessing to persecute the holy virgin any further that the flame of his unchaste affection be utter quench with the sudden inundation of that cool water in like manner as the water the fowl which we call wild-goose do obey the will and commandment of s. MILBURG for when those creature the fowle^ of the air obey she make great spoil and havoc in the corn field near unto her monastery the holy virgin full of faith which as our saviour say can remove mountain command they present to be go and charge that nether they nor any other of the same kind shall ever dare to trespass those field any more to who a syf they have be capable of reason the bird forth with obey and never more endomage those place and this miracle last not only during her life but allsoe to our late age as it be record both by the testimony of the inhabitant thereabouts and many ancient writer whereby you may see how it please the divine goodness to show a miraculous favour in our England to this his bless virgin like unto that which in time past he show to s. anthonh the hermit when he give he power and command over the wild boar in the desert 4 many other wonderful work be relate of this holy virgin which the brevity of this discourse will not permit we to rehearse of which these be that she restore sight unto a blind man and life unto the dead son of a poor widow which deed as in then selue they be very great so in respect of those other benefit and grace wherein by her pious exhortation and holy example of life she restore unto many desperate person the heavenly light of the soul which they have lose and life everlasting whereof their sinful action and unworthiness have deprive they they seem to be of far less account in as much as the spiritual light and death of the soul do excel the mortal light and death of the body v now this holy spouse of JESUS CHRIST s. the exercise of religion and piety and show more excellent example of sanctity and perfection to her religious subject and inferior 4 at length this holy virgin and dear spouse of CHTIST have pass after her departure her dead body appear to many of the stander by in form of a creature already glorify and a wonderful sweet and fragrant odour issue from that holy vessel of chastity and fill the whole house moreover when her body be carry into the church that heavenly light which obey she in her life serve she likewise after her death and light all the candle in the same church without any will stick to their hand that touch it at this time a great part of her holy relic be translate to the monastery of Benedictine nun at Monheim in Germany and at both these place many rare miracle have WALBURG incessant show to her belove servant I command some of the sacred oil which flow from her body to be bring of which at a most desire draught I drink up a little bottle full devout say these word o bless virgin WALBURG for reverence of thy most belove brother s. willibald bishop who unworthy successor be I Philip a sinner make worthy intercession to our lord form according as my sin require and that I may recover out of the grief one cure with the oil that flow from her body of this my sickness to the praise of almighty God and his unspotted mother the virgin Marie this do to the great admiration of all I recover perfect out of a disease which have give the foil to all humane art of physic many other miracle of the same oil be report by the author of her life and be wrought yet in these day at Eistadt where her body lie to the great confusion of heretic the glory of God and our holy father s. OSWALDUS EPISCOPUS WIGORNIENSIS in Benedictinus feb. 28. mart. ba ... the life of s. oswald bishop of worcester confessor of the holy order of s. Benedict feb 28. write by Branonius a monk of Worcesler the glorious bishop and ornament of the benedictin family s oswald bear of a most noble english race and endow with a very rare and beautiful form of body begin from his very infancy to avoid all such childish toy and folly as be incident to that age and whole to apply himself to the sacred study and exercise of true piety and religion thereby to ennoble the nobility of his birth which the nobility of virtue s. o^o archbishop of Canturbury be his uncle a man of wonderful wisdom s. odo Archoyop of Cant^rbury his uncle and discretion of a grave behaviour a most just and upright mind and circumspect a all his action unto who oswald be commit by his parent to be train up in the school of learning good manner and virtue under this so excellent a master our worthy scholar become so good a proficient in all profane and divine learning that he be promote to a canonrie in the church of Winchester where when other not regard the institute of their order and call let loose the reins to the lewd desire of their mind he constant confine himself to the prescript rule of a canonical life so that within a short space of time he be choose Deane in which office all though as yet he be but young yet he zealous endeavour to correct the corrupt manner of the ancient and to reform their youthful mind to the exercise of a celestial rule and discipline but they grow old in their bad custom see how hurtful a bad custom be will by no mean be recall to the obedience of any good order therefore oswald despise all secular pomp and riches of this world determine to pass over into France to the benedictin monastery of Florie where the body of our holy father s. Benedict be say to rest s. odo his uncle who before he will undertake he take the habit of s. bentdict the archbishopric have receive the habit of a monk in the same place be desirous to further his pious intention herein give he letter of commendation with token to the father there of his acquaintance oswald be safe arrive into the port of his desire put on the habit of s. Benedict among those french monk and present he that come thither to be instruct behave and fashion himself in such sort that other who think themselves his master may in he read a lesson for their own instruction his virtue and find many example of virtue worthy their imitation for he be a man of great mortification of a little sleep spare in his diet wise and moderate in his speech and continual in his prayer but how rare he be endue with patience humility curresie humanity meekness and other virtue we may easy guess out of the sincerity of his burn charity wherein it be beyond the force of weak word to express how high he excel 2 the abbot grant he the privilege of a secret place in the church where with more freedom and familiarity he may apply his mind to the divine service of allmigtie God in which place the devil enni his study of virtue be remove from the noise and disquiet of other he bend all the endeavour and power of his soul to prayer meditation and contemplation of divine and heavenly mystery which his pious exercise serve as bellows to blow the coal of the devil envy and hatred against he for as the holy man be one night earnest bend oswald vaquish^h his diabolical practice with the sign of the cross to his prayer and meditation the wicked spirit raise the most horrid noise and cry that humane ear ever hear intend thereby either to make he desist from his holy enterprise or at least to perform it more slothful or never more to attempt the practice of any such devotion but he be deceive in all for oswald keep fast his foot under the approve protection and bucklar of a firm and constant faith be no more terrify with the roar of lion the hiss of serpent and the horrid cry and howl of other beast which that wicked author of mischief do fain then if he have hear the silly bleat of so many innocent lamb or sheep and therefore he contemn and scorn all those ugly cry together with the diabolical author of they the devil confound hereat sudden vanish away and straight appear unto he transform into the shape of a angel of light when he that know a good angel will not be trouble at the sign of the holy cross present arm himself therewith which the wicked tempter no soon perceive butihe be tray himself to be a messenger of darkness vanish out of his sight like a puff of smoke and he remain free ever after from his hellish practice 3 near unto his private oratory be a place where twelve poor man receive their daily sustenance from the monastery one of which daily assist s. oswald at the dreadful sacrifice of mass it happen one day that as the holy man be past the gospel lift up his eye to heaven in his prayer his servant see a person of a very reverend countenance hold with great reverence a little piece of white bread in his hand lift over his head the poor man although wonderful terrify with this vision yet he stand stiff to it and will not offer to run away but perceave the same bread to increase more and more as the priest go forward in his mass and at length to become of a unaccustomed bigness he dare stay no long but flee out of the church with all the have he can therefore s. oswald the priest remain alone with the angel on his right hand that seem to assist he in the mean time the poor man will ever now and then tremble peep in at the church door to hearken and espy what be do about the altar and when the seruanr of God as the manner be pronounce and other such like he hear the angel answer he distinct to every thing and see he very officious wait upon he mass be end his fugitive servant return and perceave the angel to be go he run quake to s. oswald and relate the cause of his run away inquire of he if he likewise have see the Angel true say he I both see and hear what thou do rehearse all mighty god name be for ever bless who do not forsake i be destitute of help in his holy sacrifice and I strict command thou never to reveal this vision while I live 4 saint odo archbishop of Canturburie hear the fame of s. oswalds holy conversation and manner of life give infinite thanks unto the author of all goodness and with many gift send to the monastery show and declare himself in name of his nephew very grateful and thankful both to the abbott and monk thereof withal fignify unto they that he great desire to enjoy his presence in England as well for that now be tire with old age he suppose his death to be near at hand as allsoe for that he be determine by his mean to order and train up those of his own country in regular and monastical discipline this Dunstan with his praise and commendation of oswald bring he into great grace and familiarity with noble king Edgar who cause Dunstan to advance he to the episcopal sea of Worcester in this sacred dignity he behave himself worthy both for the benefit of the english church and restore William Malm. gest ang. cap. 7. of monastical disc pline which by the barbarous incursion of the dane and the lascivious fury of late king Edwy who total favour the vice of the secular clergy be much impair and first in the village of westberie he gather a little convent of twelve benedictin monk who he use very often time to visit and comfort with his pious exhortation and together with they to labour himself in the pious exercise of a retire life in watch fast and prayer afterward he build the Benedictine abbey of Ramsey among the fen of Huntingtonshire which flourish from that time to the unfortunate age of Henry the eight it be first found upon this occasion 6 count Ailwin a near kinsman to king Edgar have for many record of Ramsey year endure the cruel torment of the gout when a certain fisherman of his call vulget enter with his boat into the water of Ramesmere so the place be call endeavour to take some fish for his master but have labour a long while in vain at length much weary he fall asleep when our holy father s. Benedict appear unto he with these word at the rise of the morning say he cast thy net into the water and according to thy desire thou shall take great store of fish of which take the great call a pike the vision of a fisherman and present it to Alwin thy master in my name bid he that he receive my gift courteous and out of hand build a monastery for monk in this island to the honour of the most holy mother of God i and all the holy virgin and let he observe where his cattle rest by night and in the very place where he shall see the bull as he rise beat the ground with his right foot let he erect a altar but that he may give more credit to these my command behold I will bend thy finger crooked which he be free from the gout that so vehement afflict he shall present restore to place again the fisherman awake cast forth his net into the deep and draw out great store of fish he present the fair to the count rehearse at large what he have see and what be give he in charge to say entreat he withal to make good his crooked finger the count be heal of his gout straighten count Alwin cure of the gout his finger and go in all haste to the island where he behold the bull rise out of the midst of the other beast that in their lie make the form of a cross beat the earth with his foot whereupon give credit to the fishermans relation he give thanks unto almighty God and erect a chapel out of hand in the same place where not long after Alwin give very ample possession thereunto s. oswald within the compass of five year erect a goodly monastery for benedictin monk and in the year of our lord 974. he dedicate the church with great solemnity to the honour of the b. virgin Marie and the great patriarch of monk s. Benedict and make a monk of his call Ednoth the first abbot thereof the abbot of this monastery in time past be baron of the realm and parliament man 97^ a council in England against the incontinency of the secular clergy Matthew westm Baronius and osbern in vit. dunst. 7 about the same time the worthy prelate of Canturbury and mirror of the Benedictine order s. AIDO or Aidus Abbot and confessor feb 28. out of a ancient author recite by John cap grave AIDO bear in the province of Conaght in Jreland and give to his barren parent by the special favour of almighty God when he come to such age that he be able to make choice of a course of life he depart to the province of leinster where he lead a solitary life in all manner of virtue and holiness afterward he come into Wales where live under the discipline of great s. David he daily show many strange example of miraculous work and virtue in so much that during the time of his abode there the saxon then mortal enemy to the Britan dare never presume to invade their dominion fear the power and virtue of this saint return as he be again into Ireland he build a monastery he build a monastery in Ireland wherein he become the spiritual father and teacher of very many monk who he instruct in all good learning and the monastical discipline of those time many strange and almost incredible miracle be report of this holy man which I willing omit it suffice for proof of his sanctity that he live in the continual exercise of virtue and die load with the merit of many good work as he do this twenty eight day of February at s. David in he be call Mo^dock that be irish and there his feast be celebrate with very great reverence and devotion thus much of his life I have gather out of joannes Anglicus recite by John Capgrave with who only let the truth of his relation stand for I find no other author that make mention of this saint the end of February s. SWIBERTUS EPISC. WLRDENSIS Frisia monachus ord. s. m. ba^... f. the life of s SWIBERT bishop and confessor apostle of Frizeland and Saxony monk of the holy order of s. Benedict mar. 1 write by s. mar celline priest his companion and fellow preacher in the year of our lord six hundred forty seven s. SWIBERT be bear in Northumberland of noble and princely parent count Sigebert and berta his wife before his birth his devout mother have a vision the vision of his mother as she lie in her bed wherein she behold one star in the heaven far excel all the rest in brightness who glitter beam seem to give light to the whole country and present the same star appear to fall upon the bed where she lay this be then interpret by s. AYDAN bishop of lindisfarne to be a presage of the child that she bear in her womb who as he say shall be a light unto his country and the whole church of God and in confirmation hereof at the very hour she be deliver a strange light appear at his birth a wonderful great splendour shine in the chamber who beam seem to dazzle the day light and much astonish the beholder the child be bear the same light decrease by degree and vanish in baptism he be call SWIBERT and be from his very cradle train up in the fear of God and good learning he so careful avoid all vice incident to that age and so manful embrace the hard way of virtue that he give great hope of his future greatness which cause many already to prognosticate wonder of his sanctity and to the end he may daily he embrace a monastical life proceed the better from virtue to virtue a^ the age of fifteen year he depart with the good leave of his parent to the Benedictine abbey of Bard^^^^ in Lincolne^^ire where he forsake all worldly hope and become a monk of the holy order of s. Benedict under the government of the good abbot Higbald in this virtuous school our noble youth careful endeavour to ennoble his mind with all manner of virtue in all thing behave himself with such prompt obedience humble modesty and sweet innocence of life that in short time he grow to he much love esteem admire and reverence even of the great and ancient monk in the house have live nine year in the same monastery in continual continency abstinence and the exercise of regular and monastical discipline he be advance to the sacred dignity of priesthood in the execution of which holy function he be make priest worthy correspond with his virtuous action he offer daily to almighty God a most acceptable sacrifice for in true piety and religion he be second to none adorn with the glory of all christian virtue most attentive and frequent in his prayer and most exact rigid in fast and mortify his own body in so much that he give great example of edification to his brethren and the famous report of his virtue be publish and admire throughout the country 2 whilst thus he shine in the excellency of a religious life among his other brethren as a bright sun among the rest of the planet the bishop of York have understand the incomparable Benedictine monk sometime canon praise of his virtue rejoice much thereat and send for he make he a canon of the cathedral church of s. Peter at York whereat the reader need not wonder since heretofore be have be a laudable custom much practise in the church of God for monk of s. benedict order to govern cathedral church as canon and be indeed monastical canon and of this kind s. SWIBERT be ordain one at York in which convent say the author to show that they be monk since a choir of secular canon be call a chapter and not a convent he live for the space of two year in so great austerity of life and such strict observance of monastical discipline that he seem to lead a angelical life upon s. Swibert of a benectin canon make abbot of monk earth and now be come to that height of perfection that he be fit to be propose as a mirror to all such as profess a regular life he be create abbott of the monastery of Dacore so call from the river Dacor run thereby in the mean time the venerable man s. egbert a benedictin monk of who see April the 24. wonderful zeal the gain of soul and the promulgation of Christ holy gospel his own resolution to go into those country be hinder by revelation from heaven make choice of twelve learned english monk all zealous of the Catholic cause out of diverse monastery twelve english benedictin send to preach in Germany of England and Jreland to preach the christian faith in Frizeland one and not the least of these elect preacher be our s. SWIBERT and s. MARCELINE that write his life a other they be eleven priest and one who have all happy pass the sea towards the vineyard of CHRIST allot to their holy charge they arrive at Utrecht about the year 690. and follow the same institution order and conversation of life that the apostle and disciple of CHRIST use in the primitive church no man presume to call any thing his own but all observe the rule of the monastical and religious poverty which they profess they begin with very great constancy and resolution to preach the christian faith among those barbarous people but the frison that be man of a untamed and stubborn nature stand stiff in defence of their idoatrie refuse to listen to the sacred tiding of the true gospel so that these holy preacher be threaten with death for announce the word of life be compel to depart thence have at first reap little or noeprofitt at all 3 therefore they go into a island call Fosteland where radbode the perfidious king of Friesland be beat out of his kingdom by the most Christian prince Pepin of France then remain and in this it be a place of very great and solemn resort among those pagan by reason of the superstitious idolatry use there to a god of they call foste from who the island take name the preacher of CHRIST begin to announce the holy gospel and have destroy the profane altar of those stonie-hearted god jupiter and foste they labour to convert the people to the knowledge of the only true God creator of the world where their pain be reward with the conversion but of three soul only but radbode understand hereof cause one of they Wigbert martyr call Wigbert to be cruel put to death a glory which long before he have desire and banish all the rest out of the island when they perceive the tyranny of the worldly prince to withstand their good endeavour in preach the sweet gospel of the king of heaven retire themselves to the forename worthy prince Pepin who send they to preach in the low part of Frizeland with a strict charge to all the pagan under his dominion to hear they with patience by this mean many be daily convert a church dedicate to the holy cross to the faith in so much that they procure a church to be build at Utrecht in honour of the holy cross in which they consecrate a font that such as receive the faith may have free access to be there baptize and now the harvest of our lord begin great to increase and the labourer be but few these holy man divide themselves and go by two and three together to preach in diverse part of low Germany but s. SWIBERT of who only now we treat accompany with weresrid and Marcelline come to the great village some two mile distant from vtreight call Duerstat where constant preach CHRIST crucify and prove their worship idol to be nothing but house of devil he be straight apprehend s. Swibert beat and imprison by the pagan priest who fear the utter ruin of their idolatry and be cruel beat he be cast into prison mean to put he private to death the next morning for public they dare not do it fear the french christian under the yoke of who government they be when we say the author werenfrid and I Marcelline with tear and lamentation follow he to the prison gate which s. SWIBERT perceive with a merry countenance comfort and exhort they courageous to deliver by a angel remain in the faith of CHRIST and not to fear death for his sake but the same night as he pray in that darksome lodging a bright angel appear unto he with lightsome news of comfort follow the lustre of who fair countenance like a other apostle PETER he be deliver out of that irksome jail in the very sight and view of his astonish jailor then come again to his two companious they fall all together on their knee and give humble thanks to almighty God for this great token of his love and goodness 4 the pagan and special the priest of the idol understand the manner of his stray delivery begin to stagger in their faith and call in question the power of their weak god before who s. SWIBERT preach again the next day and worthy extol the omnipotent power of JESUS-CHRIST breed a general amazement in their blind soul and convert very many to the true Catholic faith no man offer to lay hand on he which do he return again to vtrei^ght make his fellowe-brethren partaker of what have happen who with tear of joy receive he and give infinite thanks to the almighty worker of his freedom afterward he go through diverse town and village of Frizeland Holland and teisterband sound and breathe no other many convert to the faith word or accent but of Christ and his holy gospel and albeit he find many great difficulty and endure strange affliction from the fury of the infidel yet always sustain by the divine help he constant persevere in his holy enterprise of preach whereby great store of people be convert to the knowledge of the true faith he arrive at length at a village in Holland call Hagenstein where it be a principal festivity among the pagan he chance to find the people very busy employ in the worshipful exercise of their diabolical sacrifice rite and ceremony before see the constant ^eale of s Swibert their stony god and thrust himself into the midst of that barbarous press of people he cry out in the spirit of his zeal and very eager reprehend the blindness of their ignorance in worship those stock and stone for god preach unto they the true faith of CHRIST crucify who power be infinite in heaven and earth and who only it be that rule the course of the world and produce miraculous effect therein the pagan admire so great constancy and boldness in the man and be curious to make experience whether it be true that miracle can be wrought in the virtue of he who he preach flock present about he offer he a young man call Giselbert that from his birth have never see the light who if by the power of the crucify god he so high extol he can restore to perfect sight they will be content to give more ear to his doctrine otherwise he be to expect a sudden and cruel death for his hire the holy man compel by the justness of this necessity fall present on his knee and have devout pour out his humble prayer to almighty God he arise and make the sign of the holy cross on the unprofitable eye of the blind person cry out with a loud voice in the name of the true God our lord JESVE-CHRIST crucify who gospel I preach I command thou to receive thy one bear blind he cure with the sign of the cross sight and confess the power of thy creator at which word the young man open his eye find the perfect use of his desire sight to his own great comfort and the wonderful astonishment of the beholder that hear he open proclaim that there be no other god but JESUS-CHRIST who his servant SWIBERT preach v. the pagan as blind of faith as he have be of sight much many receive the christian faith amaze at the strangeness of this miracle begin to be touch to the quick with a true compunction of heart and horror of they own ignorance and first the sacrificer of the village with great store of people fall humble prostrate before s. SWIBERT to demand pardon for the wrong offer who when the b. man with many pious exhortation have confirm in the true faith the next day almost all the people of that village be gather together in the profane temple of their idol by the same holy man on believe and be cleanse from all their sin in the sacred f (...) t of baptism and their idolatrous temple be change into a christian church and consecrate afterward by s. Swibert make bishop and his other fellow and be in want of bishop to exercise more eminent authority over they to consecrate church for the divine service to give holy order and supply all other function belong to ecclesisticall affair they make choice of two willibrord that go to Rome and SWIBERT that come into England both to be advance to the episcopal dignity s. SWIBERT be consecrate bishop on s. bartholomews day by the hand of the most excellent flower of the Benedictine order WILFRIDE bishop of York who then wrongful expel from his bishopric lead a private life in the kingdom of Mercia or middle England this do our holy SWIBERT adorn with episcopal authority and fortify with the comfortable speech of s. wilfrid return again to utreight he i^ famous over the country courageous to follow on his pious enterprise adorn his new receive dignity with a new list of virtue behave himself from hence forth with great humility meekness simplicity justice and all other degree of perfection and make these virtue as it be the bait to take and win soul out of the deluge of idolatry to the secure and quiet shore of Christ church by the force of his divine learning and unwearied labour of preach which take so good effect that in diverse part of Friesland and almost all the country of teisterband the people be convert to the faith and many church raise and build on the ruin of idolatry be consecrate to the service of JESUS-CHRIST so that s. SWIBERT grow to be of great fame and estimation in all those country for his singular virtue and miracle and be a amazement to the pagan and pagan priest it please the divine goodness to glorify he more and more with wonder to the confusion of the lentils and great advancement of his church 7 for be to dedicate a church at Malsen in the county of teisterband upon the river Linghen a young gentleman call splinter andengin desire out of curiosity to see the rite and ceremony which the christian use in the dedication of church and chief to see SWIBERT their bishop of who he have hear such wonder come over the river Rhine fall by chance out of the boat and drown leave both the shore full of the fruitless lamentation and tear of his fellow and servant that doleful bewail their loss the same day about noon he be take up by certain fisher and bring as dead as a hear to Duerstat to the sorrowful house of his unconsolable parent who through the persuasion of their idolatrous priest cause he to be carry to the temple of Mars trust that he can cure the wound give by Neptune and to that end they beseech his warlike power with the god mar call upon in vain many sacrifice to restore the young man to life but all in vain which his father perceave and consider that their poor god be not wont to bestow gift of life so liberal he be persuade by some devout christian to entreat b. SWIBERT to come to his who be the likely to prove a better advocate in his behalf in that matter of life and death to he he go and fall at his foot he begin to open his misery when a flood of tear so stop the current of his discourse that in they and his sigh the whole force of his eloquence seem to consist but the holy bishop s Swib entreat to ralsea dead man refuse gather his meaning out of that doleful speech be very unwilling to undertake a matter of so great presumption till overcome with the weep rhetoric of his importunity and the prayer of Werenfride and Marcellin his fellow he go with he who a infinite multitude of people stand expect on the bank of the river Rhine when enter the village Duerstat the doleful mother of the drown youth carry beyond all degree of sorrow run to meet he and fall at his foot in the midst of the street cry out o servant of the true God help i and revive my son by the power of thy god for our god be all too weak to do it s. SWIBERT apply a salve of comfort to the deep wound of her sorrow go to the house where the dead body be lay and command his fellow-disciple to fall hearty to their prayer he also betake himself earnest to his in the midst of that weep multitude of people and tremble flamen of the pagan his prayer end he arise and put his whole confidence in our lord JESUS-CHRIST he say o thou only comforter of our sadness who do once affirm with thy sacred mouth whosoever believe joan. 14. v. 12 in i the work that I do he allsoe shall do and great than these he shall do voutchafe to show the power of thy divinity in raise this man from death to life and take he by the hand he say (@) he rayseh a dead man to life the name of our lord JESUS-CHRIST crucify I bid thou rise and live and praise thy creator at these word he that before be dead open his eye and wake as it be out of a profound sleep he arise and embrace the holy saint cry out with great sigh there be no other god in heaven and earth but JESUS-CHRIST crucify who SWIBERT preach o the wonderful life of this bless saint who prayer banish death from the body of a other and spoil hell of its prey and present all the beholder much astonish with the novelty of this great miracle high extol the divine piety with loud shout of joy and thanksgiving that daign to ennoble his servant with so miraculous a remonstrance of his goodness and the heathen priest together with the parent of the new revive youth and a great multitude of people renounce the error of idolatry believe in JESUS-CHRIST so that there be baptize 126. person beside woman and child when so great a noise and clamour be raise in 126. person convert the street by the pagan that desire to see the new revive young man that s. SWIBERT take leave of s. willibrord and all the church of vtreight and go with some other to spread the seed of the gospel in Westphalie and low Saxony where he reduce many from the madness of paganism to the sweet peace of Christ church destroy as he go all idol and erect Christian church out of their ruin and hither unto he have for his companion b. Marcellin the author of his life who now return back into Frizeland when s. Swibert go on to minimigard now call monster s Swibert cure the palsy and squinancy where preach allsoe the Cath. faith with his accustom zeal and fervour he convert many thereunto and cure a woman in the same town that have be long sick of a most cruel palsy and in memory of the fact the same woman build a chapel hard by her house in honour of s. Paul the apostle on who feast she be heal likewise he restore to health a other name adelbert that lie mortal sick of a disease call the squinancy or swell in the throat whereby he and many other be convert to the faith afterward return again to monster at the earnest request of the people of that town by the way he give sight to a blind man with the sign of the holy cross that ask alm of passenger all his miracle still increase the number of the christian flock 9 have within a short time convert many infidel in monster he go into Saxony and first at the city of Brunswick he preach and convert many in the same town there be a noble man sick of so cruel a disease in his least side that he be not able to move hand or foot of that part of his body nor have any use of his left eye his sickness have already give the note the virtue of the holy cross foil to all antidote and be of physic when s. SWIBERT with the sign of the holy cross the chief arm of our ption restore he to perfect health again which miracle cause many to forsake their idolatry and hasten to be wash in the sacred font of baptism hereupon the blind minister of those blind god be exceed incense against the holy bishop and assemble the people together go with a great troop of pagan to the chief officer of the town complain and exclaim that unless the public enemy of their god who with witchcraft and sorcery seduce the people be banish the whole town will fall from their ancient profession and perish but the officer be ally to the noble man before cure by s. SWIBERT favour he and his proceed in all thing and now persuade he to save himself from their fury by flight which he do leave one priest there to confirm the new christian in their faith and travel himself through diverse province still hold on his course of preach convert and baptise till at length the heathen together with s Swib cruel beat by the pagan their hellish minister perceave their religion to go down by the preach of this holy man run violent upon he one day as he be in his sermon and cruel beat he with staff and buffet and kick he with their fist and heel that have he not be relieve by the valour of some true heart christian he have be likely enough to have perish in that skirmish of cruelty but be deliver out of their hand he lay hide for some few day yet not cease from his holy trade of preach so that daily more and more stray sheep be bring into the secure fold of Christ church x. at the same time in a town call Welsenberch live a rich and potent man name ethelhere who before have be one of the first and forward to set upon s. SWIBERT with his staff and now for his punishment be hideous possess by the devil he deliner a possess person that daily most cruel torment he and by he all that come nigh so that they be constrain to bind he fast in chain of iron but saint SWIBERT come thither at the entreaty of his friend make the sign of the holy cross upon he and present that hellish monster be disinherit of his desire habitation whereupon it come to pass that both he and many more to the number of forty two beside woman and child demand pardon for their former injury submit themselves to the sweet yoke of Christ glospell and be baptize and now this glorious saint have for the space of many year preach CHRIST to these barbarous people wrought many miracle to confirm what he preach destroy their idol and build many church for the service of almighty God compel partly by reason of war and tumult raise in that country but chief move by divine revelation he retire himself to the city of Cullen where he be joyful entertain by the virtuous heretire^h himself to Cullen duchess plectrude wife to the christian prince Pepin who high honour and admire the venerable sanctity and virtue of s. Marceline be a eyewitness 13 a young man of Werdt call Sweder chance to dine in the company of some wicked westphalian at a Pag^ town name s (...) the whole discourse of those bacon-fed wes^phalians grow to be of the generous power of their pagan-god and the impotency of CHRIST the god of the christian which sweder who be a christian not able to endure very honest begin to rehearse in his defence the virtue and miracle which our lord have wrought and do daily work at Werdt by the merit of s. SWIBERT the pagan who head be now a little too full of the virtue and strength of their god Bacchus find sweder to be a Christian rise up in great fury against he and have with many blow lay on his back and side make he feel some part of the strength their god have give they they cut out his tongue that have be so nimble in praise the god of the christian hope thereby to get themselves crown of bay from their own god this do they return diverse strike blind for biasphemie in jovial triumph to their dinner where as in their winie conference they vomit many opprobrious blasphemy against CHRIST and his holy bishop s. SWIBERT they be sudden strike with blindness and the loaf of bread before they which they can not see be turn into so many stone whilst poor sweder the enemy of their god lay as a miserable creature in the dirty street wallow in his own blood be not able for want of a tongue to call for any help in his misery but in heart he devout pray unto s. SWIBERT for the conversion of those blasphemous heathen who now find but not see that the revengeful God of the christian have give they a remembrance of his power they begin with repentant tear to call upon s. SWIBERT for aid desire withal to have the poor christian who so rough they have handle to be bring in to demand of he pardon for their fault but no man give ear to their cry all the servant of the house run out like so many mad thing terrible amaze at such a unusual accident and the captain blasphemer of all the host blind not only in corporal sight but in mind too begin to curse both god and man this miracle publish by the clamour of that blind company draw all the neighbour and a great part of the city thither to be spectator of that miraculous tragedy at length some friend of the host take up poor sweder out of the dirt and bring he before that blind crew when it be a rare spectacle to behold seven blind man for so many they be fall down upon their knee and with blind tear crave pardon of he who themselves have make so dumb that by word of mouth he can not answer their petition but by sign and by sign he do withal persuade they by write to forsake their idolatry and use mean to go along with he to Werdt where at s. SWIBERTS be restore to sight at s. DAVID bear of the noble race of ancient brittane and uncle to famous prince Arthur be reveal unto s. PATRICK apostle of Ireland thirty year before his birth be bring up from his infancy in piety and learning he be a child of so great towardness that he far excel all his fellow in both his master be s. iltute and one pauline both famous man in virtue and learning who footstep like a good scholar be so faithful imitate by this worthy youth that he not only parallel they but in his time go far beyond they both in the discipline of divine religion and secular learning he kepp close in the study of holy his study of holy scripture scripture for the space of ten ^ before he will presume to make himself public to the world in the instruction of other when at length like a fair ship lade with the ballast of a well ground virtue and fraught with the treasure of admirable knowledge and learning he float with full sail over the world with the favourable wind of great fame and renown daily manure the sacred vineyard of our lord and sound the heart of his people with the fervent and flourish eloquence of his exhortation and sermon by which and his unmatchable piety he utter ruin dissolve he vanquish the Pelagian horesie and extinguish the rebellion of the Pelagian heresy which in those day begin to take head and clear purge all the stink dregs and corruption thereof out of the heart of that people that we may bold say he be send into this world by the particular providence of almighty God who always have care of his faithful flock to be such a pastor thereof who with his admirable and almost incredible work and miracle shall preserve and deliver his church from the diabolical infection of this pestiferous heresy 2 among other worthy scholar and follower of his learning and virtue the most famous be these saint Aidan paternus and Th^lian who endeavour as far as they be able to perfect themselves by his holy manner of life and virtue with these he travel over the country always preach and teach the people as he go he build many monastery for the habitation of such as desire to live a more retire life at the place now call Glastenburie he build a church new from the ground and come he build Glasteuburie church thence to bath he cure the infection of the water thereabouts and with his holy prayer and benediction give they a perpetual heat and make they very healthful a^d soweraigne for many disease ever after as to this present day be experience to the wonderful comfort and commodity of all England come at length with his company which be no small one to Me^e^ia in Pembrookshire he begin to build a monastery in that place far from all worldly tumult mean to make it his principal abode whilst he remain in this mortal life but the devil who from the beginning be a envious hinderer of monk and monastery stir up a wicked member of he a Tiran of that country call Baia with a Tiran plot his death his complice to put the holy man and his company to death and by the way as they go to the execution of this mischief he and his fellow be sudden shake with such cruel fever that they be not able to perform their wicked intention when in the mean time the wife of this ring leader of mischief come cry after they with news of great misery that a infectious disease be sudden fall among their cattle which kill they so fast that she fear if some aid be not get they shall quick have more empty hide than beast whereupon they resolve to return to the servant of God and humble to who (@) (@) st punish implore his assistance both for themselves and their cattle which do they obtain their desire and in recompense and acknowledgement of that benefit the Tiran give unto s. DAVID all th^t valley where the cathedral church of menenia now stand for the use of he and his fellow and successor for ever 3 but this Tirans wife can not so soon depose her malice for meaning with a devilish practice to ruin the chastity of those poor monk she send a lascivious company of naked wench to exercise all manner of uncivil embrace and wanton action in their sight which make some of their mind begin to stagger with so evident a temptation other to be a little trouble and indeed all be impatient of such a immodest injury cry out unto saint DAVID to be go out of the fight and reach of so foul a sight you know reply the holy man that the world hate we and you must know allsoe a good lesson that the people of Israel travel to the land of promise with the holy ark of covenant be resist with continual danger and battle and yet not overcome but through all their journey remain victorious over that incircumcised people which do manifest betoken the triumph we must have in these our conflict for he that seek to enjoy the promise of the heavenly paradise the true land of promise must necessary be assail but not vanquish with the battery of temptation and adversity until by the assistance of CHRIST his chief captain he shall utter have ruin and overthrow all the unclean bulwark of vice and iniquity therefore we must not be overcome with evil but overcome evil with goodness for if CHRIST he with we who dare stand against we be valiant then my dear brethren in this conflict and let not our enemy take joy in your flight 4 have thus encourage their mind he build up the monastery he build a monastery and order it with good law and rule of monastical discipline where every one live by the labour of his own hand right follow that apostical rule he that will not labour let he 2. thes c. 3 v. 10. the manner of life of the ancient monk not eat and after their labour at set hour they fall to their prayer meditation and read of holy scripture which do again they fettle to their labour never taste any food till the star appear in the sky when their ordinary diet be so far from all delight that only bread herb and pure water be the chief dainty which quench their hunger and thirst after a sleight refresh herewith they return again to their prayer then to their rest whence they be raise at the first crow of the cock and prolong their prayer until the morning when with the rise of the sun all betake themselves to their day-labour by this mean they give the world not only a worthy proof and example of all manner of virtue and continency but allsoe of liberality for although they will not take any thing give they but with much difficulty yet be they so far from want of necessary that by their own labour and toil they succour the necessity of very many poor orphan pupil widow and pilgrim in sum in their manner of live they be lively pattern of the apostolical life of those ancient father which live at Alexandria under the institution of s. gather by Surius out of ancient manuscript saint winwaloke son to fracanus cousin germane of Cotton king of the briton begin from his tender age to give great sign of his ensue virtue and good life execution he desire leave of his father to go to a holy man of that country to perfect himself in that divine school in the study of virtue and learning but his father who desire rather to see he advance to worldy preferment and honour flat deny his godly request whereupon this bless young man appeal to his almighty father in heaven earnest crave his assistance in this case and his prayer be not in vain for not long after his father be abroad in the plain field in a fair sunny day on the sudden there happen such a horrible tempest of rain hail and snow second with the roar of such dreadful thunder and flash of lightning fall thick about he that strike with the exceed terror thereof he fall flat on the ground where muse with himself what may be the reason of such a unexpected storm it come into his mind that perhaps it be a punishment send he from God above for detain his son in the tempestuous world out of the sweet haven of his divine his father give he to God service hereupon he bequeath he in his mind to almighty God at the same instant and within a week after go himself in person and present he to the charge of a holy man to be instruct according to his own desire in that good school of unite virtue and learning winwaloke profit so exceed that in a short time he become very learn in holy scripture and most devout in the service of almighty God 2 his master happen to be absent upon a time the scholar fall to sport and recreate themselves in the field whereby some misfortune one of they chance to break his leg which turn by his prayer and the sign of the cross he cure a break thigh all their mirth into morning and their play into earnest condole their fellow unhappiness but winwaloke exhort they to take courage and comfort cause the whole company to fall to their prayer for the repair of this disastrous loss and he himself hearty beseech the omnipotent worker of wonder to grant this their humble request which do he make the sign of the cross on the wound say in the name of our lord JESUS-CHRIST rise and give thanks unto almighty God and at the same instant he arise prefect cure of his wound and restore again to the use of his leg as sound as he be before it be break winwaloke earnest desire and conjure his companion to conceal the miracle in silence but the will of God be otherwise whereby it be make know and public to the world for the great honour both of he and his saint 3 he be so wonderful pitiful and compassionate on the poor his compassion to the poor that when he see they beg a alm he will sigh and weep with the grief he suffer in their misery and not have wherewithal to feed their body he will at least with the comfort of his admonition endeavour to enrich their soul in which pious exercise he daily employ some part of his time although he want not some wicked spirit who spiteful revile and reproach he for this piety say that he spend the best part of his time idle among lazy beggar but he take all their blow on the buckler of patience render sweet word for their rude exclamation and humble answer for their insult reproach and meet on a time among those poor people with one that be blind to make know that his service be grateful to God by his prayer he restore he to perfect sight 4 he grow at length so perfect in virtue and learning that with hallow oil he cure on^ sting with a serp (...) from a scholar he become a master when many be glad to put themselves into his school and under his discipline to learn the divine mystery of the holy scripture one of his scholar fall asleep in the field as he sit muse on his lesson happren to be so greivous sting by a venomous serpent that the poison disperse itself over all his body cause it to swell in a most strange manner and put he in imminent danger of death but wniwaloke gine he drink which he himself have hallow the swell be forthwith assuage the venom expel and the man perfect cure not long after he understand by revelation that it be the will of almighty God that he shall depart with some of his associate to live in a other place therefore take leave of his master he depart with eleven other not know as yet where to take up his dwell but with a firm faith and confidence in almighty God he commit himself and his company to his sacred conduct at length he arrive into a island where together with his disciple for the space of three year he lead a very retire and solitary life but find that place to be very subject to stormy and tempestuous weather and withal so barren that it be almost inhabitable he go to seek a other habitation beyond the sea whither by a divine revelation he be appoint to go and there he find a place so fit and commodious for his purpose that he settle himself and his fellow therein with intention never to stir more while he live one discomodity it have which be want of water but that his devout prayer supply for the indeficient by his prayer he obtain a fresh fountain fountain of all goodness that make water spring out of the rock for the jsraelite furnish his servant in this necessity with a abundant spring of sweet crystal stream v. in this place he begin to lead a most celestial and angelical a summary of his virtue life shine unto his scholar like a bright star of devotion virtue and perfection he be of a very venerable aspect sweet and modest in his discourse always painful and unwearied in the service of almighty God of a pure body a sincere mind a sharp wit a sound judgement and very provident and wise in his advice and counsel most firm and constant in hope and excellent perfect in charity from the twentieth year of his age to the last hour of his life he be never see to fit in the church no man ever find he either fond merry or idle give to melancholy he be mild familiar and courteous to all in body he walk on earth but his mind and soul be always fix in heaven his custom be to read over the psalter of David every day and to kneel in his prayer to God a hundred time a day and as oft by night his clothing be poor make of goate-skinne his bed hard his diet only barley bread and pottage of herb Saturdays and sunday he add thereunto some small quantity of fish and a little ch^ese in lend he eat but twice a week he never drink wine nor any other liquor he vanquish the devil with the sign of the Cros which may intoxicate the brain the devil envy so great sanctity endeavour with his hellish plot to trouble and molest his pious labour appear unto he as he pray in his oratory in the most ugly and horrid shape that master of wickedness can invet vomit out of his infernal throat many reproachful word against he when he nothing dismay thereat courageous proceed in his devotion and brandish the chief arm of life the holy cross against that black messenger of death he compel he to vanish away in confusion 5 now the excellency of his virtue begin to be so famous all over Britain that many blind lame leprous and other disease person flock unto he as to a oracle who he not only wonderful cure in body but with the sacred balm of his pious advice and counsel heal the sinful infection of their soul his fame arrive at length to the ear of a king of that country who lewdness of life do little answer the dignity of his call but come in a poor habit unto the holy man he fall prostrate at his foot humble desire his prayer for the remission of his sin the saint lift he up encourage he with a familiar exhortation to the contempt he connet a king to good life of the world and the divine love of heaven with such a lively and move discourse that the king receive wonderful great comfort thereat and return again to his palace reform his bad life ever after many other miracle be report to have be wrought by the merit of this bless saint which exceed our brevity to relate our discourse hasten now towards his death which as it can not come unto so holy man in a ill season so it can not befall he in a better time than it do for the night before his departure have have a revelation of that happy hour he make it know unto the rest of his brethren who with bitter tear witness the sorrow they conceive for the loss of so good a father and entreat he to appoint one to succeed he in the government of the monastery whereunto he willing consent and on the morrow have celebrate the mann^r of his death the holy sacrifice of mass and receive the sacred body and blood of our lord stand yet at the altar he sweet render up his bless soul into the hand of his dear redeemer without any appearance of sensual pain at all after which quiet separation his body by the hand of his brethren be reverent commit to a poor house of clay in the earth and his unspotted soul free from her terrene habitation be convey into the heavenly court of almighty God by a sacred convoy of celestial spirit he flourish about the year of our lord 459. and die the three day of march in the first week of Lent his holy relic be translate afterward to s. Benedict mar. 4. out of venerable bede gest ang. saint Owen be chief steward of the royal family of s. etheldred wife to Egfrid king of the Northumber increase so excellent in the fervour of virtue that forsake that princely service and all the pleasure and riches he enjoy in the world he put on poor apparel and go to the monastery of lest where the holy bishop s. Chad then live he bring nothing with he but a axe in his hand to show that he come not to the monastery he forsake the world to live idle as many do but to get his live by the labour of his hand which afterward by his great industry he prove for have receive the habit of a benedictin monk in the same place by how much his want of learning do disfurnish he of ability to meditate on the mystery of the holy scripture by so much the more he employ and apply his whole endeavour to serve the monastery with the labour of his hand but when the holy bishop s. Chad remove his seat to Lichfield he take this holy monk along with he and judge he worthy to be one of those eight who as we have say in his life he make his more familiar companion in that little retire place of his devotion which he build near adjoin unto the church for his more private exercise of piety there s. Owen be for reverence and respect of his devotion number a among the other brethren when the rest be earnest busy at their prayer and meditation he labour abroad in make provision of such thing as be necessary he be a man of very great merit and one who have leave the world with a pure intention and sincere desire of the eternal reward promise to such as follow the footstep of CHRIST and his apostle and therefore he his gift of revelation be esteem of almighty God to be in all thing most worthy to who he may more peculiar reveal his heavenly secret be for his sincerity most worthy to be believe in his relation for this cause the glorious vision of the angelical troop which come from heaven with their melodious tune to bring news of the neere-approching death of s. Chad be show unto this holy monk as he labour without when the holy bishop be at his prayer within this you may read in the life of s. Chad the second of March and this only testimony of alimightie god particular favour unto this holy saint may serve for a sufficient proof of his great virtue and sanctity who after the death of the holy bishop have long exercise himself in the execution of his his happy death pious vocation leave the world the second time to receive a everlasting reward in heaven for have renounce it at first and yield up his pure soul into the hand of his most dear redeemer thus much of he we have gather chief out of s. bedes-historie of England Trithemius in his three book and 118. chapter of the mar. 5. write by Joannes Anglicus recite by John Capgrave saint PIRAN bear in Jreland of a noble race for the love of God contemn the riches of the world and become a hermit in the same country lead the space of many year a very strict and rigid manner of life by which and his concontinuall preach and work of many miracle he draw diverse out of the blindness of idolatry to the true faith of CHRIST he be his virtuous life wonderful spare in his diet continual in watch and prayer and from his very childhood to the hour of his death always employ in read teach and practise the work of charity humility continency and all other virtue be make priest he omit no duty belong to that dignity feed the hungry clothing the naked instruct the ignorant restrain from vice and move to virtue at length he depart out of Jreland and come into that part of England call Cornwall where with some other in a poor little habitation he prepare himself for death the hour whereof be the manner of his death partly by a grievious sickness of which never in his life he have taste before and partly by a divine inspiration make know unto he he cause his grave to be open and enter himself into it yield up his bless soul out of that house of clay to be carry up to the never die joy of heaven in the glory of a great light and splendour that appear at the same instant he die the six of march and be bury in Cornwall in a chapel in the town of padstow which chapel remain there to this day he be report to have wrought many wonderful miracle in his life time which because they tend rather to breed a incredulous amazement in the reader then move to any work of virtue or piety we have willing omit his life be write by JOANNES Anglicus and recite by JOHN CAPGRAVE and mention be make of he in the Benedict mar. 6. take out of diverse grave author saint KYNEBURG and kyneswide daughter to wicked Penda the heathen king of the mercian inherit so little of their father impiety and be so far from follow the blind way of his paganism that contrariwise like two bright star they shine in the true profession of christian religion and virtue so that their father though ever rebellious against almighty God Kyneburg marry king alfred yet in they he furnish his heavenly kingdom with two most sacred branch of sanctity KYNEBURG to get out of the reach of his cruelty marry alfred king of the Northumber which be rather a advancement than a hindrance to she in the continual exercise of virtue and piety the poor needy and afflict have so pious a mother of she that she seem to be bear for no other end then to relieve their misery and yet do she not so excel in this one grace as if she be dead to all other virtue for there be almost no praise due unto a pious-noble woman wherein she may not just challege her part all way perform with a singular care and diligence whatsoever appertain unto God and his divine her desire of a chaste life service the fervour of her piety daily increase she become at length so ravish with the sacred love of her immortal spouse the king of heaven that she earnest desire to renounce her terrene king and kingdom thereby to bear the sweet yoke of CHRIST with more freedom and loathe all mortal embracement she aspire only to unite her soul with almighty God in the sacred link of his divine love which that with more liberty and profit she may bring to pass she never cease with her pious persuasion to solicit the king her husband until he have grant her licence to live according to her own free will the king at length honour and admire so great fervour of piety and religion in his wife as it be violent force and compel himself contrary to the inclination of his own will to forgo his power of matrimony otherwise lawful and not only give her way to follow she own desire but himself allsoe put on a constant and settle resolution and purpose to keep perpetual continency ever after therefore within a short time the king palace itself contrary to a royal resolution of chastity custom in such place be change as it be into a monastery of religion and a shop where be practise all manner of discipline of more exact virtue and piety the king and his queen live as brotheir and sister unite together in a strict union of mind then before they be of body KYNEBURG not a little glad hereat when after a while she perceive the king her husband to be sufficient confirm in this new course of piety she depart with his leave to a monastery which she have prepare for herself and other virgin where change her kind of life she make the splendour and greatness of her former estate stoop to the plainness of humility her riches to grow rich by a voluntary poverty her delight to be a ordinary slender diet and instead of the ambition train of her noble lady of honour she be accompany with a few poor virgin-nunne with who she lead a virtuous and religious life under the rule of our most holy father saint Benedict this monastery be build at a place then call Dormundcaster and afterward Chineburgcastle some two mile distant from the famous Benedictine abbey of Peterborrough 2 in the mean time her sister kyneswide as yet but young JOHN CAPGRAVE and other do northy speak his praise the life of saint Felix bishop and confessor mar. 8. out of diverse author Felix be the first bishop of the east-angle but a man of how great piety he be it appear chief in this he leave his country to preach in England one famous example that be native of and understanding how few labourer there be in so fruitful a harvest of CHRIST as England of his own accord he leave his bishopric friend kindred and riches and all other maintenance and promotion of his state to come into our country and employ his best endeavour in so pious a work who holy purpose be understand and admire by honorius archbishop of Canturbury he allot he the province of the East-Engles which have he convert the east-angle forsake the christian faith before receive be fall again into the blindness of idolatry but Felix be in effect correspondent to his name which signify happy with so great happiness discharge the province he undertake that in a short time he whole and happy reduce it from the idolatrous bondage of the devil to the sweet freedom of Christ sacred gospel he hold his episcopal sea in a town then call Dimmock but afterward from his name it be name FELIXTOWE or felstowe in which place and dignity happy Felix have discharge the part of a good pastor for the space of seventeen year continual labour with invincible patience for the advancement of Christ holy gospel load with virtue his death and good work make a most happy journey to the eternal happiness the eight day of march and be bury in the same town but his relic be after ward translate to a place call Scha^ where appear yet say malmesbury some sign of a church destroy and burn by the dane but the sacred body of this saint be seek for and find a long time after be again translate to the famous abbey of benedictin monk at Ramsey this life we have gather out of s. bede the gest lib. 2. c. 15.
