weak to comprehend the one and this poor pen far to barren to set down among so many worthy any thing worthy so worthy a subject yet on the other side because the benefit which not only the benedictin order in England but allsoe all England itself have from he receive be so infinite we can choose but strain according to our power to make some small show of acknowledgement thereof imitate those herein who in a little map or card to the great pleasure and profit of the beholder do describe the mighty compass of the whole world and here now o Rome^ do thou first acknowledge thy happiness and diligent endeavour to imitate so great a worthy many everlasting monument there be which have eternize thy name to posterity thy king thy dictatour thy consul thy emperor thy trophy yea and the empire of the world seat in thy bosom all which and all other thy monument of antiquity diverse have so large elegant learned and exact search into that there be scarce a stone a marble or a sepulchre extant within thy wall which have not be particular note mark and examine but I will not have the stick here to long I will not have thy eye and throught fix on these trophy of vanity I invite thou to behold more noble and more excellent glory of thou and omit all other thy only and chief ornament thy gregory who alone next to the two light of the world the apostle excel all the rest of thy wonder nether yet be he thou so much as we too we he be indeed not only because he shine unto as with the bright lustre of his authority and virtue as to the rest of the world but allsoe and principal because by his disciple s. augustin he bring we out of the blindness of idolatry to see the light of the truth and make we that be the son of wrath become the child of CHRIST in the unity and peace of his church thou too he be because in thou he be beget bear and breed and in thou ennoble with the sacred dignity of supreme pastor of the christian world acknowledge therefore this thy great happiness thy native and domesticque glory honour this most generous branch breed out of a noble and holy root and thou wretched England acknowledge likewise the inestimable benefit receive from this thy spiritual father and apostle look upon this bright sun that first send thou the light of truth have regard to this thy pious fosterer who first feed thou with the sweet milk of the gospel search exact into his life work and action and even therein thou shall see how far thou have swerve from that faith and religion which through his mean be first plant within thy dominion and which as at that time thou do embrace for truth so yet I hope thou be not so impudent as to deny for such if thou find then by the manner of this thy first apostle life which be ever conformable to his doctrine that the present state of thy life and religion be contrary or other wise main differ from that which first he deliver unto thou be then most assure that thou have err and go astray from thy first foundation and principle of the true religion which be not can be but one only this life be write in latin by P^ul^s Dia^^n^^ a benedictin monk above 850. year ago and for the antiquitle we have make choice of it rather than any other i. gregory bear in Rome son to gordian and Silvia descend his birth and parent from a noble race of roman senator in who nobility be adorn with religion and religion ennoble with virtue for Felix chief pastor of the same sea Apostolicque be father unto his great grandfather and a man of great virtue and integrity and in his time the glory of Christ church but yet gregory in his pious conversation and manner be a ornament to the great nobility of his birth in fine as clear afterward it appear it be not without some great presage that this name be allot he for gregorin in greek signify as much as vigilant or watchful in English his name expound and in very deed he be watchful over himself whilst exact adhere to the commandment of God he lead a virtuous and laudable life here on earth he be vigilant over the faithful people of God church when by the force of his fluent doctrine he make plain unto they the straight way to heaven from a child he be so well instruct in the liberal science that albeit at that time the study of learning flourish much in Rome yet he be judge second to none in the whole city in his age which as yet be but little and unripe there be a mind full of mature study and manlike endeavour to wit to stick to the saying of his ancient and when he hear thing worthy of notice he will not by neglect commit it to oblivion but rather commend it to the strong hold of his memory so that then with a thirsty breast he suck up strea of learning which afterward with a mellifluous voice he may utter in due season 2 in the very time of his youth when that age be wont to enter the conversation of his youth into the dangerous path of the world he begin to settle himself in devotion towards God and with all the desire of his heart to aspire to the country of everlasting life but while he deffer the grace of his conversion somewhat long and think best after he be inspire with that heavenly desire to hide it under his secular apparel and to serve the world as it be in outward show so many difficulty out of that little care of the world arise against he that now he be not detain therein only in outward show but almost in mind too as he himself affirm till as length the death he build many monastery of his parent give he free scope to dispose of himself and his affair he make that open know which before lay hide under the secrecy of his mind and that which before be only in the sight of he that see all thing he manifest now to the public view of the world for distribute all his temporal good in pious work to the end that in the state of povertic he may follow CHRIST who for our sake become poor he build six monastery in Sicily and furnish they with virtuous monk to sing the praise of almighty God the seven he erect within the wall of Rome in which afterward have gather together a great convent of monk and forsakesn the pomp of the world he himself live in regular discipline under the command and obedience of a abbot unto these monastery he allot so much yearly rend out of his own mean as may suffice each one for necessary maintenance all the rest of his temporal good house and land he shall and deal the money to the poor turn hereby by a divine inspiration all that glory and nobility which he seem to have in the world to purchase the happiness of the ever-florishing city of heaven and he that before be wont to wall through the city of Rome clothe in silk and load with glitter gem afterward cover with a poor simple weed become a poor servant to the poor 3 for have change his secular apparel he go to the he take the habit of a benedictin monk monastery and make a naked escape out of the shipwreck of the world there he begin to live in so great grace of perfection that even then in his very beginning he may be reckon in the number of the perfect so that within a while be choose by the common consent of the convent he refuse not to undertake the charge of abbott to be short he be so abstinent in his diet so vigilant in his prayer and so untired in his labour of fast that out of over much weakness in his stomach he be scarce able to subsist he sustain beside a continual sickness of body and chief he be grieve with the trouble of that disease which the phistian call in greek the cruelty whereof so torment his vital part that be take with frequent and sudden agony he seem every moment to be ready to yield up the ghost but what manner of man he be in his monastery and with how commendable a exercise he lead his life we may gather out of his own word which with weep tear he utter when he be pope his speech to Peter deacon to Peter his deacon say my wretched mind be strike with the wound of its own present necessary employment remember in what state it be in the monastery how all sleet thing than see the happiness of a religious life be subject unto it how eminent it be above thing that be toss in the world that it be accoustume to think on nothing but heavenly matter that be yet detain within this body in contemplation it surpass that inortall prison itself yea and that which be a punishment almost to all man it be in love even with death itself as be the entrance to life and the reward of labour but now by reason of this heavy pastoral charge it suffer in the affair of secular man and after so swcet a form of its own quietness it be defile with the dust of worldly business I consider therefore what i do endure i consider what i have lose and when i behold that which i have lose the burden which I undergo grow more grievous for now behold toss in the wave of a huge sea and in the ship of my mind I be dash and beat with the storm of a mighty tempest and while i call to my remembrance the tranquillity of my former life castle back my eye to what be past i sigh at the sight of the desire shore and which be yet more irksome whilst I be discontent toss in these huge wave I have scarce the happiness to see the haven which I leave thus he be wont to relate of himself not brag of his proficiency in virtue but rather bewail his deficiency which he ever fear to run into through his pastoral charge but albeit he speak in this manner of himself out of a mind full of profound humility it become we notwithstanding to believe that by reason of his pastoral dignity he lose nothing of his monastical perfection yea rather that he receive thereby a great advancement in perfection by his labour in the conversion of many than he have in time pass in the tranquillity of his own private contemplation 4 but by what mean this bless man be raise first to the office of deacon and after to the high dignity of chief bishop the ensue speech shall declare the roman bishop who then govern the church preceave Gregory to climb up by the degree of virtue he be worldly palace intermitt the purpose of his heavenly manner of life for the divine providence so ordain for his great good that diverse of the monk out of a obligation of fraternal love follow he from the monastery to the end that by their example as a ship with anchor he may be stay at the please shore of prayer and contemplation and that while he be toss with the continual blow of secular affair he may fly to their company as to the bosone of a most sure haven after the volume and wave of his worldly employment and allthought that office with the sword of his extern labour now be abstract from his monastery despoil he of his former tranquillity of life notwithstanding among they the aspiration of his daily remorse through the discourse of their earnest read do give he new courage of life therefore by the company of these he be not only fence from worldly assault but allsoe enkindle more and more to the exercise of a heavenly life then at the earnest request of those his brethren and chief of that venerable man LEANDER archbishop he writ moral upon job. of Seville who at that time be come legate to Constantinople in the cause of the visigothe he be compel to explicate the book of holy job so intricate in mystery nether have he the power to deny a work which at the request of charity brotherly love do impose upon he for the profit of many but in a course of thirty five book he thorough instruct we how the same book of job be to be understand literal how to be apply to the hide mystery of CHRIST and his church and in what sense it may be fit to every christian in particular in which work of he he discourse after such a admirable manner of virtue and vice that he seem not only to express those thing in naked word only but after a manner to demonstrate they in visible form wherefore there be no doubt but he have true attain to the perfection of the virtue themselves who effect with so much efficacy he be able to declare v whilst yet he remain in the same royal city of Constantinople he overthrow the heresy of Eutichius by the assistant grace of the Catholic truth he overthrow a new bud heresy of the state of resurrection in the very first appearance and beginning of it for indeed Eutichius bishop of the same city hold a opinion that our body in the glory of the late resurrection shall be impalpable and more subtle than either the wind or air which s. Gregory understanding he prove both by force of reason and truth and the example of our lord resurrection that this assertion be whole opposite to the doctrine of the Catholicque faith which hold that this our very body raise in the glory of the resurrection shall indeed not only be subtle by reason of its spiritual power but palpable allsoe to show the truth of the nature according to the example of our lord body of which raise from death himself say to his disciple Luc 24. v. 39 feel and see for a spirit have not flesh and bone as you see i have for the assertion of this the venerable father of our faith gregory fight with so great pain against this breed heresy and with so great instance have allsoe the help hand of the most pious emperor Tiberius Constantine he utter break in piece that opinion that no man yet be ever find that offer to revive it 5 than within a short time after the venerable Levite or deacon gregory be return back to Rome the river Tiber swell over his bank with so virtuous and holy life partly with his wholesome sermon and exhortation and partly by the miraculous cure of many disease for diverse of that country have profane their faith and religion with their the holy man traucl through that country preach and teach the way of truth and justice unto all with very great profit and fruit of his pious labour for he have so great skill in teach such a amiable confession of sin and enjoin (@) penance force in persuade and bear such a angelical majesty in his countenance that many forsake their wicked life of their own accord will reveal and confess their most secret and hide offence for they imagine nothing can lie hide from he and be confess willing undergo the work of peanance which he enjoin they for satisfaction of their sin but he be wont chief to visit those his labour in preach place and preach in those village which be seat in the rude and rugged mountain and hard to come at where by reason of the rusticity of the people and barrenness of the place they be in great want of teacher in these place which breed a horror to other man be his great delight and in these he will stay sometime a week together sometime two three yea a whole month never return to his monastery but labour with his daily preach and example of good life to reduce that rude people to the true knowledge and love of almighty God v. in the mean time the holy man begin to excel in the spirit of prophecy to foretell thing to come and to declare thing absent for be upon some important necessity of his monastery to take ship with two other monk to pass over into the land of the pist call Niduars and the fair calmness of the weather put they in hope to make a speedy return they go forth whole unfurnished of provision in victual but it fall out otherwise for they be no soon on land but there arise such a bluster and tempestuous wind that the sea move with those furious blast began-allsoe to be puff up into whole mountain of outrageous wave which hinder they quite from think how to return so that be there among the cruelty of cold and hunger for the space of some day they be almost starve to death through want of victual when the holy man be never idle but watch night and day in prayer comfort his fellow with pious discourse invite they to fall to their prayer and commit themselves into the hand and protection of almighty God he feed himself and he follow by mir^cle who doubtless will succour they in this necessity as he do the child of Israel in the desert and now say he let we go to find out what sustenance our lord have send we his servant then lead they under the bank where he have pray a little before they find three piece or portion of dolphin flesh ready cut to be boil with which they satisfy their hunger and give thanks unto almighty God for his benefit you see dear brethren say he how great a grace it be to be confident in almighty God behold he have he forell thing to come not only send food to his hungry servant but by the number of three signify how many day we must yet remain here before the tempest cease and it fall out as the holy man foretell 5 go forth one day to preach accompany only with a little boy and be both weary with their journey and destitute of any food to repair their weaken force tell i child say the holy man what courage thou have by this time see that we have nether meat nor drink to satisfy our hunger nor no place whither to retire ourselves for shelter that be it reply he which great trouble i since we have nether victual nor money to buy not friend to assist we be confident a eagle furnish he with meat my child in the goodness of almighty God answer Cuthbert and rest assure that he will never abandon those in time of necessity who give themselves faithful and with all their heart to his divine service do thou see that eagle yonder which fly in the air mark she well for by her mean our lord will send we succour in this extremity with such like discourse they hold on their journey by a river side when the eagle have take a fish lay it for they upon the bank the own half whereof the holy man cause to be leave for their divine purvey or and with the remainder he refresh himself and his companion in the next village yield most hearty thanks to the divine goodness for his benefit where he allsoe say the people with the spiritual food of the gospel 7 but as he preach in one of those village the devil the devil seek to hinder his preach a perpetual enuier of goodness fear leave he shall draw his minister out of the stench of their vice to the sweetness of piety and devotion cast a fantastical fire into a house near to the church during the time of his sermon but the holy man instruct by the divine spirit that be be but a deceit of his hellish malice warn his auditor to listen only to the word of God and not to suffer themselves to be deceive with those vain illusion but the giddy multitude terrify with the apprehension of that fantastic danger run almost all out of the church to quench those false flame which they can not do albeit they pour on true water until by the prayer of s. Cuthbert the author of those fallacy be put to be put to flight flight his vain flash vanish together with he into the air whereat the people much astonish and ashamed humble on their knee acknowledge their folly and demand pardon for that so great lightness and inconstancy nether do he only command these fantastic fire but allsoe true flame too which when a whole village can not quench with great store of cold water be by the servant stream of his tear and prayer utter extinguish and many house deliver that at once be in danger to be devour by that merciless element whereby in these two miracle he worthy imitate the virtue of two worthy ancient saint in chase away the feign fire that of our most holy father s. Benedict of who s. gregory the great report the like and in the other the act of M^ircellinus the most venerable bishop of Anchona who when the same city be all in fire by his prayer miraculous deliver it most fit therefore unto these holy man that of the prophet esay may be apply when thou shall pass esay 43. through the fire thou shall not be burn and the flame shall not burn against thou 8 but let we now see of what power this holy man be against the open fury and war of this hellish fiend Hildmer perfect unto a woman possess with the devil king egsrid have a very devout wife very much give to religious and Catholic work who one day be bufy in exercise of piety give of alm to the poor at the same instant she be sudden possess with the devil which make she roar out with such horrid cry and howl that they give sufficient testimony of the great danger she be in her husband that be well belove of s. Cuthbert post unto he in great haste and tell he into what a perilous disaster his wife be fall entreat he again and again by all the force of his affection to be mindful of she in his prayer and to send a priest to minister the venerable sacrament of the eucharist unto she who be now come to the period of her life thus he say meaning to hide her disease be ashamed to let he understand that she be possess by the devil as suppose it to be a punishment for some secret enormous crime the holy man foresee the perplexity of his soul and the torment of his wife wherefore reply he have thou conceive so bad a opinion of thy wife not only the wicked and such as have quite forsake the service of almighty God be in this life subject to the torture and rack of the devil but the innocent allsoe and such many time as be endow with great sanctity of life by the secret judgement of God be try and exercise in this world with such like torment but be of good courage I will go myself along with thou and before we be there we shall find thy wife deliver be deliver by to (@) ch his bridle out of this distress and as they draw near to the house where that poor captife lay languish sudden the wicked spirit be not able to abide the approach of the holy spirit which inhabit his virtuous soul flee away and leave the woman release out of those devilish band who rise as it be out of a deep lethargy run joyful to salute the holy man and take hold only of his bridle she be present as sound and perfect as ever which cause she to break into infinite joy and thanksgiving testifie withal that then first she be prefect cure when she touch his horse bridle 9 in these and such like work of virtue the holy man have spend many year in the monastery of Mailros his good abbot Eata send he to the monastery of lindisfarne to plant there allsoe the rule of monastical perfection and make he superior thereof for lindisfarne it be a bishopric yet the bishop and all his clergy be monk from s. AYDAN their first bishop who be a monk but s. Cuthbert be the first that reduce they to the rule and order of s. Benedict for come say s. bede in his life to the church or monastery of lindisfarne he present here form the monk of lindisfarne to s. benedict rule deliver monastical institution to the monk there both by word and work but there be some brethren in the monastery who choose rather to follow their ancient custom then obey a regular observance who he notwithstanding overcome with the modest virtue of his patience and by daily exercise convert they by little and little to a state of better purpose but dispute oftentimes in the convent of the rule which be that of s. Benedict since at that time there be no other rule extant in the latin church when he his great patience be toil with most sharp injury of those that contradict he he will rise from his seat and without any show of discontent either in mind or countenance depart and dismiss the convent for that time but on the morrow as if he have endure no resistance the day before he will repeat the same admonition to the same auditor until by little and little as we have say he have bring they to his own desire for he be a man very excellent in the virtue of patience and most invincible in endure courageous all adversity which oppose themselves against he either in soul or body and no less bear a merry countenance in all disastrous and sad mischance so that he give the world to understand that be arm with the internal consolation of the holy ghost he contemn all extern misfortune moreover he his wonderful be ch be so wonderful give to watch and prayer that sometime for three or four night together he take no sleep at all and if perchance as man nature be sleep forceble seize upon he he be wont to shake off both it and tediousness in his prolix prayer either with manual labour or go about the island diligent search how all thing be carry and manage and when some other of his brethren do complain and take it very grievous if any one chance to awake the out of their mightly or noon sleep he contrariwise be wont to say that such a one call upon he be far more grateful than troublesome for he be cause say he that shake of sluggishness I settle myself to some rare example of goodness good work or meditation he be so exceed give to compunction of heart and so ardent inflame with heavenly desire that he never celebrate the holy solemnity of mass but with a abundant shed of tear worthy imitate thereby the mystery he have in hand when offer up the sacrifice of our lord bitter passion he allsoe sacrifice himself to God by inward contrition of his devout soul he be fervent and severe in the zeal of justice to correct sinner but very mild in pardon the penitent in so much that many time hear the confession of sinner he himself pity their pittisull estate will burst out into tear show the sinner what he ought to do by his own example with these and such other spiritual exercise this venerable man engraft in the heart of good man a singular affection to imitate his virtue and recall those that be stubborn and rebellious to a regular life out of the obstinate opinion of their error x. after he have spend some year in that monastery he he embrace a solitary life obtain leave of his abbot and brethren to betake himself to the sweet loneliness of a long desire solitude rejoice that from the exercise of a active life he be think worthy to ascend to the leisure of divine contemplation he depart therefore into the island so infamous by the habitation and infection of devilish spirit that none dare ever before dwell there alone but this ice our holy Cuthbert break when like a worthy champion arm with the helmet of health the bucklar of faith and the sword of the spirit which be the word of God he oppose himself against that hellish crew and dissipate dissolve and put to flight all their infernal troop and this champion of CHRIST have subdue the force of these black Tirans and now make monarch of that little land he build a city befit his empire and house therein agree unto it which be a little poor cottage with mud wall make of turf and cover with straw and in that earthen lodge this holy domesticque he obtain a foutaine by his prayer lead a heavenly and angelical life but his habitation be destitute of water follow a other miracle of our great father s. Benedict he obtain by his prayer to almighty God to have a sweet crystal fountain spring out of the hard rock with which and a little bread which be sometime bestow upon he he satisfy his thirst and hunger in this place be visit by his brethren he will go out of his cell to meet they and wash their foot with warm water and sometime be compel thereunto he will permit they to wash his foot for so far he have turn his mind from the deck of his body to labour in the adorn of his soul that sometime for a whole month together nay for the space of a year he do not once put off his shoe whence it be that through his continual pray and kneel a great thickness of hard skin be grow over his foot then his desire of perfection his extreme solitariness daily increase he shut himself close prisoner in his house of clay lead a most solitary life in continual watch fast and prayer admit very few to talk with he and that but through a window and upon some important necessity he live by the labour of his hand dig and till the earth and sow it first with wheat which his brethren bring he but that his weak land will not bring to good therefore he sow it with barley which increase in great abundance when the bird that in great troop seek to devour his li^le harvest be force at his only command to depart the bird o^ the air obey his command and never more touch his corn the like he command and be obey by the crow and daw which labour to tear off the thatch of his humble building but one of they return again to the holy man lamentable spread her wing abroad bow down her head and make a pitiful noise seem by all sign possible to entreat pardon which the holy man understanding give her leave to return as present she do bring a mate with she and for a present to the saint the one half of a hog grease which the holy man the sea and element serve he be wont afterward to show oftentimes to the monk his brethren and give they part of it to liquor their shoe or boot see here again the spirit of his great master s. Benedict in the obedience and service of the crow but not only the creature of the air water and earth but the very element themselves obey he yea and the untuly wave of the sea do serve he when they cast upon land a piece of timber just of the length he desire with which his brethren contrary to promise have forget to furnish he before and be now much abash to see a insensible element more careful to serve he than they whilst thus he live in his solitary course many out of all part of England draw thither with the fame of his virtue come to visit he whence none ever return but very well satisfy comfort and deliver from what anguish or trouble soever either of mind or body unto s. ELFLED abbess he foretell the time of king Egfrid her brother death and who shall be his successor with many other particularity all which true fall out afterward 11 but a council be hold at Adtwiford under s. THEODORE archbishop of Canturbury in the presence of king Egfrid by the common present and desire of all CYTHBERT be choose bishop of Lindisfarne who be by many letter and legate send from the king and he refusoth a bishopric council call to the synod and to receive that charge he will not stir a foot so unworthy he that be most worthy judge himself of that dignity at length good king Egfrid himself together with the most holy bishop trumwine and many other religious and noble person go over into the island and fall all upon their knee before the holy man with weep tear and humble entreaty they beseech he and conjure he by the name of our lord not to resist the wish and desire of so many and to oppose himself to the common good of the church nether do they cease until Cuthbert he be compel to take it as full of tear and sorrow as a honest heart can be suffer himself to be draw out of his belove cell of solitariness and bring into the council where be vehement urge of all he be compel much against his will to yield to their desire 12 the easter follow he be consecrate bish of lindisfarne in presence of the king bless Theodore of Canturbury and 7. other bishop at York in which office he so worthy discharge himself that he omit nothing of those duty which be wont or aught s. Cuthbert make bishop of York to be perform of the perfect and holy prelate of the church protect his flock with his daily prayer feed it with his virtuous and piousad monition and which best become all teacher make his own example and outward manner of conversation the perfect rule of what he teach and of his internal virtue and perfection the sign and miracle which he wrought as he travel over many miracle his diocese preach teach and confirm his people give sufficiet testimony one Baldhelm a servant of one of king egsrids noble man and the wife of a great count drink only of the water hallow by his prayer be both sudden and perfect cure of most grievous and mortal disease when all man quite despair of their health an other holy virgin who a long time have lie languish of a grievous pain in her head and side be anoint with holy oil hallow by s. happiness three week together he be continual afflict with sickness upon a wednsday he fall first into his disease and upon a wednsday he die but what sore grievance he endure all this time as well by torment with a extremity of thirst he have nothing wherewith to refresh himself and quench it but one poor onion of which in those five day space he have scarce consume the one half then he desire his Benedict mar. 23. saint EDILWALD be first a monk of s. benedict order in the monastery of Rippon where have receive the dignity of priesthood he adorn the same with a pious conversation of life well become his degree and calling but afterward be take with the desire of a more solitary and retire life he go to the hermitage of the island of Farne which saint Cuthbert have first build and inhabit and there become saint cuthberts immediate successor as well in habitation as holiness of life of who virtuous life that it may the better appear to the world of how great meritt it be I will only rehearse one miracle out of saint bede Gudfrid a venerble priest and afterward abbott of the benedictin monastery of lindisfarne desire to have some conversation with saint EDILWALD go by his prayer he assuage a tempett over into the island whence much refresh and comfort with his godly discourse he return with his companion homeward but be at the sea their fair calm be sudden change into such a bluster storm what with the force of the wind and the rage of the water struggle together that indeed their incuitable ruin as they think seem to be the wager of the other contention till be come to the point of despair to have any long time of life in this world behold b. EDILWALD hear the tempestuous noise of this storm and solicitous of their safety come run in all haste out of his cell to see what be befall they and find in what imminent danger and despair they be he fall present to his prayer for their life and safeguard which do the swell sea be appease and the cruelty of that tempest give way to their ship to pass quiet till they be all safe on the dry shore and then the wind and sea as if they have gather new courage begin to raise the same storm again which furious dure all that day to the end we may more plain understand that the small intermission wherein they escape be grant from heaven for their sake by the prayer of the holy man and this story be relate to i say saint bede who write it by one of those monk that be in the same ship and danger other miracle be wrought by the merit of this saint who when he have live in great holiness for the space of twelve year in this solitary kind of life he be call to the joy of heaven to receive the desire reward of his merit and labour he be bury in saint Peter church of lindisfarne by saint Cuthbert thus much out of saint bede hist. a^ l. 5. c. 1. and Nicholas harpsfy hist. eccl. saec. 7. c. 35. he flourish in the reign of Alfrid who succeed to Egfrid in the kingdom of Northumberland the life of s. RICHARD of bless and never die memory be a Englishman bear of honest parent in worcester-shire at a village which from the salt-pitt thereabouts be call the wiche s Richard parent etc country his father name be Richard too and his mother Alice it be not without some presage of his future excellency that he be bear in a town of salt for indeed he season the whole country with the salt of his wisdom learning and holy life from his tender year contrary to the custom of that age he so far abandon dance his happy wit play and other such vanity that his other fellow and equal in year can by no allurement nor persuasion draw he thereunto on the other side within a short time he far excel all his rival both in learning integrity of life and good manner his elder brother during the time of his nonage be keep in ward and by that mean he come to his land in great poverty and want who case richard much pity and have not any thing wherewith to comfort and succour he in that necessity he he serve his brother give himself whole into his service in which he spend no small time in great poverty and abjection and with no less patience humility and modesty toil and sweat now at the plough now at the cart and other such hard employment and labour of husbandry whereby he win to himself so great good will and affection from his brother that by a seal writing he assure all his land upon he then his friend and kinsfolk begin to treat of a marriage to be solemnize between he and a young gentlewoman of that country which when his brother perceive he begin to repent that he have resign over his mean because he know that with that gentlewoman he shall come in possession of a very large and ample dowry richard have intelligence hereof he forsake all for love of lean you have no reason dear brother say he to be afflict at this for the same liberality and courtesy which you have show towards i will I return to you again therefore behold I not only surrender up your writing and bond but allsoe all the interest I have in this my future wife if so it may stand with the good will and like of her friend and for my own part I never once kiss her lip henceforth have abandon all he have his land his spouse and his friend he betake himself to his study first at Oxford then at Paris in France where he learn his logic and he be so violent carry away with a^ extreme love and desire to apparel his mind with learning that he scarce ever think either offoode or apparel for his body for as himself afterward be wont to say when he be one of the three scholar that live in one chamber they have but one cap or hat betwixt they and each of they but one gown so that like some of our courtier now a day when one of they go forth to lesson with the hat the other two remain barchead at home and so the same cap serve they all by turn to go hear their lecture their ordinary food be bread and a little herbe-pottage or some such poor dish for their poverty will not allow they to eat either flesh or fish unless it be upon sunday and high day and when their friend and comrade do invite they and yet the holy man be wont to say that in all his life time he never enuoy merry and sweet day than those 2 in the mean time our hopeful young man prosit so excellent Hefs make master of art in his study that by the public applause and acclamation of all man he be judge worthy to be honour with the title of master but refuse to take any degree at Paris he return again to his country and to the university of Oxford where within a short time he be promote to be master of the liberal art he study canon law when liberal he impart that learning to other which before with much labour he have purchase to himself and go afterward into italic for seven year space he give his mind to study the canon law in the university of Bolognia and that with so great increase of learning that his master fall sick make choice of he among all his other scholar to supply his place and continue the lecture begin which for more than half a year he perform with so great modesty and readiness of wit and judgement that he purchase to himself great affection and praise throughout all the university and get so high a place of favour and good will with his master that he desire and aspire to nothing more willing then to give he his only daughter in marriage but rich. who move by a divine inspiration be far otherwise bend give he very humble thanks for his noble love courteous pretend some reason for his excuse add withal that for the present he have a long journey to make promise that at his return if so it please God his duty shall be yield to the level of his desire and take leave of his master and his daughter in this sort he return into England to the university of Oxford where he lead a very rigid and austere life in he be make chancellor of oxford continual labour watch and other bodily affliction when his fame and renown increase to such a height in the ear of the world that by the consent of all he be make chancellor of the university 3 about the same time s. Dover he fall into a sickness which he suffer not to hinder his pious enterprise for he cease not to labour on in the vineyard of our lord all way preach confirm child hear confession give holy order till he exhaust almost all the strength of his body come at length to Dover he be receive as a guest into a certain hospital call gods-house and at the entreaty of the master of the same hospital he have always a long desire to consecrate before he die at the least one church to the honour of that holy saint his ancient lord and master give there hearty thanks to almighty God who have not frustrate his desire therein add withal that now he know that the time of his departure be at hand and therefore he earnest recommend himself to the suffrage of their good sacrifice and prayer 13 the long to bear up his feeble limb he fall flat on the ground then he be carry back into the hospital by some of his servant and lay on a bed where to one William his chaplain with who he be ever very familiar he declare that he shall not escape that disease command he to prepare thing necessary for his funeral but private lest family perceave may be trouble and to Simon terringe he foretell the for very holy thing and keep as relic 14 afterward his sacred body be translate to Chicester according to his desire and bury in a mean place before s. edmond altar which himself have erect in the merit of this holy man no less but rather more wonderful sign of holiness when beside many other benefit and strange cure he restore three man from death to life and one child bear dead but revive by his merit be present at the age of four year before the inquisitour that be appoint to take the information of saint RICHARDS life and miracle nay his apparel be wear or but touch cure many disease and the sick person that lay in his bed present recover their health all which miracle and many more for brevity sake here omit be write in those day as manifest and certain truth and the book be Benedict apr. 6. out of William malmesbury gest pont. Anglo ELSTAN first a monk of the holy order of s. Benedict in the monastery of Abington under the government of the famous s. ETHELWOLD afterward bishop of Winchester be a man of wonderful simplicity and obedience a rare proof thereof be see in this accident for be command by his foresay abbot to see that the workman and artificer of the monastery be daily and due provide with necessary victual he undertake that labour with great devotion and play the cook himself in the prepare of their accustom diet and serve they very diligent and afterward wash the dish and other vessel with his own hand whilst the abbot all way think he have perform this duty of obedience by the help of a servant till one day go about the office of the monastery as his custom be he chance unaware to to find ELSTAN stand by the cauldron that boil on the fire and all the vessel very neat and clean and the room new sweep the abbot much delight hereat brother ELSTAN say he this not the virtue of prompt obedience obedience thou have steal from i but if thou be such a champion as thou seem to be put thy bare hand present into the boil cauldron and fetch i a piece of meat out of the bottom the command be no soon out of his mouth but flstans hand be in the boil water who unresistable heat yield to the courage of his true faith and obedience and do he no hurt at all to the great admiration and comfort of the holy abbot ELSTAN afterward be make abbot of Abington and last bishop of Wilton in both which charge he discharge the part of a holy prelate and end his day very happy to receive the reward of his obedience in heaven he flourish about the year of our lord 980. thus much of he we have gather out of William malmesbury pont. l. 3. Ethelwold the first day of August the life of saint GISLA and saint rictrude virgin of the sacred order of saint Benedict apr. 9 out of diverse author GISLA and rictrude bear in Kent of noble parent but much more ennoble with virtue and good learning from their very youth give themselves to the study of the elegancy of the latin tongue and other science under that excellent master s. alcvine a benedictin Monk after who departure out of England they live in a monastery at Canturbury under the holy rule of s. Benedict labour and profit daily in the continual exercise of virtue and learning diligent imitate s. Marie Magdalen^ in the sweetness of a contemplative and Martha in the labour of their skill in learning a active life be careful first to profit themselves in mortification and meditation and then to show external work of charity to their neighbour and peculiar to comfort the afflict whence it be that have attain to a sufficiency of learning a rare thing in their sex they write many spiritual and consolatory work which envious time have suffer to perish but some epistle of they and special one to s. alcvine and his answer thereunto be extant among his work the inscription of he to they be thus to the most noble in holiness of christian religion the most devote to the study of wisdom the two virgin consecrate to God Gisla his sister and rictrude his daughter the humble brother and father ALCVINE wish the health of perpetual blessedness at length these holy virgin after the long exercise of virtue and good work this world toreceive the crown of their virginity in heaven among that glorious choir of other holy Benedictine nun they flourish about the year 770. in the reign of alrick king of Kent thus much we have take out of Nicholas Harpsfield 8. c. 6. arnould Wion John pitts scrip aug. an. 770. and other s. GUTHLACUS monachus EREMITA ord. s. April 11. (@) f. the life of s. GUTHLAKE priest and anacherite of the holy order of s. Benedict apr. 11. write by Felix a benedictin monk of Croyland the worthy servant of JESUS-CHRIST saint GUTHLAKE bear of noble parent guthlake parent P^nwald and descend lineal from the royal stem of the Mercian king but he ennoble his princely progeniture with the nobility and spendour of religion and virtue which his future excellency and incomparable virtue a strange and admirable presage seem to make know and a strange apparition at his abyrth manifest at his very birth for the same hour that his mother lie in childbed of this holy offspring a fair yellow hand as it be of a man appear by the cross which stood^ opposite to her house cast forth wonderful beam of brightness and when the people of the country flock together in great troop to behold that miraculous apparition the same hand make the sign of the cross on the house door of the labour woman and present vanish a happy sign and precursour of his birth foreshow that in his life time he shall always carry in his body the peanance of Christ holy cross but the multitude of people much astonish and amaze at this unaccustomed spectacle begin as the manner be with diverse and doubtful opinio to waver in their sundry exposition of that divine miracle the great part affirm that sure it betoken some great and heavenly mystery when the mid wive come forth with news that the child for who sake that wonder appear be bear in baptism he be name GUTHLAKE and during the time of his childhood he appear to bear in a clear and love countenance so grateful and acceptable a grace that his sole look be of force sufficient to purchase love in the mind and heart of all man 2 at the age of twenty four year he begin very hot to follow and practice the noble act of military discipline to defend himself and his whole race against the adversary which take head against they and be set forth in warlike ornament and have muster together some troop of soldier he begin cruel to he give himself to the war in his youth invade his enemy to besiege to w^es to overthrow castle in soemuch that out of his worthy deed of arm he purchase to himself many title trophy and monument of fame throughout the country but in the midst and heat of all this cruelty he be not so far corrupt with a desire of military glory but even in that bloody kind of life he give some figne of true piety for oftentimes he will restore back the three part of his spoil to those he have vanquish thereby overcome his enemy the second time with courtesy as before he have do with the sword at length call to mind by a divine inspiration the lamentable end of many great king and prince of his ancestor and consider that the secular pomp of the world be but as a puff of smoke and a vapour quick vanish and remember the shortness of man day the uneertaintie of his death the terror of his departure out of this life the severity of God tribunal and the eternity of the pain in the life to come he resolve to give over that course of life and call his fellow soldier together he bid they adieu in these word hitherunto my dear friend I have wage war in the regiment of the world vanity from hence forth I be determine to bear arm only under the ensign of JESUS-CHRIST our true and dear captain choose yourselves a other leader who colour you may follow for I will follow the banner of our lord holy cross sanctify in his pretions blood and no reason nor prayer be able to turn he from this pious resolution he cast of his martial arm and go to the famous monastery of benedictin monk at Ripendown in the kingdom of Mercia where have take the habit he become a Benedictine monk of a monk under the holy rule of s. Benedict he enter into a very strict and severe manner of life deprive himself not only of the superfluous but almost of the necessary use of meat drink and sleep the psalm hymn and other knowledge of holy scripture he learn with a wonderful facility within the space of two year he be of a pleasant countenance humble in his behaviour and gate religious and full of the fear of God in his work constant in faith his manner of life in the monastery in hope abound in charity in his counsel and very circomspect and mild in his word and live among his brethren he imitate the diligent and laborious be which avoid all infectious weed suck whatsoever be good and profitable out of all the sweet flower round about and bring it to her hive for as he high detest all manner of vice so he strive and endeavour with a great contention of mind to express in himself not only one but all the good manner and virtue of those with who he live therefore whatsoever be excellent or notable in each of they he heap it all to himself the learning of one the continency of a other this man patience the other submission and humility the silence of some the strict diet of other and their night and day watch and in a word he rank into himself alone a goodly train or lift of all other virtue and pious action 3 now when he have make good trial of himself for the space of two year and show a worthy example of virtue and holiness in that excellent school of religion he begin to aspire his desire of a solitary life to a high manner of perfection be take with a wonderful desire of a eremitical and solitary life therefore have communicate his purpose with his abbott and brethren with their good leave and well-wish he be dismiss to his own choice and he choose himself a habitation in the island of Crowland in Lincoluethire a place at that time most remote from all humane company and which as well for many fen marsh and rude grove thereof as allsoe through fear and horror of devil and goblin that molest it be never before inhabit by any into this desert our famous champion be waft over in a little boat with two other youth in his company on the very feast of saint Bartholomew the apostle in who merit he have a he enter the horrid (@) of Crowland particular confidence begin to lead a solitary and strict life have build a little cottage he use for his clothing the raw and rude skin of beast his diet be a small quantity of barley bread and water which he do not taste till after sunnsett but the common enemy of mankind envy so great virtue and goodness assault he with such a vehement spirit of temptation that he bring he even to the very brink of fall into the bottomless gulf of despair for be much overthrow in mind and trouble more than can be express he begin to think of fly away and forsake the desert when the almighty helper and comforter of his servant in affliction send he his divine assistance by the mean of the holy apostle saint Bartholomew who appear in temptation (@) comfort by s. Bartholomew visible unto he revive his weak spirit with such like word be of good comfort my son and resume thy strength and courage thou have enter a mighty battle it do not become a professor of so great and worthy a purpose to be overthrow with a little blast of tentation therefore go on courageous for albeit our lord permit the to be tempt notwithstanding he will make thy temptation redound to thy great good thou be cruel set upon to be overthrow but I have make intercession for thou that they faith do no fail thou be assist from above our lord have put to his help hand it be his will and health of his servant he will be to thou as a tower of fortitude against they enemy at these word the holy apostle vanish out of his sight and he remain much comfort and strengthen in our lord and four other monk have according as they be able repair a little habitation of defence only against the violence of the weather make choice of one Godrick for their abbot and live in a religious poverty and a pious expectance to be restore to their ancient state for the space of a hundred year and more till a age man call turketill chancellor to worthy king edred pass by Crowland as he go on business for the king to York be meet by those bless old monk and with a pious courtesy compel to lodge in their ruin monastery and hear the monastery of Crowland reedisy the woeful story of their miserable STEPHEN surname Harding bear in England of noble parent be bring up from his very childhood in dorsetshire in the monastery of sherburne under the holy rule of s. Benedict till be now in the flower of his youth when the nettle of the world begin to sting his mind far otherwise incline he flee out of the danger into France where careful lay the ground of true learning he receive the first efficatious motive to tue and the love of God for when his ripe year have banish all boyish inclination he take a journey to Rome with one other in his company in which albeit the way be long and difficult and their poverty little able to defray that charge both go and return they daily recite and sing the whole psalter have pious visit the sacred tomb of the apostle they return into Burgundy where STEPHEN in a new build monastery of s. benedict order call put on the habit and conversation of a benedictin Monk and at very first he grow easy he take the habit of s Benedict familiar with the precept of s. benedict rule in which he have beme conversant long before but find other statute propose which he have not read in the rule before he begin all way keep religious modesty to demand the ground and reason of those law all thing say he be govern with reason but because through sloth and negligence humane frailty oftentimes fall from reason many law be make in time past and from our holy father s. Benedict we receive a rule to recall the scatter mutability of nature to the bound of reason in which albeit many thing be for which I can give no reason yet the authority of the author who questionless receive they from heaven bid i yield thereunto therefore show a instance out of the rule uphold with reason and authority and dictate by he who be replenish with the spirit of all just man this if you can do you do in vain make profession of his prerogative who doctrine you refuse to follow 2 this opinion creep from one to a other much move their heart that fear God lest perchance hitherunto they have or may hereafter follow a wrong course therefore after a frequent disputation thereof in chapter s. ROBERT the abbott approve Stephen opinion and conclude that they shall surcease from follow superfluous statute and search only into the marrow he depart to cifterce of s. benedict rule but many refuse to leave their old custom some few only embrace s. Anselme and discourse with he of the government of monastery begin great to complain of the liberty and disobedience of the young gentleman under his charge and that he watch night and day over they and make their fault to be severe whip and chastise and yet it seem that the more he keep they under the worse and more incorrigible they grow and what say s. Anselme become of these child when their be at age or what profit reap you out of all this whip and scourge gentleness most requisite in bring up youth for the most part reply the abbott they grow to be great ignorant dolt then s. Anselme this manner of education of youth seem to i most uncertain for even as if one who by hedge in of young plant do so choke they up with thorn that they can neither grow nor put forth their bough will consequent bring no fruit nor profit so in the nourishment of child who be rich and delicate plant to bring they to good one must use a fatherly love towards they give they a gentle and discrete liberty and not always make they slave with fear threaten and stripe because when they do not acknowledge and find in their tutor and master that guide they the cordial affection and love of a father they think whatsoever be say or do to they proceed out of chollar hatred and malice and as they grow in age they grow allsoe in a great defiance of their master of who they have as great horror as a thief of his executioner rule for superior in their government in fine s. Anselme teach the abbott that true government ought to know how to temper sweet with sour clemency with severity and to cure wound not only with the sharpness of wine which close up but with the suppleness of oil allsoe which soften and open the sore for although hard bread and crust be good for those that have good tooth yet suck child can eat it and if a superior will guide all his inferior the same way without discern the different condition and inclination of the person who he govern he will certain commit many gross fault to the great affliction and loss of his suiect the fame of s. Auselme draw many choler 8 s. Anselme then environ with the glitter beam of excellent virtue his renown be carry on the wing of fame over all Normandy through France into Flanders and England so that many learned and pious man come to the monastery where he be prior to range themselves into the spiritual warfare under the colour of s. Benedict strive to receive the habit at his hand and to live under his correction and discipline nevertheless he be so prudent and reserve that he never solicit any man to give himself to God rather in his monastery then in any other but all way leave it to their choice to enter into what convent they best like to the end that if afterward they happen to repent they shall have no just occasion to murmur or coplaine against he but they come so thick of their own accord that the abbey of bec be in a short time wonderful increase in temporal and spiritual good of many good religious monk and abbott Herluine be dead Anselme by the common suffrage of all the convent be choose to succeed in his place albeit he labour with prayer and tear against it throw himself prostrate at the foot of the monk and conjure they by the dear passion of our lord issus CHRIST not to charge his weak shoulder with such a weighty he be choose abbot of Bec. burden in fine when all his resistance do but increase their importunity he yield sincesuch he perceive be the will of God be therefore make abbott he govern the monastery with such holy prudence and prudent holiness that this new increase of dignity be in he as a discovery of a new mine of shine virtue who beam amaze all behoulder 9 at that time there be many possession in England belong he come into England to the abbey of bec to visit which saint Anselme go over into England at Canturbury where LANFRANCK his old master be archbishop he be with wonderful great honour receive by the benedictin monk of that city which he no less ingenious then elegant put off affirm the great honour and great affection of charity to reside in they that perform it then in he to see his great humility who it be perform because he who unworthy receive that undeserved duty can expect for it no reward from God for what say he can be due to i from God in that any one show love towards i but to they from who this love proceed he owe a reward for their pious affection and he will not fail to lay up store of grace for they but the more he seek to avoid honour the more still be throw upon he when people of all order sex and condition strive to do he the high honour they can and among the rest king william the conqueror who albeit otherwise a norman of a fierce and barbarous nature yet towards saint Anselme beyond all man expectation he behave himself with a unaccustomed courtesy and kindness to the great admiration of all but the saint quick weary with these honour think his journey in nothing so well spend as in the sight and conference he have of his old master LANFRANCK the archbishop between who discourse of many grave affair fell at this time that famous disputation mention in his life of s. elphegus the martyr afterward he return again to his monastery and govern the same the space of fifteen year with all virtue belong to a good prelate in the mean time William conqueror die leave the crown to his onne William Rufus who by all indirect way possible seek to oppress and impoverish the clergy and church thereby to satisfy his own unbridled covetousness and with their gold to give a glorious outside to his own wickedness whereupon s. Anselme at the earnest entreaty of the noble resolve to come again into England but in the mean time Lanfrank be dead a rumour arise of the advance of Anselme to the archiepiscopal sea of Canturbury which make he o wonderful contemmpt of honour to defer his journey for five year space how many be there now adays that will have take post in this case x. come at length to Canturbury he be salute by the Benedictine monk and other as their future prelate which he take so s. Anselme refuse the stile of archbishop heinous that the next day he depart before the sun be guilty of his be in town albeit it be the very feast of the nativity of our lady refuse to be win by any prayer to celebrate there that solemnity thence he go to king William and deal free with he to amend his manner of life to order the common wealth in better fashion as well in ecclesiastical as temporal affair tell he withal what a ill opinion of his bad life be blow over the world but the king be deaf to all good counsel till fall into a grievoussicknes he begin to make he remember himself and hearken a little more to his pious persuasion he be choose archbishop of Cauturbury in the mean time be put in mind that the sea of Canturburie be void of a pilot and that that mother-church of England have many year be a widow he proclaim Anselme to be the most worthy of that dignity that the disciple may succeed his master and this his proposition be present accept with the common consent and applause of the benedictin monk of Canturbury unto who the election of the archbishop belong and the general like of the people only Anselme with might and main resist this election and obstinate refuse to undertake the dignity with tear allege many reason and excuse he make many protestation that it be a very foolish and overthwart proceed to join to the plough a old sheep yoke with a untamed bull by the bull meaning king William but all in vain for the pastoral staff be forcible thrust into his hand himself violent draw into the next church be proclaim archbishop and his election witness with many joyful acclamation and sing of the himme etc. and now the day of his consecration and installation at Canturbury be prefix to the four of December when by the open of the bible this sentence fall to s. anselmes lot 11 at the first king William show goodwill and friendship note the covetousness of the king towards s. Anselme in hope that be now advance to so great dignity he will bestow some worthy present upon he but as soon as he perceive that Anselme have no such meaning he begin to repent himself of this one albeit a rare good deed and be whole give by hook or by crook as they say to get money he not so require as exact a friendly gift of a thousand pound sterling for a gratuity for his advancement to the archbishopric but saint Anselme hate that unroyall covetousness in the king be determine not to send he a penny till sway by the counsel of many friend lest he shall great exasperate the king to the great detriment of the whole english church he send he five hundred pound promise to gratify his majesty more large when occasion serve William utter refuse to accept that present as too slender and spare a reward for a king whereat s. Anselme great rejoice because by this mean he clear himself from all stain of honour which for this fact malice may have lay to king William move against s. Anselme his charge and without any delay he distribute that whole sum of money to the poor afterward he begin to call upon the king to have a council assemble for the reform of the clergy and establish of ecclesiastical discipline in the church but his good intention receive a sharp rebuke from the king who seek by all mean to break all the liberty of the church in persecute the clergy invade the ecclesiastical good and other such outrage that the holy man can neither hinder his unjust proceed Noah execute his function in peace so that albeit he be whole dispose to stand strong in defence of the truth and the freedom of the church yet than he judge it more expedient for the avoid of great inconvenience which even the other bishop and country back with the authority and power of the king may cause to absent himself a while out of England imagine that to be the safe way both to appease the enrage king and qualify the tempest of the country 12 therefore he make a supplication to the king to permit he to go to Rome to obtain from pope urban the second the pall due unto his archiepiscopal seat the king amaze at this demand answer that no man in his kingdom shall acknowledge any pope of Rome without his consent and that he himself be after a fashion pope within his own dominion which answer infinite afflict the holy archbishop who to extinguish this spark of infernal fire before it go any further assemble a council he summon a council of the bishop abbbot and peer of the realm wherein have declare the king mind the consequence and importance of the matter he find the great part of the bishop incline to subscribe to the prince will so great be the power of flattery and ambition join with the authority of a furious and resolute king for they cry out aloud that he be a person impious and rebellious to the king and state whosoever will attempt to maintain any obedience in England to be due to any but king William alone as well in ecclesiastical as temporal matter rob the pope hereby of his primacy and sovereign power over all the Catholic church s. Anselme see this unlawful proceed and that he can not resist against so horrible a stream desire leave of the king to leave the kingdom and go to Rome but he receive diverse time a bitter denial the king always affirm that he will hold he as a enemy to his crown and the common wealth if the attempt that journey and that at his first instalment in the archbishopric he have bind himself by oath to observe the law and custom of the country which forbid go Rome without the king leave the holy man answer that it be not the part of a christian prince to cut of any he appeal to the pope appellation to the roman sea of PETER and that he have engage himself to the observance of no other law then what stand with the honour of God and good reason when the king and his reply that there have be no mention make either of God or goodness to which Anselme o goodly do say he that shun the name of God or goodness which word put all his adversary to silence for that time but the king anger and hatred against he increase more and more every day which also so terrify many of the other bishop that they begin open to forsake their metropolitan and not to defend his cause although in their heart they do not utter disprove it 13 in the mean time saint Anselme constant tell the king that notwithstanding all this opposition he will go to Rome and before his departure provide that he king will not reject it he promise to give he his benediction which do he go to Canturbury where after one day stay have with a oration he go to Rome like a pilgrim full of piety and affection exhort his monk to follow the train of virtue and to put on the armour of constancy and patience against the imminent danger that threaten to follow he put on the habit of a pilgrim to the great grief of all his friend and especial of the monk of Canturbury and go to take ship at Dover and with he go Eadmerus a benedictin monk of Canturbury who write his life they pass over into France and to lion where s. Anselme be entertain with wonderful magnificence and respect by Hugue archbishop of the place the pope understanding of his be there send for he to come to Rome with all speed where he be honour by all the court and so high praise by the pope in presence of the cardinal and lord of Rome for his great learning and piety that the holy man much confound and ashamed therewith dare not lift up his eye before the company which humility make they all judge he to be a other manner of man in the presence of almighty God than he appear by his outside then he solicit the pope in nothing more then to get leave to lay aside his episcopal dignity for the love of a private life but pope Vrban will by no mean grant his request but advise he to seiourne a while in a monastery of Benedictine monk near the city of Capna where by the prayer of saint Anselme a lively fountain of water spring out of a hard rock which be call a fountain out of a rock by his prayer the bishop of Canturburys well and the water cure many disease 14 s. Anselme be present by the command of the pope in the council of bar where he make show of his knowledge and prudence in the convince of the greek and prove the holy ghost to proceed from the father and the son as from one beginning and mention be make in this council of king William and of his outrage commit against Anselme and the church his crime appear so heinous that all proclaim he worthy to be cut off from the church by the sentence of excommunication have not Anselme interpose himself and fall on his knee the wonderful humility and meekness of s. Anselme crave a time of respite which with difficulty he obtain and this his meekness and humbleness of mind gain he a wonderful great favour among they all the pope be return to Rome be meet by a ambassador from king William to defend the king cause against Anselme who but new come from play the part of a advocate in his behalf and by the importunity of this ambassador the cause be commit to be hear in a council hold at Rome where s. Anselme into his favour and send he in peace to his archbishopric to the great contentment and enjoy of the whole kingdom here now we may see of what power the constancy of a good prelate be when pure and sincere for the only love and service of God they defend the authority of the church without any pretence of temporal respect by flatter king in their injustice and suffer themselves to be carry away with the wind of worldly favour we may see allsoe the great grace which God show to king that respect his church and churchman for as soon as king Henry have submit himself our lord give he a noble victory against his brother Robert by mean whereof he get the signiory of the dukedom of Normandy of which victory he present make saint Anselme acquaint by letter end thus werefore venerable father w^ll Malm. l. 1. Anselme fall sick when load with old age labour and merit he fall into a great sickness and special in his stomach which make he abhor all sustenance till by little and little the force of his body be exhaust he faint and when the infirmity of his body be such that it will not suffer he to go to the church notwithstanding he be carry thither every day in a chair to be present at the sacred mystery of the mass whereunto he bear a singular great devotion pierie and reverence at length see himself to draw near his end he receive the holy sacrament of the church and give his benediction no the assistance humble recommend the king queen and all the whole kingdom to God holy protection and lie on a haircloth strew with ash according to the pious custom of those time he rend r^d up his bless soul to the everlasting possession of all blessedness on Wednesday morning his happy death before easter the one and twentieth day of April in the year of our lord 1109. the sixteenth since he be make bishop and the threescore and six of his age he be bury in great solemnity and lament by his church and the whole kingdom of England which lose a master a father and a pastor so holy so wise so courageous and so venerable 18 our lord ennoble this glorious saint with many miracle his wonderful miracle both during his life and after his death 1. as he be one night at his prayer he be see to be encompass round about with the brightness of a heavenly splendour 2. one that drink only of the water in which he have wash his hand be cure of a most pitiful leprosy that reign all over his body 3. by the sign of the cross he quench a mighty fire that be ready to devour the chamber where he ^ay 4. one of his religious most cruel possess with the devil be cure only by the well-wish of s. Vsuard ado Arnold wion and other make honourable mention of hi^^ the life of s. egbert priest and monk of the holy order of saint Benedict apr. 24. out of venerable bede the admirable master of humility and most zealous advancer of Christ gospel saint egbert bear of a noble race of english parent in the south part of England spend the flower of his youth in the monastery of lindisfarne or holy-iland in which school of virtue he receive the first ground of true religion under the holy rule of saint Benedict which afterward he communicate to other place to the great honour and increase of the benedictin order it be the manner in those day of many of our english to go over into Ireland there to apply themselves in a more strict course of holy meditation watch fast and prayer and other exercise of a monastical life among the rest holy egbert forsake friend and country go thither with a fervent desire to piety accompany he go into Ireland with a other noble Englishman call Ethelune and hue together in Jreland in a monastery call in irish Rathmelfigi they be both infect with the plague which at that time muster whole troop of people under the black banner of death when holy egbert expect nothing but to be enrol in the same number of death servant go one morning out of that mournful lodging where the sick monk lay expect their end into a secret and solitary place where sit down to entertain himself with his own throught he begin to cast up a strict account of his former life wherein he find many item who remembrance beget such contrition in his heart that the tear trickle down his cheek be worthy witness to prove it excellent then in the heat of true devotion he humble beseech almighty his petition to allmigh tie God God to grant he a little long respite in this world as well to bewail the sin of his youth as allsoe more abundant to exercise himself in the work of religious perfection vow withal never more to return into his native country of England but to live a pilgrim all the day of his life moreover beside his canonical office he be wont if sickness do not hinder he he daily recite David psalter to recite every day the whole psaker of David in honour of almighty God and to fast one whole day and a night every week without any food at all but when his prayer have set a period to his tear and his vow to his prayer he return back to his lodging where he find his fellow Edelhune that labour with the same disease fast asleep and he himself lay down his feeble limb to recreate they a while with rest but long he have not repose when his companion awake and look pitiful upon he o brother egbert say he what have thou do I have hope we shall have go joyful together to the kingdom of heaven but now by thy desire we must be separate for know that thy request be grant it have be reveal unto he in a vision what egbert request be and that he have have a grant there of from God 2 the night follow Edelhune die happy and egbert by a he be miraculous cure of the plague special favour of divine grace recover his health afterward adorn his monastical vocation with the dignity of priesthood and ennoble that dignity with worthy action of virtue and good life always govern himself with the rule of perfect humility sweet meekness pure continency plain simplicitte and candid innocence his example of life his labour in teach his authority i^ reprehend and his liberality in bestow what the charity of the rich give he be of wonderful great profit and edification to all the country where he live in voluntary banishment and his rigid fast to increase the austerity of his own life he add to the vow aforesaid to make but one small meal a day throughout all the lent which be a little bread and a poor quantity of thin^e milk which he do eat cold after it have stand a whole night and when the cream or fat substance thereof be skim off this manner of fast he observe like wise forty day before Christmas and as many more after Whitsuntide upon these well settle foundation and ground of holiness in a short time saint egbert raise a spiritual build of virtue to the very height of monastical perfection so that the same of his great Britain now call his country and youth North-wales be from his youth bring up under the government and discipline of great saint KENTIGERNE in the monastery of ell in flintshire where among nine hundred and three score other monk his fellow-scholler he s^ined in all manner of virtue and bear the prize of obedience and sanctity from they all he descend from a noble race and seem to have the root of virtue engraft in his soul from the cradle which by his diligent and careful manage bring forth a worthy baruest of pious fruit at their time he put forth himself in nothing so much a sin labour to make his own conversation and manner of life conformable to the austere pattern of virtue and mortification which appear in his holy master saint KENTIGERNL to who his obedience be such that it deserve to be witness for excellent by miracle for saint KENTIGERNE come one night out of the cold water in which as his custom be he have recite the whole psalter of David and be so extreme freeze that he be almost quite deprive of heat the necessary companion of life he the strange virtue of prompt obedience send his holy disciple asaph for fire to recover the force of his decay body he that have no lesson so perfect as obedience run hasty to the fiery oven and find no other instrument to carry his fire take the hot scorch coal into his lap and without any sign of burn in his coat bring they to his master who admire so great virtue in his scholar hold he in great estimation ever after and commit to his charge the whole regiment of the monastery and make he his successor in the bishopric of ell now call s. asaph retain always the name but far wide of the virtue and faith of saint asaph who when he have govern his sea for the space of many year in great sanctity and
