EADBERT bishop and confessor of the holy order of saint Benedict may. 6. out of venerable bede hist. gest ang. lib. 4. EADBERT surname the almoner a man as excellent in learning and the knowledge of divine scripture as in the observance of ecclesiastical and monastical precept and most excellent in the virtue of give alm be raise from the humility of a Benedictine monk in the monastery of lindisfarne to succeed that glorious ornament he be make bishop of Lindisfarne of the Benedictine family great s. Cuthbert in the government of the same episcopal sea in which dignity he most worthy discharge the office of a good prelate exact observe withal the rigour and severity of monastical discipline he be wont to spend the whole time of Lent and forty day before the nativity of our lord in a secret place separate from his church where he exercise himself in the continual practice of prayer contemplation and bitter penance with all other religious virtue and this be the same place in which his excellent predecessor s. Cuthbert have for a time lead a solitary life before he go to the island of Farne the eleven year after the deposition of the never-enough name s. Cuthbert when the monk of Lindissarne open his death and burial his grave have find his body uncorrupted as be say in his life the twentieth of march they bring part of his clothes to saint EADBERT then live in his solitary place of devotion which he both receive very grateful and reverence with wonderful affection and say he let that sacred body be wrap in new clothes in steed of those you have take off and place it honourable in the shrine which you have prepare for most certain I know that the grave which his holy relic have consecrate with such admirable miracle will not long be empty of a inhabitant and how happy be that man to who our lord the author and bestower of all happiness shall voutchase to make worthy to rest therein these and such like word the holy bishop utter with a tremble tongue whilst the tear that trickle down his cheek witness the feel compunction of his heart the monk present perform his command and place the sacred body of s. Cuthbert in a chest over the sepulchre wherein he have be bury in the mean time the belove servant of God s. EADBERT desire of almighty God that for better satisfaction of his former life he may pass out of this world through his death and burial the parch furnace of a long-during sickness fall into a most grievous disease which increase daily more and more for the space of more than a month when the vehemency be so great that it force his bless soul to leave her mortal lodging to make a happy flight to the immortal habitation of happiness the six day of may. and out of the prerogative of his great sanctity he be judge worthy to be bury in the grave which his predecessor s. Cuthbert have consecrate eleven year with his incorrupted body and so alive he become s. cuthberts successor in the episcopal sea and in his sepulchre be dead where venerable bede affirm that he shine with same of work many miracle but whether they be wrought by his merit or saint cuthberts who body be place in a chest over the same grave it can be judge by none but he who search the heart and reins of all man who name be for ever bless he die in the year of our psal 9 lord 698. beside s. bede who we have follow William malmesbury Molanus Nicholas Harpsfield and the roman martirologe (@) honourable mention of s. EADBERT the life of s. JOHN of Beverley bishop and confessor of the holy order of s. Benedict MARTINO 7. out of venerable bede hist. gest ang. lib. 5. c. 2. and (@) saint JOHN surname of Beverley bear of noble english parent in the north part of great Britain be send in his youth to Canturbury to be instruct by the two oracle of learning and virtue s. THEODORE the archbishop and s. adrian abbott of the Benedictine abbey of s. PETER in the same city in this holy school of virtue and learning JOHN not only profit in the knowledge of holy scripture and good manner but allsoe be kindle with a desire to embrace the same monastical rule of s. Benedict which his master profess and to this end have sound perfect his understanding with learning he depart to his inclination to a religious life the Benedictine abbey of Streanshall where put on the habit and profession of a monk he both exercise himself in the perfection of monastical discipline and great promote the observance of s. benedict rule which great s. wilfrid have introduce into the same monastery moreover the worth of his learning be worthy witness by the excellency of his scholar among who be s. BRITHUNE afterward abbot of Beverley s. wilfrid the lesser that succeed he in the archbishopric of York both Benedictine monk and above all the glory and ornament of his country and the Benedictine order venerable bede all which with other saint JOHN not only instruct in divine and humane knowledge and incite to piety with his godly admonition but also inflame they much more with the example of his own life and virtue to undertake the high journey of religious perfection he bear a singular affection to s. bede who when he be bishop he advance to the dignity of deaconship and priesthood alfred king of the Northumber move with the fame he be make bishop of hagustald of this holy man sanctity make he successor to Eata in the episcopal sea of hagustald otherwise call Hexham but after the death of Bosa he be translate to the archiepiscopal chair of York in which sacred function he perform his duty with g^e^ praise and admiration of all when all the mind and eye of England be fix whole upon he both for his excellent virtue and equal rare learning as allsoe for his wonderful and miraculous deed which worthy witness the piety of his life and conversation 2 but during the time of his regency in the church of hagustald or Hexham at a place somewhat more than a mile distant from his retire life in Lent thence in a chapel dedicate to s. MICHAEL he go often time and special in time of Lent to lead a solitary and contemplative life separate from the affair of the world attend only to thing divine and heavenly begin this holy exercise on a time he conmaund his companion as his custom be to seek he out some poor creature more miserable than ordinary who he may maintain there with the charity of his daily alm they bring he a poor boy dum-borne with a cap of scab and scurf on the top of his head instead of hair about which grow a thin hedge of fright hair the sight whereof beget a horror in the behoulder the holy bishop much rejoice that he have find so fit a subject upon who to exercise his accustom office of charity cause present a little lodging to be build within the precinct of his own habitation where that wretched poverty be daily refresh with the stipend of his piety but the first week of Lent see the virtue of the sign of the cross be past he command they to bring the poor man before he and make the sign of the holy cross upon his tongue he receive not only the perfect use of his speech but also be cure of the scabby scuruine in his head so that he that before bear the shape or dumb-shew of deformity be sudden become ready in his speech quaint and fair in his countenance and curl lock and glad to hear himself play the crier of his own happiness 3 alsoe with his benediction he cure a nun of a great swell many miracle and cruel pain in her arm catch by let blood and be by a earl who countess lie languish in a mortal disease invite to consecrate a church he send she of the holy water which he have use in that act of consecration and she no soon drink thereof but present rise sound out of her bed she come like s. Peter mother-in-law cure by our saviour and wait on they luc. 4. at the table show thereby that she have not only recover her health but her lose force allsoe the like benefit he show to a young man of who health his friend be so hopeless that his grave be already prepare when contrary to all expectation by the prayer and benediction of the holy bishop and drink a cup of wine by he hallow he be restore again to perfect health but one herebald who sometime have be his scholar receive a far great benefit at his hand be by his mean preserve from the ruin both of body and soul as himself be afterward abbot of Tinemouth relate to venerable bede in this manner when in my youth I live under the tutorship of the b. bishop JOHN note this miraculous history to betrayn up in the study of ecclesiastical discipline and learning my mind be at that time carry away with the wild and untamed sport of a youthly ardour we happen be one day in a journey with the holy man to come into a fair plain and large way which seem to invite we to run a course with our horse and the secular young man of the company begin earnest to entreat the bishop leave to have a course whereunto he be loath to consent till overcome with their importunity he yield to their request but the punishment of disobedience to s. John upon condition that herebald shall abstain from that sport but then I begin earnest to plead my own cause that I may try my horse with the rest know he to be of very good speed but can by no mean prevail to get his consent whereupon be no long able to contain my untamed desire within the limit of obedience I set spur to my horse and run among the rest when I can hear he behind i fetch a great sigh and say o what a grief thou give i in so ride notwithstanding I hold on that forbid course till leap over a hollow place I catch a fall which leave i as dead without any sense or motion a just punishment of my disobedience from seven of clock till the evening I lay there for dead and then revive a little my companion carry i home where I pass that night without speak one word but the holy bishop who bear a singular affection to i grieve exceed at this mischance and that whole night he spend only in watch and prayer for my recovery in the morning he come to i and out of a divine instinct ask if I be certain of my baptism to who have now recover my speech I answer yes and name the priest that have wash i in the sacred font. if that be the priest that do it reply he thou be not right baptize for he be both of wit and understanding so dull that he can never learn the true manner of catechise or baptise and for that reason I have command he to cease from the exercise of that function which see the ancient ceremony of baptism he can not execute in due manner this say he begin present to catechise i and it happen that breathe in my face as the manner be I straight begin to find myself much amend of my hurt he cause the chirurgean to settle and compose aright the dissolve joint of my skull and have give his benediction to the work at the same instant I recover foe well that the next day I be able to ride a other journey with he by who merit I be restore to health and within a while after be full recover I receive the sacrament of baptism so that I be indebt the salvation both of soul and body to bless saint JOHN thus be herebald wont to relate of himself to venerable bede 4 but s. JOHN have govern his bishopric the space of s. DIMPNA in Ireland there live a very potent king but a heathen who have marry a fair woman who as well in regard her father a pagan king of her beauty as her other good part he dear love out of this marriage be bear a daughter call DIMPNA nothing behind her mother in beauty who her parent very careful and dainty bring up nevertheless as soon as she have attain to year of discretion come to the knowledge of JESUS CHRIST she become a christian and vow perpetual virginity unto he utter she vow her virginity to God despise all the pomp banquet dance and other vanity of the court. in the mean time her mother be dead her father have dry up his superfluous tear for her death be desirous to marry a second wife which he will have to be a fair young maid like unto the former but fail to find such a one in the country his flatter courtier persuade he to cast his eye upon his daughter DIMPNA than who none can be fair and in who be very like her mother he may revive the figure of his late her father ^^keth she in marriage wife what more this detestable counsel no soon arrive at his ear but straight the devil who desire to bring DIMPNA to idolatry incense the king with the flame of a incestuous and impure love towards his daughter here upon he begin to sound her intention with all manner of sweet speech and allurement promise to give she her whole heart desire if she will but marry he DIMPNA stop her ear at the hiss of this venommous serpent and answer that she will never consent to such a abominable i^nceste the king still earnest urge and she as courageous resist till in the end grow extreme angry he can she that he hold marry she whether she will or no then recommend herself hearty to the dear spouse of her soul CHRIST JESUS she answer her father that since he be resolve thereunto she desire forty day respite and to have all her ring and royal ornament that she want to set out herself for his great advantage he most willing grant her request think that his daughter have change her intention 2 in the mean time there be a holy priest in the country call Gerebert who have be confessor to the queen and have baptize DIMPNA and administer the venerable himself to be her companion so that they take ship private take but one servant and his wife in their company God permit they to arrive at Antwerp whence through uncouth way they pass from village to by Nicholas a monk of Durrhan his confessor this bless man be bear at a village call walpole in the county of Norfolk but adorn polish and bring to the perfection of virtue and piety in Northumberland in who true the almighty wisdom seem to have imprint and leave to the world a most sound and wonderful figure of his immense goodness and mercy for from a man bear in a most poor and abject place and endue with no learning at all he advance he to that know height of virtue prudence perfection and other heavenly gift and grace that many of they do seem almost to be beyond the bound of credit which indeed I will not commit to writing unless I think myself secure and certain he become a merchant of the truth of his worthy deed therefore come to the flower of his age he become a merchant of petty ware which he carry on his back to sell over the country from village to village till his own industry have increase his little mean he frequent the city and fair in the same trade and at length his riches daily grow he become master or at lest a patner in a ship in which he transport his merchandise into Scotland Denmark and Flanders so that by much practice he grow to be a man very skilful in before the worm and maggot begin to take possession of the old nether do he ever use any other food but this nor any other drink but pure water unless when the extremity of his hunger or thirst be correspondent which he do not take in bed but his manner of sleep lie upon the ground or lean his weary limb to a stone or wall never yield to this short and hard allowance of rest until the very necessity of nature by force compel he thereunto after the heavy toil of his day and night-labour^ his continual labour for he labour not only by the sun but by the light of the moon also as well in and prayer although indeed at this time he be not idle from both he spend his whole night and day banish from himself thereby all sign of sloth and dullness of mind and body 5 but amid all these of prayer as at midnight at sunrising at the three six and nine hour and evensong at which time no occasion or hindrance never so great can withdraw he from his devotion and the punctual observance of his time of prayer and divine office which be not that of the church to which his learning will not reach but such psalm as he himself by a divine grace have allot to himself for his devotion and to each of they lest he shall omit some through oblivion he lay by a little stone to signify how many be pass and how many be to come give himself also a triple remembrance at the end of each prayer with this small devotion in the people place himself on a bridge over which they be to pass from church to their village where when the hasty multitude of people come who mind be a pious art already in their beef-pott at home he begin to put forth his voice with all the musical be he can and charm their ear with his song for which when he grow to be grateful and plausible to that rude people and perceive that his song flow into their ear and mind to the great pleasure and contentment of both he begin by little and little to mingle his ditty with more serious and holy matter take out of the holy scripture and by that mean bring they in time to a feel of devotion and to spend the sunday and holy day with far great pro^^^^ to their own soul now let we go on with the course of his life 3 therefore when he have take the habit and profession of a his exercise in the monastery monk he bend all the force and power both of soul and body worthy to perform in deed what he promise by word wherefore he never move a foot out of the monastery unless some urgent necessity do he he spend all his time in read and prayer that as he himself do testify elsewhere in a epistle by read he may hear the voice of almighty God speak and by prayer he may speak unto he himself his diet be poor and very spare thereby to force the body to the subjection of the soul to which purpose he use a other wonderful austerity for in a fountain near adjoin which afterward he recite the psalter in the water bear his name he be wont by night according to the example of the awcient saint to plunge himself up to the neck whence he will not stir until he have recite over the whole psalter of David for his nightly task of prayer by which and other such exercise he so tame the sensuality of the flesh that if he happen at any time to feel the tickle motion and sting thereof he will not therefore like a coward-souldier present a example to be admire not imitate avoid and fly from the presence of a object move thereunto until after many prayer and psalm most devout offer to almighty God he find all that unclean motion of body to be utter extinguish and beat down a rare although to other a dangerous manner of overcome and questionless much envy of the devil but if any one chance to contend against the truth of this history in so Christian a philosopher I remit he Dioge^ Laert. l. 4. vit. Benedict may 26. write by Gotsellinus a monk and s. bede the fruitful country of England in time past call Britain be oppress and whole subdue by the warlike power of the saxon and other people of Germany be compel not only to receive and bear their governance dominion and name but also which be much worse to embrace their impious idolatry and the service of their false god so that the Christian Catholic religion which from king Lucius have flourish in that happy island for the space of three hundred year be miserable banish and destroy till a hundred and forty year after the eternal mercy of almighty God cast a fovourable eye upon our wretched country and put such holy thought into the mind of saint Gregory the great pope of Rome that although our country s. Gregory the great send Augustine in to England be far distant yet he embrace it with a pious affection and serious cast about how or by what mean he may reduce it again to the sweet subjection of Christ holy gospel which divine work when he himself as be say in his life can not bring to pass he commit the charge thereof to this our glorious apostle saint Augustine who at that time be prior of the monastery of saint benedict order which saint Gregory bid build in Rome on the side of the hill Scaurus and dedicate to saint andrew the apostle out of this monastery therefore our saint Augustine when he have lead a holy monastical life under the rule of the great patriarch of monk saint Benedict for the space of many year be call by great saint Gregory from the sweetness of contemplation to labour for the advancement of God church in a active manner of life and send together with other holy monk of the same order to preach the gospel of CHRIST to the english nation who obey the holy will of the pope undertake that great work and begin their journey towards Augustine begin his journey England and now they have pass over the freeze hill of Jtalie and be enter into the confine of France when understand the english nation to be of a barbarous cruel and warlike disposition and perverse in the profession of idolatry be terrible affright from their attempt after a consultation have among themselves they resolve rather to turn homeward again then to loose their labour among those fierce and barbarous people who language they know not 2 therefore set aside all delay the whole company send he return to Rome back Augustine to Rome humble to obtain of the pope in name of they all to have a exemption from that journey so dangerous laborious and so uncertain of reap any profit to who the holy pope burn with zeal to gain soul to the church send letter of exhortation to encourage they in their holy enterprise whereof this be the tenor Gregory servant of the servant s. Gregory epistle to comfort they in they journey of God to the servant of our lord JESUS-CHRIST because it have be better never to have begin good work then even in thought to fall from they be once begin you ought with all diligence ^moct belove child to accomplish the good work which by the help of our lord you have undertake nether let the labour of the journey nor the tongue of slanderous man deter you but God be your ruler perform with all instancy and fervour what you have begin know that a great glory of eternal recompense follow the greatness of your labour but in all thing be humble obedient to Augustine your prior to you return who we allsoe constitute your abbot know that through all thing it will be profitable for your soul whatsoever you shall do by his admomtion almighty God protect you with his grace and grant i to see the fruit of your labour in the everlasting kingdom to the end that although I can labour with you I may have a place with you in the joy of your recompense because indeed I desire to labour God keep you in health my most belove child give the three of the calend of August in the reign of our most pious emperor mauritius Tiberius etc. at the same time this most bless pope send letter allsoe to the archbishop of Arles in France wherein he commend sane Augustine and his fellow to be by his charity courteous receive and assist in what be necessary for that holy enterprise 3 saint Augustine and his company be strengthen and encourage with these pious line of the holy pope joyful undertake the journey which before they so great fear but come to in France be there much deride and scoff at by the rude people of the village and especial the woman for their poor habit and humble manner of carriage they be compel one night to take a hard lodging under a tree in the open view of the heaven where almighty God who be never forgetful of his servant by the prayer of s. Augustine send they a clear fountain of water which miraculous spring out of the earth to quench the extremity of their thirst refresh wherewith they sing the praise of almighty God all that night over who in the a pillar of light over the saint mean time appear a heavenly splendour which drive away the horrid shade of the night to the great comfort of his servant and confuse amazement of those rustic that flock thither the next morning ashamed and sorrowful for their fault in so reject god servant near unto the fountain s Augustine write these word in the earth here lodge Augustine the servant of the servant of a church bu^^ to s Augustine God who the bless pope Gregory send to convert the englishman whereby the people understand who they be and the cause of their journey great repent for their insolency show towards they and in the same place afterward a church be build in memory of s. Augustine into which entrance be forbbidden to all woman because their sex have most of all injure the holy man in that place but a rich matron that by force as it be get into that church presume on her own guiltlessnes towards the saint by the miraculous and sudden loss of her own life teach all man to believe who before will believe no man and she that think with her presumption to overcome all by her example give a plain interdict to all never to presume the like but now let we follow our divine legate Augustine enter the ocean towards England 4 have perform therefore all this long journey by land on foot he now sail into the ocean world of great Britain till he arrive with his fellow to the number of forty at the island of Kent call tanet which may worthy triumph that it be the first that receive CHRIST in his legate and in the rock that s. Augustine first set his foot he leave the impression of his step as in a piece of wax which place be of great devotion many year after have take interpreter out of France according to the direction of that it be easy to convert heathen the heretic that have no knowledge of CHRIST or his church then to reduce schismatic out off their error to the truth for after a long disputation those stubborn Britan will not yield nether to the prayer exhortation nor rebuke of saint Augustine and his fellow but rather prefer their own custom before all the church of the world unite together in CHRIST therefore saint Augustine end this laborious and long controversy say let we beseech almighty God to voutchafe to show by heavenly sign which tradition be to be follow you or we let a disease person be bring in and by who prayer he shall be cure let his faith and work be believe and follow of all which condition the adversary unwilling accept one deprive of all sight be lead in and place among his spiritual grace the heart of many of his faithful his prayer be end the blind man receive his sight to the great confusion of his adversary and comfort of those of his side who with one voice extol saint Augustine as the true preacher of the eternal light and the Britan themselves confess against their will that indeed the way of justice which Augustine follow be true but yet they can not thou swerve a apostrophe to England Thren. 4 v. 1. from the religion of this thy first apostle how be the gold make dark and the best colour change of thy first faith and charity in JESUS-CHRIST in time past thou do learn that faith only which be the beginning head and foundation of eternal salvation of those that be Catholic Roman priest and monk who now thou do persecute they celebrate the dreadful solemnity of mass which now thou abhor they honour and call upon the saint in heaven who thou despise they acknowledge the supreme authority of the bishop of the roman and Apostolicque sea whence they be send to deliver thou out of the blind night of idolatry to the bright day of the true christian faith by thou then pious and dutiful receive hear and retain and now like a degenerate child be fall from the obedience of thy mother-sea of Rome like unto a ship without a stern thou be blow and toss in the deep of the mystery of faith with every wind of erroneous doctrine be not able to steer into the haven of any settle and well-grounded opinion again therefore I repeat those word of the prophet how be the gold make dark and the best colour change in very deed thou have now leave thy first faith Thren. 4. v. 1. great Britain of the noble blood of Britan seem to be send to that trouble country as the son of peace for at his birth the seucritie of the divine justice be change into clemency and meekness and the three common scourge of kingdom plague famine and war which long have afflict that nation cease be baptize together with his year the grace of the holy ghost increase in his soul and the understanding and knowledge of divine learning when he come to man age all man presage that he will one day prove a worthy pillar of the Catholic church he be adorn with the sacred dignity of priesthood then he begin to lay open the hide treasure his learning and scholar of his wisdom and learning get in his tender year and to instruct other with the undrayneable fountain of his divine science whereby many be so rare enkindle with the beam of the true sun that they become fit to lighten and inflame other with the virtue and learning which they have suck from his breast at length the fame of saint GUDWALL be of so he be make bishop great estimation in the world that he be advance to the height of ecclesiastical dignity and make bishop when by how much he be exalt high to honour among the people of God church so the more abundant he spread abroad the sweet odour of his holy life and conversation to the great consolation and joy of the whole country he be bear to a very large and ample patrimony but despise all the riches and wealth of the vain mortal world he give all that he have to the church of CHRIST his immortal King and perceave allsoe that his pastoral he leave his bishopric chargety his mind with the chain of care to worldly affair more than he desire he find mean to discharge himself thereof and have substitute a other in his place retire himself to a monastery within his diocese where he enter into a contemplative life serve our lord in watch fast and prayer and all other austerity and discipline of a perfect monastical life 2 but desire within a short time after to enter into a more he lead a heremitical life secret solitariness whole to apply his mind to the contemplation of divine thing he depart with one only companion and go to a great rock that stand like a little island within the sea where have cut himself a little cave in the hard stone he lead a most retire and solitary life according to the example of the ancient hermit till the brethren of the monastery which he have leave being not able to endure the hard burden of the absence of GUDWALL who have endow they with the learning of heavenly discipline make a pious search over all the country to find he and be find they joyful range themselves in the institution of his virtuous school careful study to imitate his holy simplicity and lively mortification but be press with the narrowne of the place they hew many little habitation in that hard rock to defend themselves from the violence of the weather therefore the rock which before breed a solitary horror to the behoulder the number of his disciple be now turn into a house of prayer be make a habitation of monk where solemn watch be observe and the echo of god divine praise resound amid the roar of those swell wave when the fame of the holy man increase daily the number of his disciple likewise increase so that one hundred fourscore and eight monk be report to have live under the government of his pious institution in so much that the quantity of that place be not able to contain so great a number at a low water saint GUDWALL go down upon the the sea obey his command sand and with a assure and strong confidence in the divine goodness make the sign of the cross in the sand command those unruly wave in the name of JESUS-CHRIST no more to flow beyond the limit which he have there prescribe when to the great admiration and comfort of God servant that untamed element contain the accustom pride of its swell fury and obey the holy man command never more dare to transgress the bound by he prefix hence it appear that the miracle of the old law have be revive in the christian church for Moses divide and our GUDWALL bridle the wave of the untamed he (...) prayer sea and not only in this but in a life of saint ROBERT confessor and abbot under the holy rule of saint Benedict june 7. write by a ancient author recite by Surius the venerable abbot ROBERT bear in Yorkshire shun from his very infancy the vain sport and pastime of other child his equal so worthy profit in the study of good learning that he be afterward promote to the government of a church in that country but discharge himself within a while of that office and all care and cure of soul he go to the Benedictine abbey of Whiteby where he put on the habit and profession of a monk of saint benedict order at that time one Richard prior of our lady of York have receive a piece of land at a place call fountain where by the mean of Thrustine archbishop of York he have build a monastery in which together with twelve other monk over who he be abbott he lead a monastical life according to the constitution of the congregation of cisterce under the holy rule of saint Benedict no man there do eat his bread in idleness nor give his body to rest but when it be overweary with labour they all go hungry to the table and weary to bed their diet only supply necessity not their appetite and yet without either sadness or murmur they give God thanks with alacrity therefore our saint ROBERT have he become a Cistercia^ monk first obtain leave of his abbot join himself to this holy company and change his black habit for a white that be from a Benedictine become a cistercian still observe the rule of our holy father saint Benedict and now it be rare to behold how strong this holy man perform the accustom labour of the monastery how fervent he be in holy read and contemplation and how devout he follow his prayer and other monastical exercise be venerable in his behaviour provident in give of counsel and elegant in his speech 2 in the mean time have spend five year in this place in he be make abbot the year of grace a thousand one hundred thirty seven a noble man of Northumberland give a ample possession of land to the church on which saint ROBERT build a new monastery and be choose abbot thereof he take with he eleven other devout monk wherewith he furnish the same these he govern in the rigour of a monastical life make himself so perfect a pattern his wonderful abstinence of a abstinence that he never rise from the table with a full stomach and in Lent for the most part his great dainty be bread and water whence it come to pass that at a easter time his appetite and gust of meat be so utter mortify and overthrow that he can not eat the meat which be set before he and when the monk that wait upon he demand why he do not eat if I have some oaten bread reply he moisten with butter I think I shall be able to eat it therefore the monk so holy David refuse to drink the water which he have desire his servant bring some such bread when the holy man reflect with himself that he have give a little favourable scope to his appetite conceive so great fear thereat that become a rigid and severe revenge to himself he refuse to taste it at all but remain fast and that meat so provide he command to be give to the poor that wait at the monastery gate where they find a fair young man of a very beautiful countenance who take the meat with the dish and vanish which as they relate to the holy abbot behold the same dish fall upon the table before he whereby they understand that a angel send from heaven have receive that alm from the holy man 3 OVERDO and above the accustom task of his divine office and his prayer and the effect thereof prayer he daily recite the whole psalter of David contain a hundred and fifty psalm but as once more earnest he make his prayer unto almighty God and with the tear of his devotion abundant trickle down his cheek he pour forth his soul before the court of heaven desire that as well his own as the service of his brethren may be acceptable to the divine majesty and that they may be find worthy to have their name write in the book of life he hear these comfortable word come from above take courage my son for thy prayer be write in heaven only two of they who heart have be always fix to the love of terrene thing be inscribe in the dust of the world and not long after two conuerse common call lay-brother cast off their habit make a miserable end of their life in the world whereby the divine revelation of the holy man be verify 4 pass on WILLIAM but allsoe proclaim he to be a worthy lover of justice and good life 2 at length Eugenius a cistercian monk succeed in the roman primacy pronounce his sentence for Henry Mordach a pious monk of the same profession who be sustain by Osbert the archdeacon not that he judge WILLIAM unfit for the dignity but because he be more incline to the other be a man of his own order therefore the same of saint WILLIAM be thus unjust his great patience tear with the venomous detraction of his adversary he make use of no other weapon for his own defence in all these broil but the bucklar of a content patience with which and the unshake constancy of a virtuous mind he conquer all his trouble he retire himself to Henry bishop of Winchester of who be his uncle he be so courteous entertain that he make his whole family to be observant and dutiful unto he but the holyman abhor the pomp of the world affect more the solitariness of a retire life content himself his pious life and exercise with a little corner of the bishop house where he pious spend his time in watch fast and prayer and the contemplation of divine and heavenly thing he rejoice to have find the leisure of this good occasion to bewail the fault of his life past and to drown the revengeful flame of the pain due thereunto with the sorrowful stream of his devout tear he live in great silence and tranquillity suffer no vain word angelical creature in a humane shape 3 but after the course of seven year in one and the same day pope and Henry archbishop of York change this life for a better who death be by a divine revelation age when other of such royal birth be wont to decline to the vain pleasure of the world she begin to order her life according to the rule of continency to love God above all thing to apply herself to Albanus protomartir in 22 (...) the life of saint Alban the first martyr of great Britain june 22 out of venerable bede and a ancient manuscript of s. Alban when the bloody persecution which the two cruel emperor diocletian and maximian raise against the Catholic church rage over the world the fury thereof be so cruel outrageous that it can not be contain within the bound of the ocean but pour itself out in cruelty even into the remote land of the christian world and among other into our famous island of great Britain where saint Alban be the captain and leader of that sacred warfare who be a citizen of the ancient city of verulam which the place of his birth at that time be a colony under the roman emperor and bear of a famous stock receive first the christian faith by the precept and instruction of the most holy martyr Amphibaluss of who allsoe we must in this history make often and honourable mention for after that by preach he have purchase other country to CHRIST be enkindle with a ardent zeal of gain more and more soul to God church he come to verulam where first with courteous hospitality he be entertain by our Alban as yet a heathen but understand that his new guest be he defire to know the point of faith not only a professor but a teacher all so of the christian name he be desirous to hear he discourse of the assertion of his faith and be as eager to give his host a account thereof hope to win he to the same profession therefore he show he how almighty God consist of one essence and three person so dear love the world that he send the second person in Trinity his only son from heaven as a witness and messenger of his love for the reconciliation and redemption of mankind who when he be true God of God yet so far he humble himself for our health sake that he vouchsafe to take humane flesh upon he and be bear of a virgin albeit he be the maker and creator of the same flesh and of his mother the Virgin and these say he be the principle of our faith these by the instruction of the holy ghost be many age ago know and foretell by many of the jew and since confirm by the wonderful work of CHRIST himself and receive by the common consent of almost all nation and in embrace of these point consist the height of all felicity and perpetual misery follow all that deny they 2 but at first Alban seem to laugh at these thing and contemn they and to hold the teacher of they himself not only to he laugh at the mystery of faith be vain in his doctrine but allsoe scarce sound in his wit in avoch such paradox so abhor as he think from all sense and reason for who can be bring to believe say he that say he that God have a son and the same soon to be make man and bear of a virgin without a father and she to remain both a virgin and a mother in sum that day discourse be break off and Alban be displease with and his doctrine go to please his trouble mind in his bed while his holy teacher sorrowful that his word have take no deep root in the mind of his kind host and still remain careful for his soul health betake himself to his prayer in steed of sleep nether be his petition to almighty God in vain for Alban be oppress under the heavy wing of sleep seem to behold his vision be asleep the whole tragedy of our lord sacred passion so perfect act before he that to his imagination it appear not so much to be in a dream as in very deed represent to his corporal sight terrify therefore out of his sleep with the strangeness of this vision he go forthwith to and desire he if those thing which he preach of CHRIST be true to expound allsoe the meaning and interpretation of his dream who have first give thanks unto almighty God for so wonderful a vocation of his belove host draw out a crucifix expound his dream which he always carry about he and show in that sign how he may plain understand what his nightly vision do portend and follow on with a declaration of Christ gospel and passion conformeable to what he have see in his sleep he so solid discover the mystery of CHRIST crucify that there be no place for any doubt leave in the mind of Alban so powerful the holy ghost have plant the truth of faith in his soul by who sacred unction Alban note the strange and sudden eonuersion of s. Alban be whole replenish with unusual sweetness and contentment of mind desire now nether teacher nor argument to instruct he but of his own accord detest his false god abiur his idol profess to acknowledge no other God to believe no other in his heart to confess no other with his mouth but God the father and his son christ-iesus and he crucify he admire the greatness of the divine piety and goodness in the redemption of mankind and begin whole to be inflame with his love who vouchsafe first so to love humane frailty that he undertake not only our nature but allsoe all the misery adherent thereunto as also a most shameful death itself to redeem man from the tyranny of eternal death to the glory of God elect people nay fall he worship the crucifix prostrate before the cross as if he have see CHRIST himself real hang thereon he embrace and kiss his wound give he infinite thanks for call he to the knowledge of his faith be whole carry beyond himself to think how to appear worthy grateful for the benefit of so undeserved a vocation therefore he bid adieu to all worldly pleasure and embrace tear and sigh for his great delight all other thing he contemn that he may gain CHRIST alone for all in he he place all his hope and love to he he so perfect vow himself and all he have that he will rather a thousand time endure to be rob of this life then to be separate from the faith and charity of his dear redeemer 3 in the confession of these and such like thing admit Alban to the purify grace of baptism and at his he be baptize earnest entreaty remain there some day more ample to instruct he in all thing that belong to the profession of his receive religion but in the mean time the renown name of Alban and the fame of this fact albeit secret perform make that it come to the ear and knowledge of the enemy of the christian cause who envy the advancement thereof make complaint unto the judge of the city and he forth with command both the master and the disciple to be cite to appear before he which cruell-minded decree be soon make know to saint Alban who desire by all mean to prevent the deceit of the prince exhort to fly into Wales depart secret out of town give he a rich garment of his own which at that time be of great dignity and reverence with all man thereby to pass with more security through his enemy but he himself retain his master poor habit for his own use know for certain that the very sight thereof will more vehement incense the fury of he and Christ cruel enemy against he therefore the sun have scarce clear the day follow but take leave of his dear scholar when the tear shed on each side witness the greatness of their mutual love hasten into Wales there to preach the faith of CHRIST and find out a place of martyrdom and Alban clothe in his master weed expect the same glory at Ver^da^ which afterward he most glorious obtain 4 for the same day the furious officer break violent into his s. Alban be apprehend lodging search narrow in every corner thereof and fill the whole house with noise and tumult till come to the little cottage where he and his master have pious spend their time the day before they find s. Alban in a strange habit barefcot humble pray before the sign of Christ holy cross then rush furious in troop upon he they apprehend he bind he and violent hale he some by the garment some by the hair to the presence of the judge who at that time in a great assembly of people be bysy employ in offer sacrifice to his diabolical idol but see Alban lead in that manner his heart boil with rage and fury against he because of his own accord he perceive he bend to hazard his life for who he have entertain therefore he command he to be draw before the idol threaten to make he suffer all the torment due unto his sacrilegious guest so his wicked tongue term holy because as a contemner of the god he have presume to conceal he from the officer and now seem himself to be depart from the profession of his ancient religion but s. Alban he contemn the threat of the judge who have willing betray himself to the persecutor of the christian faith without any sign of fear let pass the storm of the prince threat and fury and arm with the shield of the spiritual warfare bold and plain affirm that he will not obey his command then the judge demand of what family and race he be it appertain not to thou answer Alban to know my lineage but if thou desire to understand the truth of my religion know that I be a Christian and one that embrace all christian duty my parent call i Alban and I adore and worship the true live God the maker and creator of all thing then the judge swell with wrath and fury if thou desire say he to enjoy the happiness of life offer forthwith sacrifice to our great god these sacrifice reply saint Alban which by you be offer to devil can neither help the supplicant sacrificer nor accomplish the end of their desire but reward they in the end with the everlasting torment of Hell v. at these word the judge can no long contain his fury but command the holy confessor of CHRIST to be cruel beat he be cruel beat and torment hope with stripe to overthrow the resolution of his constancy which with word he can not move therefore the lictour execute their office of cruelty upon his holy body in most rude manner when amid the noise of their pitiless whip he joyful call upon the name of our lord JESUS-CHRIST make a willing oblation and sacrifice of himself to his divine goodness till the tormentor be weary with their vain punish and he nothing weary with constant suffering the people obtain to have he imprison for the space of six he be commit to prison month hope that time will wear out the purpose of his resolution in the mean while the heaven witness the injury do to the holy martyr for from the first day of his apprehension to the day of his martyrdom such a intolerable drought by the extremity of the sun heat rage in that province that the fruit of the earth be quite burn up and destroy which the heathen who heart nevertheless be freeze up against the holy flame of true charity judge to be do by the art magic of the imprison Christian therefore the wise of the country be assemble together to discuss this point saint Alban be call out of the horror of the prison to answer for himself at the bar he be release of their examination and be find not guilty they all grien at the injury and suffer in his suffering in so much that a sedition be rise among the citizen and his friend all stand up in his defence and free he out of his belove chain by which they think he injure have all way have the name and fame of a man of good life that he may render a account of his deed before the judge but saint Alban take this kind of mercy as a act of the great cruelty great fear lest his martyrdom shall be defer he exclaim a against idol 5 therefore stand in the midst of the whole assembly he make a new invective declamation against the weakness of their profane god and their blind folly in worship those blind idol whereby they be all incense afresh against he and with one voice pronounce he guilty of death then arise a great contention among they in define with what kind of death to punish he some as a disciple of the crucifix judge he to be crucify other will have he bury alive as enemy to their god the rest think fit to have his eye dig out and send so to seek out his master in fine the ^udge and all the people agree he be condemn to death and condemn he to loose his head therefore be again bind in chain he be rude drag to the design place of his martirdom call Holmhurst on the top of a fair plain hill who pleasantness seem worthy to be consecrate with the blood of our glorious martyr but the throng multitude of people that hasten to see this strange spectacle be so great that come to a large river over which they must pass to the hill the bridge be not able to receive they many that for haste endeavour to wade or swim over be by the fury of those wild stream carry down to a untimely death mean while s. Alban much grieve in mind to see the ruin of those perish soul and perceave his journey to the desire place of martyrdom to be hinder by that huge concourse of people fall down on his knee and humble make his prayer to he who side flow water and blood for the redemption of the world to give a safe passage to that people so desirous to be present at his death then by the almighty power a notable miracle of he that divide the red sea for the israelite the fury of that great river be stop and the channel make dry for the holy martyr to pass the flow of his prayer and tear before almighty God take from the river the power of flow and lay open a fair passage for himself and the people through the water 7 but the virtue of this wonderful miracle give grace to the officer that be appoint to be albans executioner to cast off all the executioner convert thought of such like wolvish cruelty and become a meek lamb of Christ flock for throw away his sword that shall have do that bloody deed he fall prostrate at the holy martyr foot confess his error and humble demand pardon cry aloud that there be no other true God but the god of the christian and earnest desire to die in steed of he who he be command to put to death but his belief move the rest of those minister of mischief to great rage and fury and fall upon that new confessor of CHRIST they beat out his tooth tear his mouth that have give testimony to the truth and so bruise all his limb with cruel blow that in his whole body scarce any one part be leave unhurt yet in heart he remain firm and sound in the confession of his faith but leave this wretched creature in that miserable plight they arrive at length be cruel beat to the top of the hill where a infinite number of people be expect to behold the action of this tragical scene who be general torment with a extremity of heat and drought he obtain a fountain by his prayer s. Alban by his prayer obtain to have a clear fountain spring out of that dry earth by which the multitude quench their thirst yet always thirst for the effusion of his blood by who merit they have receive that benefit so great be the ungrateful cruelty and cruel ingratitude of their blind mind which ascribe all these most sensible miracle to the power of their own senseless god 8 therefore whet still the edge of their own fury on the unshake rock of the holy martyr constancy and virtue they he be behead be more and more incense to the shed of his innocent blood a new executioner be choose to give the deadly blow for they all who at once make a cruel separation of his head from the body that his bless soul may take a happy flight to the crown of everlasting life which our lord have promise to those that suffer for his sake but the cruel executioner be not permit to triumph in his wicked fact for his eye ashamed as it be to the punishment of his executioner behold their master cruelty fall miraculous out of his head at the very instant that he give the martyr his death so that lose the guide that have direct he to do what he do he lose allsoe the power to see what he have do which miracle cause many of the gentile there present to confess that he be just punish mean while the poor soldier who they have leave half dead below have crall to the top of the hill and come to the holy body of saint Alban he be present restore again to the perfect use of all his limb but that happiness be soon after second with a far great for make profession of the faith of a soldier martyr CHRIST he be forthwith behead and by be baptize in his own blood be make worthy to follow his leader saint Alban into the everlasting joy of christ-iesus the eternal crown and glory of his martyr s. Alban be martyr about the year of our salvation three hundred and three and his body be bury in the same place of his martyrdom 9 but about the year of our lord four hundred forty six and a hundred forty three year after the passion of s. Alban the Pelagian heresy as over the rest of the world so chief it reign in great Britain in which it be report to have first begin to suppress this infection saint German bishop of au^er the Pelagian heresy suppress and Lupus bishop of Troy come out of France into our island by the force of who argument and miracle the impudent mouth of the pelagian be stop and at that very time many great miracle and cure of disease person be wrought at the sacred tomb of s. Alban thither the holy bishop go for devotion sake to give thanks unto almighty God for their success and s. German have open the holy monument lay therein many relic of the apostle and other martyr that the same place may contain the bone of they who soul enjoy one and the same glory in heaven which do he take thence some part of the earth which have receive the holy martyr blood and which yet blush therewith to be by he reserve as a most precious treasure the ancient Britan over come by the saxon and a worthy reward of his labour afterward the english and saxon that be pagan like unto a furious tempest invade the island of great Britain and by force of arm drive the ancient inhabitant thereof to the mountain and far part of the country now call Wales persecute not only the man but the christian faith which they profess then among other the ancient city of verulam be destroy and all sacred monument and church demolish the memory of the glorious martyr saint Alban be extinguish for the space of three hundred forty four year and to the reign of the most famous king of the mercian Ossa who follow a divine revelation that command he to search out those holy relic and place they in a more worthy monument assemble the people and clergy together and arm with fast and prayer they ascend the mountain where the holy martyr suffer in the mean time the divine goodness that will not have that treasure lie hide any long send forth a heavenly splendour which glitter over his sepulchre and light they to find out those desire relic for have dig in the same place they find his sacred body in a the invention of s. Alban body wooden chest together with the relic of the apostle and martyr which saint German have place therein therefore the king and whole assembly be replenish with inestimable joy translate that sacred treasure with great veneration and solemnity sing of hymn and praise to almighty into a ancient church near verulam build in time pass to the name and honour of saint Alban where in a very rich shrine make of gold and silver and adorn with precious gem they repose those sacred spoil whereby it be make manifest that as in time pass to Lucian priest the body of the protomartir of jury saint STEPHEN and to king Dagobert the relic of saint Denis the first martyr of France so to our noble Offa almighty God miraculous reveal the body of the prime martyr of great Britain s. Alban in the very same place where the holy martyr have shed his blood for the christian faith this monastery he not only adorn with great wealth and revenue but go himself to Rome and obtain for it large and ample privilege of pope Adrian whereby it be exempt from all episeopall power and jurisdiction and by the royal charter of Offa the exercise of all civil authority within the territorre thereof be deliver into the hand of the abbott and last pope Adrian define in his privilege grant thereunto that as s. Alban who at the earnest desire of king Offa and the whole country he have enrol into the number of canonize saint be know to be the first martyr of Britain so the abbot of his monastery shall always have the precedence before all the other abbot of that country and that abbey be account the principal and head of the rest the abbot of this s. Alban the head ab^ey of England monastery in time past be baron of the realm and parliament man and from the abbey the town build there ^ be to this present call by the name of Sainct-Albans 11 but a far great and more excellent honour come to this monastery by the wonderful miracle which almighty God wrought there by the merit of this glorious martyr s. Alban then by all the other glory of privilege wealth and riches add thereunto nay more the whole country receive infinite benefit of cure of all manner of disease as we may understand out of venerable bede a author beyond all exception who avouch miracle wrought there even unto his time and by the ancient annal of the same monastery wherein the wonder which yearly happen be diligent and faithful set down let we hear the author themselves make a of their own sincerity whatsoever we go about to relate say they of the holy martyr let no man esteem as feign or frivolous for we take God to witness that they be such as either we have see with our own eye or hear report by man of approve credit out of which it shall miracle wrought at his tomb suffice we for the glory of our protomartir brief to rehearse some few 1. his relic be oppose to a furious fire oftentimes extinguish it 2. in extremity of drought his holy body be carry in procession with the usual litany and supplication of the church obtain rain and in time of immoderate rain purchase fair weather 3. those that by a injurious violence presume to rob he of land or riches dedicate to his honour be oftentimes punish with a miserable end 4. one a notable punishment Hugh who with a impious mouth utter reproachful speech against the bless martyr and his sacred solemnity cast forth the excrement of his body at his blasphemous mouth all his life after be just punish in that part which have offend 5. a woman sick of a cruel palsy who for many year be not able to go herself be admonish from heaven enter into the holy martyr church where have make her prayer unto God and his saint at the very time when the priest at mass offer the sacred body of our lord to his father she feel herself strong recover and present walk home in perfect health of all her limb 6. the water which have wash his holy shrine be oftentimes prove sovereign against many disease 7. and the dust gather out of the place where he be bury and put into drink wrought the like miraculous effect but we shall never come to a end if we go about to load this paper with all the miraculous cure do at his tomb blind lame deaf break and contract person receive the wish benefit of their health by the merit of this thrice glorious martyr scarce any disease can be name that be not here cure yea and many dead person be recall Surius ^ tom. 6. jun. 22. intercession and patronage of this glorious martyr saint Alban 12 here it shall not be amiss to admonish my good reader if perchance he light on the writing of some foreign author unskilled in our english history that affirm the body of our saint Alban to have be by the sorenamed saint German translate to Rome and thence afterward again transport by the mean of Theophana the empress to the Benedictine abbey of saint pantaleon at Cullen that he suffer not himself to be easy deceive for all our english writter maintain the contrary first saint bede follow the ancient annal of saint Alban avouch that saint German take only with he some of the dust where his body be lay and not only leave the body itself behind but as we have say place many other relic of other martyr which he have thither bring in the tomb of saint Alban as so many sacred witness and pledge of his devotion to the holy saint which relic to the manifest confutation of the contrary opinion be find there together with the body of s. Alban three hundred forty and odd year after s. germane come into England as Matthew Westminster William of malmesbury and other english writer do testify therefore his body can not be carry out of England by saint German moreover in Surius who I take to be the chief author of the adverse opinion I can but admire one thing as a sign of great partiality in he for have gather the whole life of saint Alban out of venerable bede he willing pass over in silence that act of saint germane put the relic into saint Alban tomb and carry away of the earth imbrue with his blood and why do he so I leave the reason to the judgement of the judicious reader be loath to touch the authority of so great a man it may be because he be himself of Cullen he have rather for the honour of his town report it to be enrich with the whole body of saint Alban then only with some of the dust of his tomb use a figurative speech of rhetorician and put the whole for a part. or else the identity author that affirm his body to be a s. Alba^s of the name of saint Alban martyr of Mentz and our saint Alban of England draw he to report that of we which he shall have say of the other howsoever he be deceive this much we can say on our own behalf ommit to make a argument of the unliklihood of the contrary assertion that Matthew Paris in the year 1179. Matthew Westminster in the year 1259. Walsingham in the year 1313. Henry Huntingdon in the nine book of his history Thomas Rudburne in his great chronicle and other english writter of great credit and authority and far more conversant in our history then any stranger can be do constant affirm that the sacred relic of saint Alban remain always in his own monastery in England and this the ancient record of the same place which I have in my hand do large testify by the undiscontinued relation of the yearly miracle wrought at his tomb to the reign of he^^y the second and in the year of grace 1257. certain workman that be busy in repair the church of saint Alban dig somewhat deep into the ground happen upon the marble tomb in which his body have be lay present after his martyrdom at which time a heavenly splendour shine over his grave and the ravish note of angelical harmony warble four the praise of the holy martyr but the garment of saint Alban his garment find spot with fresh blood master in which saint Alban suffer martyrdom be afterward carry to the benedicti^e monastery of Ely and there in a certain tomb reserve which king Edward the second cause to be open in his own presence when it be find uncorrupted and stain with fresh spot of the blood which he have s^ed for CHRIST who be for ever glorify in his saint amen all ecclesiastical writer make very honourable mention of s. Alban convert many many of the astonish assistant to be far better affect to the christian faith than they be in so much that have they have but a teacher it seem they may easy be bring not only to approve but to embrace it for truth be of their own accord already well incline thereunto nether be the divine goodness want to their good will in this point by who instinct one bold than the rest stand up and in this manner speak unto they if only with word o fellow-citizen Alban have maintain the truth of a citizen speech to his fellow his faith it be not to be admire if all man have reject it as vain and unprofitable doctrine condemn by public law and contrary not only to the institution of our ancestor but even to reason the guide of all thing but now since he have confirm his word and faith with such admirable work whosoever shall presume to deny it will seem in resist Alban to resist God himself by affirm that these wonderful sign proceed from any other author but God or that that faith be not ground in truth which be authorize by the testimony of such divine work for when I pray you do our god ever perform the like when be the like hear off in our religion moreover the singular integrity the praise of s. Alban meekness patience constancy piety and other virtue of of this divine man do set he forth among his other wonderful work for the great wonder be vex with so many taunt and reproach he revile no man be afflict with so many injury he be so far from make the lest show of any indignation of mind that he seem more tobewayle our case then his own nay he go with so joyful and clear a countenance to his last deadly punishment that one will have judge he go to a banquet of mirth and not to the scaffold of death who do not see in this man a divine power great than humane frailty if than these gift do proceed only from God sure he be not wont to bestow they on wicked impious and sacrilegious person but on those that pious and holy serve and worship he nether be it to be doubt but that he will adorn we and our common wealth with these and far great gift than these if we show ourselves pliant and dutiful to his divine call let we therefore follow Alban our captain and courageous embrace his faith and piety which God grant to be fortunate and happy to we our child and our common wealth 2 these and such like word be speak in a great assembly of the citizen of verulam all public proclaim that then the religion of CHRIST nothing be more divine nothing more holy nothing more true therefore they resolve to search the whole country over to find out AMPHIBALUS A^BANS guest who be a teacher of the christian discipline but he be go into Wales where with so happy success he have cast abroad the divine seed of the gospel that he have fill all the country thereabouts with fruit of the evangelicall harvest and the sweet odour of his own fame and name whereupon the citizen of verulam to the number of about a thousand leave their house and home and follow the send of his holy deed and virtue come at length to AMPHIBALUS who have understand of the martirdom of his dear host Alban they be baptize and the cause of their come thither receive they all to the sacrament of the christian faith which they desire and they joyful embrace those divine institution be incense daily with so ardent a desire to profit and perfect themselves in their new-receaved faith that the multitude of faithful christian grow every day great in number and more famous and renown in sanctity 3 but the ancient and common enemy of mankind perceave the evangelicall kingdom to be amplify daily with such joyful increase and his possession to be great diminish by these purchase judge it high time to oppose himself against those proceed and to that end he incense the citizen against their fellow-cittizen those remain at verulam against the other who AMPHIBALUS have now make citizen of the kingdom of heaven against who the burgess of the earth be incense with the fury of the prince of darkness determine to raise a cruel war ground their quarrel on no other theme than that their fellow citizen have forsake the desire and love of the world and be by the mean of AMPHIBALUS range into the warfare of Christ a thousand christian cruel murder holy gospel march therefore against they when they perceive they to be so resolute in the opinion of their new-receaved faith that with courageous mind they be ready to expose their neck to the furious sword of their persecutor set aside all thought either of the name of fellow-cittizen or affinity of blood or dignity of their innocence they make a furious assault upon they be unarm and in most cruel manner bathe their sword in the blood of their own fellow and countryman they in the mean time joyful and willing offer their body to the deadly blow of Christ enemy whereby his triumphant church be adorn with the fresh rose of new troop of holy martyr 4 but apprehend the captain of this holy war AMPHIBALUS reserve for great pain in the midst of those murder body they bring he back to verulam to be there reserve for great and more exquisite torment whither when the news of his come arrive all the town flock out to meet he though not in courtesy but to revenge on he the loss of their fellow-cittizen and kindred of who slaughter they judge he to be the sole and principal author therefore fall violent upon he with so great inhumanity they torment and beat the body of the holy man that they leave no place thereof without the cruel mark of many hurt and wound all which he be report to have endure with so great fortitude of mind that no sign of anger or trouble appear in his countenance when all man hold it for a miracle as indeed it be that his age body be able to endure so many and so great torment with such a unmoved constancy and that they can not force his soul out of that weak lodging with such pain the lest whereof seem more than sufficient to martyr the strong champion in the world v all be astonish and many much grieve at this spectacle many convert to Christ make as the manner be diverse interpretation and construction of the matter some impute it to witchcraft other to a divine power in so much that there want not those that affirm it to be a most unworthy act to exercise so many torment on a innocent man which without note of great cruelty can not be inflict on the wicked malefactor that ever be for what offence be it say they to draw man from the horrible rite of profane sacrifice and from a savage manner of life to a holy and pious way of serve God therefore because AMPHIBALUS teach these thing we ought rather to honour his virtue with all due reverence and with benefit to requite he labour for the common good then so ungrateful and cruel to persecute his innocence and this proceed seem to they to besoe unwarrantable that they feafeared not to affirm the patient to be most grateful to God in suffer such cruelty for virtue sake and the doer themselves to they be martyr with s. be of God most hate for so outrageous persecute a poor innocent on these then speak in this manner and recommend themselves to CHRIST and the prayer of AMPHIBALUS the barbarous multitude exercise their mad cruelty and together with AMPHIBALUS their captain with sword knife and stone batter their soul out of their mortal lodging to take a happy flight to the immortal 6 this holy man be martyr at the village of Rudburne three mile distant from verulam where Thomas Rudburne report that two great knife which have be instrument of this cruelty be reserve to unite to her heavenly spouse the king of king christ-iesus let all the marry admire and the unwarry in their degree endeavour to imitate this example of wonderful continency the like whereof very few be to be find in the ecclesiastical history hear her life i the glorious virgin etheldred be daughter to Anna king her parent of the east-angle and his wife Hereswith adorn the royalty of her blood with the glory of her virtue and sanctity for from her very infancy she study to order all her action to the service of almighty God by avoid the toy company of other maid the virtue of her youth her equal and whole betake herself to embrace chastity modesty humility and all other virtue as the only ornament of a devout soul and that they may be the better plant and root therein she nourish they with the food of her continual prayer and water they with the stream of her devout tear make it her chief exercise to be present at the divine service to visit and frequent church wherein she be more delight then in the splendour of her father royal palace in a word she lead so holy a life in this her tender age that to she may be true apply that say of wisdom a pure and immaculate life adorn with many virtue beget more veneration than many year of old age for he live long that live well 2 at length when this holy virgin have in this virtuous manner she be desire in marriage pass over her young year and be come to a age in which she appear marriageable her virtue of mind wherein she excel and beauty of body wherein she parallele almost all young virgin of that time be by fly fame make celebrious all over the country many prince and noble that frequent her father court be much take therewith and judge it a worldly bliss which they great aim at to be wed to such excellent part seat in so fair a throne of beauty but she contemn all worldly pleasure aspire only and whole to the bedchamber of her eternal spouse christ-iesus for who love she desire always to preserve her chastity untouched sing continual spiritual hymn and canticle to his honour and praise and daily sacrifice herself unto almighty God in the mean time the divine wisdom so dispose it and that her unshake resolution of chastity may in this world be make more famous and deserve a great crown of victory and triumph in the next she be earnest she marry against she will desire in marriage by one Tunbert a prince of the south part of the i will of Ely who have obtain her father consent judge himself sure of his desire till the flat refusal of the holy virgin make he perceive that more than one word be requisite to a bargain then her father interpose his royal authority his virtuous daughter etheldred obey use violence to her own desire to make they subject to her father will therefore be marry in royal manner to the forename prince behold that which amaze the fond world and worldling she be find worthy to imitate the bless virgin Marie and to lead a chaste life together with her husband if he alm deed and other good work for both party be consent to the observance of chastity till a happy death make a separation of that pious union and call Tunbert into a other world to receive the everlasting reward of his continent and chaste life when he have live in the band of a unexperienced wedlock the space of almost three year 3 than although our holy virgin etheldred pious lament she retire to Ely the death of her husband yet in heart she rather rejoice that now she be free from the yoke of matrimony hope by that mean more easy to escape the vain allurement of the world therefore her devotion increase daily and her pious desire be more and more enkindle with the fire of the holy ghost but now her former labour be overcome she be to be draw out and range into a great conflict peculiar good thereof one whereof we can omit in the sixteenth year of the reign of king Henry the first there live in the province of Ely a man call Bricstan who be from his very infancy entangle with the cross and adversity of the world give himself among other vice to deal in the damnable trade of usury by which only he be maintain in the world till have draw his line of life to a great length in such wickedness he fall into a sickness so vehement that it make he apprehend death to be nigh when the extremity of his disease force he to enter into consideration of the miserable state he have live in and be inspire with a heavenly glimpse of divine grace he make a faithful promise to deliver himself to the service of almighty God under the habit of a Benedictine monk in the monastery of saint etheldred at Ely and without any further delay have gather all his good together he go to the monastery bricstan resolve to be a monk and make livery and season of they and himself unto the monk humble crave mercy for his former life but the common enemy of mankind by who envy Adam fall out of paradise stir up a instrument of he and a servant of the king call Robert malarte who in behalf of the king hinder poor brickstans take the habit he be malicious hinder of religion and have lay theft and other great offence to his charge affirm that not to save his soul but to cloak the hay nousnes of his wicked life he seek now to enter into religion in fine Brickstan have no other weapon but his own innocence stand stiff upon his denial as indeed he have reason be guiltless of the crime he be accuse off but the authority of his adversary so prevail against the justice of his cause that he be clap under guard and lead fetter and bind to London where he become a unwilling guest to the jailor in a dark and loathsome prison and load with bolt and iron chain in great misery he a long time feed upon the two common dish of the poor prisoner ordinary cold and hunger 17 in the mean time albeit he find in himself no former merit whereby he may deserve much before the face of almighty in prison he call upon s. Benedict and s. etheldred God yet he cease not to call to his divine goodness for help with a sorrowful heart and voice desire the intercession of the glorious patriarch of monk saint Benedict to who order he have vow himself and of s. etheldred in who monastery he purpose to have embrace the same order and this be his daily and nightly exercise whilst he live in this wretched state of imprisonment which dure five month what more one night when the bell in the city ring to the midnight office of matin and our prisoner have fast three day before lay as he think at such a point of extremity that he expect nothing but death to be the period of his misery yet still call either in mouth or heart on the name of those glorious saint the divine goodness show he a heavenly token and sign of his mercy for s. Benedict and saint etheldred with her sister saint SEXBURG appear visible unto he in the prison with such a glorious lustre to he have a apparition that dark place and such a lightning of comfort to his weak soul darken with sorrow that betwixt joy and amazement he be almost transport beyond himself not know what to say or what to think till those heavenly citizen have make themselves know unto he demand if he will be deliver out of that captivity at which word awake as it be out of a deep sleep he answer that he will most willing enjoy liberty if he think he can any long live but because the force of his body be quite spend he have now no further hope to escape then s. Benedict draw near unto he very gentle pull off his he be release by s.
