by Gilebert the abbot and the whole convent of monk that come in procession to meet he in fine by command of the queen he be honourable convey out of all his trouble to the belove haven of his desire the monastery of Ely carry with he as the trophy of his victory over the world the chain and fetter which have bind he in prison and out of which he be so miraculous release at Ely he be very honourable receive where he bring Briestan become a monk at Ely his former purpose to perfection and put on the habit and profession of a Benedictine moke and his fetter be hang up in the same church before the high altar for a perpetual spectacle and monument of the miracle this happen in the time of Herueus first bishop of the same place 18 THOMAS Walsinghan in his history of England in Richard the second in the year 1389. relate how during the same king reign the holy virgin etheldred appear at two several time to distinct person and foretell strange accident and punishment that shall happen unto the country if they be not avert by the prayer and sacrifice of good man other particularity thereof we omit fear to be over tedious have show sufficient how great a care this glorious saint have of her country let we make intercession unto she that by she merit and prayer she will obtain we grace of almighty God to be free from the yoke and oppression of heresy which in these our day bear so great a head over our miserable country her life we have gather out of the chronicle of Ely which we have in a ancient manuscript write by Thomas of Ely a monk of the same place a^ also out of venerable bede ang. lib. 4. cap. 19 Nicholas Harpsfield sec. 7. cap. 24. and jonne Anglicus recite by John capgrave in his legend of english saint mention be make of she in the roman martirologe and in that of bede ado Vsuard and Wion also William malmesbury lib. 2. gest cap. 13. Matthew Westminster 679. Polidore Virgil lib. 4. Wigorniensis 672. 673. and 679. Trithemius in his three book of the famous man of saint benedict order chap. 122. and many other writer do worthy sound forth her praise and in ancient time her feast be celebrate in England with great solemnity the life of saint Bartholomew priest and monk of the holy order of saint Benedict june 24 write by joannes Anglicus saint Bartholomew bear in Yorkshire in the province of Whiteby in time past call Streanshall be by his parent first name but when he leave the world and enter into a monastical life he leave also that name and be call Bartholomew in his very infancy he give many rare sign of future sanctity and receive from heaven many special favour to confirm the his divine vision same be diverse time visit by our lord JESUS-CHRIST himself in person and by his glorious mother the bless virgin MARY and the holy apostle s. PETER and saint JOHN in his youth he travel into many foreign country and in Norway he be adorn with the sacred dignity of priesthood but return into England he receive the habit of a monk in the Benedictine monastery note a miracle of Durham where enter into the church and make reverence to the crucifix the sacred image of Christ hang on the cross seem with a humble bow of the head to resalute he again in this monastery he lead a very regular and strict life profit daily more and more in humility obedience and all other virtue belong to a monastical life till at length aspire to a more solitary manner of live segregate from all humane company the great patron of that order and monastery s. Cuthbert appear to he in a vision and invite he to live in the island of Farne which be the place that he himself in his life time have honour with his holy conversation Bartholomew be glad of so heavenly a offer so suit with his desire promise to spend the remnant of his life in that island and to that end with much difficulty and importunity he obtain leave of his prior who fear lest so strict a life may be too hard for he to undertake have yet live but a year in the observance of the monastery be the more unwilling to consent to his purpose 2 to the hermitage of Farne than he go where he lead a most his strict life in the the ermitage strict and rigid manner of life he wear a hair shirt next his skin for many year until his prior command the contrary his bed be no other than the hard ground his diet bread and herb he never taste any flesh and after some year he abstain from fish also his drink be fair water and seven year before his death he be report not to have drink at all his clothing be a woollen stamin a cowl and a black cloak line with skin his stocking be also of leather which he never put of until they be quite consume with age for he be wont to say to his brethren that our body be to be use to all manner of hardness and filth if we desire to bring our soul to the perfection of beauty and purity but in all this rigorous manner of life he always carry so pleasant and merry a countenance and have his face so well temper with its natural colour that all that behold it will have judge he rather a great lover of bodily delight and dainty than so severe a chastiser and tamer of his own flesh in prayer so unwearied that beside his ordinary office he recite over David psalter sometime twice sometime thrice every day in the mean he overcome the temptation of the devil time he be grievous vex and assault by many hellish temptation of the devil all which with a firm confidence in almighty God and by the sign of the holy cross and the virtue of holy water he utter vanquish and overthrow 3 he be report also to have wrought many miracle in his life time and to have be comfort with diverse heanenly vision during the time of his strict life in this hermitage among which he behold the soul of Thomas prior of Durham who have leave the regency of the monastery have live a retire life together with he and die in the same island carry up into heaven by the ministry of angelical hand and at length saint Bartholomew himself when he have live forty year and six month in this hermitage in all sanctity and holiness of life have a long time before have a revelation of the hour and time of his death be call out of the thraldom of this world to receive the everlasting reward of his labour in heaven on the very feast of saint JOHN the baptist the four and twentieth day of june he be bury in his oratory in the same place at who tomb many miraculous cure be wrought by the all mighty power of he who be for ever glorious in his saint what year he die be not specify by the author of his life but he must needs have flourish since the year 1100. about which time the Benedictine monk be first introduce into the cathedral church of Durham in the reign of William Rufus the life of s. Bartholomew we have gather out of joannes Anglicus recite by John capgrave in his legend of english saint with who let the truth of this history stand for i have not yet find any other author that make mention of he the life of saint adalbert deacon confessor and monk of the holy order of saint Benedict June 25. out of a ancient manuscript recite by Surius to 3. this holy man be one of those twelve Benedictine monk which s. egbert send as so many elect apostle to preach the faith of Christ in Germany of which mission you may read more in the life of saint Swibert march the first and in that of saint egbert April the twenty four he be son to Edilbald king of the Deiri and nephew to saint oswald king of the Northumber but esteem the gain of the kingdom of heaven before all worldly greatness he despise the royal wealth dignity and honour of his birth and embrace first a monastical life in England afterward he become a disciple to saint egbert in Ireland in a more rigid and strict observance of the Benedictine rule and profession and last be make deacon he be join to eleven other priest and Benedictine monk to make up the number of twelve apostolical man which as we have say saint egbert send to announce the he convert many in Germany christian faith to the barbarous pagan of Germany adalbert therefore for the love of CHRIST and the advancement of his holy gospel go courageous with the rest and at Egmond in Holland he employ his best labour for the conversion of soul to CHRIST and his church where after he have reap a most happy and fruitful harvest in the vineyard of our lord and reduce great multitude of heathen out of the blind night of idolatry to the comfortable light of Christ gospel famous for his holy life and miracle which it please allmighiie God to work by his merit for the better confirm of what he preach he end his toilsome day in this world and depart to the eternal reward of his labour in heaven the five and twentieth day of june about the year of our lord 705. he be bury at Egmond in Holland where his tomb flourish wonderful with many great miracle wrought thereat 2 afterward in the time of Theodoricke the first duke of Holland his holy body be take out of the earth where under his coffin there appear a fountain of most pure water spring out of the ground and the pall in which that sacred treasure be wrap they find to be as entire and uncorrupted as it be at the first and the elevation of his body the same Theodoricke build a chapel in a place call hallen in which the holy body be place with great reverence and solemnity but his son Theodoricke the young be a most fervent follower of his father devotion found there a goodly monastery of s. b^nedicts order in honour of s. adalbert by who merit his son egbert a monastery dedicate to his name afterward archbishop of trevir be cure of a tedious and cruel fever which have give the foil to all the skill of human physic this monastery of Egmond be hold for antiquity and dignity the noble in all holland in which lie bury the body of many prince expect the dreadful summons of the last trumpet who in their life endow it with many rich gift and possession many other miracle be wrought at the same place by the merit of this glorious saint which be contain in the history of his life write by the monk of Medeloc and recite by Surius in his three tome out of which we have gather thus much of he the roman martirologe make mention of he as also that of ado and Wion also Molanus in his index of the saint of Belgia Trithemius in his three book of the famous man of s. benedict order chap. 294. Baronius tom. 8. 697. marcellinus in the life of s. Swibert and other the end of june and the first tome
